Turning power up or down does not solve the basic problem of two groups on the same channel, and cancelling the net is unnecessary if a clear frequency can be found. Memory Trick: Net control rule: "Ask or move, never shove."
If a net is about to begin on a frequency that you and another station are using, what should you do?
Transmit as long as possible on the frequency so that no other stations may use it
As a courtesy, move to a different frequency
Increase your power output to ensure that all net participants can hear you

As a courtesy, move to a different frequency is correct because good operating practice avoids unnecessary conflict and leaves scheduled nets room to function. Power wars or deliberately holding the frequency are poor etiquette, and you do not have to shut down completely, just move. Memory Trick: "When the net comes near, clear the gear."
If propagation changes during your contact and you notice increasing interference from other stations on the same frequency, what should you do?
Tell the interfering stations to change frequency, since you were there first
Report the interference to your Section Manager at Radio Amateurs of Canada (RAC)

Move to another frequency is correct because conditions can make distant QSOs suddenly overlap; the simplest cure is to QSY and avoid mutual interference. Being "there first" does not give you ownership, and complaining or raising power just adds to the mess. Memory Trick: Interference rule: "If it gets crowded, slide away, not shout louder."
When selecting a single-sideband voice transmitting frequency, what minimum frequency separation from a contact in progress should you allow to minimize interference?

Approximately 3 kHz is correct because an SSB signal typically occupies about 2.4–3 kHz of bandwidth, so being at least 3 kHz away keeps your audio from spilling into the other QSO. A 150–500 Hz separation is far too close, while 6–10 kHz is more than needed. Memory Trick: "For SSB, think 3 kHz free."
A schedule of additional band allocations for recommendation to the International Telecommunication Union
A voluntary division of an amateur radio band to avoid interference between incompatible modes
A schedule of operating restrictions within a band prescribed by Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada
A plan devised by a club for the effective use of a frequency band during a contest

A voluntary division of an amateur radio band to avoid interference between incompatible modes is correct because band plans are agreed guidelines by amateurs (not laws) that group voice, CW, digital, repeaters, etc., into different segments. They are not official regulations or contest-only plans. Memory Trick: Band plan = "gentlemen's agreement map" of the band.
Before transmitting, the first thing you should do is:
make an announcement on the frequency indicating that you intend to make a call
listen carefully so as not to interrupt communications already in progress
ask if the frequency is occupied

Listen carefully so as not to interrupt communications already in progress is correct because "listen before transmitting" is the most basic on-air courtesy and helps you avoid doubling over someone. Asking if the frequency is in use comes after you have listened for a while. Memory Trick: LBT = "Listen Before Transmit."
What is the correct way to call "CQ" when using Morse code?
Send the letters "CQ" three times, followed by the word "DE," followed by your call sign once
Send the letters "CQ" ten times, followed by the word "DE," followed by your call sign once
Send the letters "CQ" until someone answers
Send the letters "CQ" three times, followed by the word "DE," followed by your call sign three times

Send the letters "CQ" three times, followed by "DE" and your call sign three times is correct because this standard pattern is easy to copy and clearly identifies who is calling. One call sign might be missed in QSB, and endlessly sending CQ wastes band space. Memory Trick: Same 3–3 pattern as voice: "CQ CQ CQ DE VE3XXX VE3XXX VE3XXX."
How should you answer a routine Morse code "CQ" call?
Send the other station's call sign twice, followed by the word "DE," followed by your call sign twice
Send your call sign four times
Send the other station's call sign once, followed by the word "DE," followed by your call sign four times
Send your call sign followed by your name, station location and a signal report

Send the other station's call sign twice, "DE," then your call sign twice is correct because it immediately tells the CQ-ing station the call is for them and clearly identifies you. Just sending your call or a long introduction is less clear and less efficient. Memory Trick: "You-you DE me-me" on CW.
At what speed should a Morse code "CQ" call be transmitted?
At the highest speed at which you can control the keyer
At any speed which you can reliably receive
At the customary speed for the band
At the highest speed your keyer will operate

At any speed which you can reliably receive is correct because you must be able to copy replies to your own CQ. It does not matter what your keyer can send; if you cannot copy at that speed, the QSO will fail. Memory Trick: "Send at the speed your ears, not your keyer, can handle."

Calling any station is correct because CQ is the general call inviting any operator listening to answer. It does not mean testing or frequency in use. Memory Trick: Think "Seek you" as a sound-alike for CQ = "I seek any station."
What is the meaning of the word "DE" in Morse code?

From is correct because "DE" is used to introduce the station sending, as in "CQ CQ CQ DE VA3ABC" meaning "CQ ... from VA3ABC." It is not a Q-signal and does not mean "all received." Memory Trick: Think of DE as the French "de" ("from") – same idea.
What is the meaning of the Morse code signal "K"?

Any station please reply is correct because "K" invites a response from whoever is being called (or from any station, depending on context). "AR" means end of message, and "R" means received. Memory Trick: Hear "K" as "OK, go ahead."
What is meant by the term "DX"?

Distant station is correct because DX is ham shorthand for long-distance communication, typically outside your own country or region. It is not a procedure word like "go ahead" or a greeting. Memory Trick: DX = "distance × extra" – far away contacts.
What is the meaning of the term "73"?

Best regards is correct because "73" is the traditional telegraphy sign-off meaning friendly regards. "88" is the one that means "love and kisses," not 73. Memory Trick: 73 = "best regards"; 88 = "hugs and kisses."
Which of the following describes full break-in CW (QSK)?
Automatic keyers are used instead of hand keys
An operator must activate a manual send/receive switch before and after every transmission
Stations wishing to break in must send the Morse code signal "BK"
Incoming signals are received between transmitted dots and dashes

Incoming signals are received between transmitted dots and dashes is correct because in full break-in (QSK) the transmitter and receiver switch fast enough that you can hear other stations while you are sending. It does not require manual switches or special "BK" use. Memory Trick: QSK = "Quickly hear While Keying."
When selecting a CW transmitting frequency, what minimum frequency separation from a contact in progress should you allow to minimize interference?

150 Hz to 500 Hz is correct because CW signals are very narrow, typically a few tens of hertz wide, so a few hundred hertz separation is usually enough to prevent overlap. 1–3 kHz spacing is more than necessary for CW and is typical of SSB. Memory Trick: "CW is thin, so a few hundred hertz keeps you in."
What is the meaning of the Morse code signal "R"?

All received is correct because "R" acknowledges that you copied the previous transmission, similar to "roger" in voice. "AR" (· – · – ·) means end of message, and "AGN" (again) would ask for a repeat. Memory Trick: R = "Received."

Signal reception is correct because RST reports describe how well the other station's signal is being received: how readable it is, how strong it is, and (for CW) how clean the tone is. They do not directly describe power, sunspots, or propagation conditions, only what you actually hear. Memory Trick: Think "RST = Receiving Signal Test" to remember it is about what you hear at your receiver.
What does "RST" stand for in a signal report?

Readability, signal strength, tone is correct because the R digit (1–5) describes how easy the signal is to copy, the S digit (1–9) is its strength, and the T digit (1–9, for CW) describes the purity of the tone. The other options use words that are not part of the standard reporting system. Memory Trick: R = Readable, S = Strong, T = Tone.
What is the meaning of: "Your signal report is 5 7"?
Your signal is perfectly readable and moderately strong
Your signal is readable with considerable difficulty
Your signal is perfectly readable with near pure tone
Your signal is perfectly readable, but weak

Your signal is perfectly readable and moderately strong is correct because R = 5 means "perfectly readable" and S = 7 is a moderately strong signal on the S scale. Tone is not part of a normal voice R S report, so the other tone based interpretation is incorrect here. Memory Trick: Think "5 = fine copy, 7 = solid but not blasting."
What is the meaning of: "Your signal report is 3 3"?
Your signal is readable with considerable difficulty and weak in strength
Your signal is unreadable, very weak in strength
The station is located at latitude 33 degrees

Your signal is readable with considerable difficulty and weak in strength is correct because R = 3 means you can copy it, but it is hard work, and S = 3 means the signal is weak. The other choices confuse the RST numbers with unrelated numbering. Memory Trick: "3 3" = "hard to hear and weak" on both counts.
What is the meaning of: "You are 5 9 plus 20 dB"?
Repeat your transmission on a frequency 20 kHz higher
Your signal strength has increased by a factor of 100
You are perfectly readable with a signal strength 20 decibels greater than S9
The bandwidth of your signal is 20 decibels above linearity

You are perfectly readable with a signal strength 20 decibels greater than S9 is correct because "5 9" is the standard "loud and clear" report, and "plus 20 dB" means the S meter is 20 dB above its S9 calibration point. It does not tell you to change frequency. Memory Trick: "5 9 plus something" always means "very strong and very clear," with the "plus" number showing how far above S9.
A distant station asks for a signal report on a local repeater you monitor. What do you report?
Your S-meter reading on the repeater output frequency
Your S-meter reading on the repeater input frequency
The readability and strength of the repeater signal
The quality of the station's signal and audio as heard through the repeater

The quality of the station's signal and audio as heard through the repeater is correct because the useful information is how well that station is being repeated at your end. The S meter tells you more about the repeater output than about the original station. Memory Trick: On a repeater, you always report "how you sound coming out of the machine."

Your receiver's S-meter is calibrated to a standard of 6 dB per S-unit per a recommendation by the International Amateur Radio Union (IARU). The S-meter shows S9 when receiving a station transmitting with 100 watts. Neglecting propagation changes, what transmitter power would cause your receiver's S-meter to read S8?

25 watts is correct because a one S unit change (from S9 down to S8) is 6 dB, and a 6 dB decrease in power is a reduction by a factor of 4. One quarter of 100 watts is 25 watts. Memory Trick: Remember "6 dB = 4 times" power change; going down one S unit means divide power by 4.

Assume your receiver's S-meter is calibrated to a standard of 6 dB per S-unit per a recommendation by the International Amateur Radio Union (IARU). The S-meter on your receiver shows S8 when listening to a nearby transmitter. Approximately how much must the transmitter power be raised to increase the reading to S9?

4 times is correct because going up one S unit (S8 to S9) is an increase of 6 dB on a properly calibrated meter, and 6 dB corresponds to four times the power. The other factors do not match the standard dB to power relationship. Memory Trick: "One S step up = 4 times the power."
What does "RST 579" mean in a Morse code contact?
Your signal is fairly readable, fair strength, and with perfect tone
Your signal is barely readable, moderately strong, and with a faint ripple
Your signal is perfectly readable, moderately strong, and with perfect tone
Your signal is perfectly readable, weak strength, and with perfect tone

Your signal is perfectly readable, moderately strong, and with perfect tone is correct because R = 5 means "perfectly readable," S = 7 means "moderately strong," and T = 9 is "perfect tone." The other choices change either the readability or strength numbers. Memory Trick: 5 7 9 is the "good solid CW" report: clear, good strength, clean tone.
What does "RST 459" mean in a Morse code contact?
Your signal is very readable, very strong, and with perfect tone
Your signal is barely readable, very weak, and with perfect tone
Your signal is moderately readable, very weak, and with hum on the tone
Your signal is quite readable, fair strength, and with perfect tone

Your signal is quite readable, fair strength, and with perfect tone is correct because R = 4 means "readable with practically no difficulty," S = 5 is "fair strength," and T = 9 again indicates a pure tone. The other answers misinterpret the R, S, or T values. Memory Trick: 4 5 9 is "almost 5 5 9": good copy, middling strength, clean tone.
In voice contacts, what is the meaning of "Your signal report is 1 1"?
Your signal is unreadable, and barely perceptible
Your signal is 11 dB over S9
Your signal is moderately readable with moderate strength
Your signal is very readable and very strong

Your signal is unreadable, and barely perceptible is correct because R = 1 is "unreadable" and S = 1 is "faint, barely perceptible." It does not describe an S meter reading above S9. Memory Trick: "1 1" = "almost nothing there."
What does the code "QRS" mean in amateur radio?

Send more slowly is correct because QRS specifically requests the other operator to reduce their sending speed in CW. It has nothing to do with static, signal reports, or locations. Memory Trick: Think "QRS = Quick? Reduce Speed."
What does the code "QTH" mean in amateur radio?

My location is ... is correct because QTH is the Q code used to give or ask for a station's location. It does not refer to name or time. Memory Trick: QTH = "Q-Topographic Home" to remember it is about where you are.
What is the proper Q code to use to see if a frequency is in use before transmitting on CW?

QRL? is correct because it means "Is this frequency in use?" and is the standard CW way of checking before you call. QRV means "I am ready," QRU means "I have nothing for you," and QRZ means "Who is calling me?" Memory Trick: QRL = "Q, is this frequency already in use?"
What does the code "QSY" mean in amateur radio?
Change frequency is correct because QSY means moving to another frequency or asking someone else to move. It is not related to power or speed. Memory Trick: QSY = "Q, Shift Your frequency."
What does the code "QSB" mean in amateur radio?

Your signal is fading is correct because QSB is used when signals slowly rise and fall due to propagation changes. It does not mean busy, empty, or confirmed. Memory Trick: QSB = "Signal Bouncing" up and down.
What is the correct Q code to ask who is calling you?

QRZ? is correct because it means "Who is calling me?" and is often used when several stations call at once or the operator did not catch the call sign. QSL is about confirming, QRL is about frequency in use, and QRT means stopping transmission. Memory Trick: QRZ = "Who aRe you?" on CW.
What does the code "QRM" mean in amateur radio?

I am being interfered with is correct because QRM refers to man made interference from other stations. Static noise from nature is QRN, not QRM. Memory Trick: QRM = "Radio Men" interfering (man made signals).
What does the code "QRN" mean in amateur radio?

I am troubled by static is correct because QRN refers to natural noise like thunderstorms or atmospheric static. QRM is the code for interference from other stations. Memory Trick: QRN = "Noise" from Nature.
What is the Q code indicating that you want the other station to send slower?
QRS is correct because it means "Send more slowly." QRM is about interference, QRL is about the frequency being busy, and QRN is static. Memory Trick: QRS = "Reduce Speed."
What is the Q code that means "Who is calling me?" in amateur radio?

QRZ? is correct because it means "Who is calling me?" and is used when you know someone is calling but did not fully copy their call sign. The other Q codes refer to readability (QRK), low power (QRP), or interference (QRM). Memory Trick: Think "QRZ = Who aRe you?" when you did not catch the caller.
What is the Q code that means "I will call you again" in amateur radio?

QRX is correct because it means "I will call you again" or "Stand by, I will call you later." QRZ means "Who is calling me?", QRS means "Send more slowly", and QRT means "Stop sending". Memory Trick: QRX = "Q, Reminder neXt time" — I will call you again.
When may you use your amateur radio station to transmit an "SOS" or "MAYDAY"?
Only at specific times (at 15 and 30 minutes after the hour)
Only in case of a severe weather watch

In a life-threatening distress situation is correct because SOS and MAYDAY are reserved for immediate danger to life or serious risk to a vessel, aircraft, or person. Using them in non life-threatening situations is illegal and can delay help to real emergencies. Memory Trick: "MAYDAY" = "My life is in danger" — anything less is not MAYDAY.
You need to summon help while stranded in a remote location, but without immediate risk to life. What priority is your message?

Urgent is correct because urgency traffic covers very important situations that are not yet immediately life threatening, while distress is reserved strictly for current danger to life. Safety and welfare traffic are lower in priority. Memory Trick: Order them in your mind as Distress > Urgent > Safety/Welfare.
What voice signal, transmitted three times, signifies distress?

MAYDAY is correct because "MAYDAY MAYDAY MAYDAY" is the internationally recognized voice distress call for life threatening emergencies. SOS is used as a Morse code distress signal, and the words EMERGENCY or HELP by themselves do not have the same formal, protected meaning. Memory Trick: Voice = MAYDAY, Morse = SOS.
What is the correct distress signal in Morse code?

SOS is correct because the Morse pattern "SOS" ("dit dit dit dah dah dah dit dit dit") is the standard global distress signal in Morse. CQD and other older codes are obsolete and no longer used as the official distress call. Memory Trick: Remember the simple three three three pattern of SOS.
What is the correct way to interrupt a repeater conversation to seek assistance in a distress situation?
Break in between transmissions to state your call sign and situation
Say "HELP" as many times as it takes to get someone to answer

Break in between transmissions to state your call sign and situation is correct because you should clearly identify yourself and briefly describe the emergency so that others can assist or relay. Shouting random words may confuse other operators or be misunderstood. Memory Trick: Wait for a pause, then "CALLSIGN — EMERGENCY" with short, clear facts.
What is the advantage of preparing to operate your station without commercial AC power?
So you may use your station while mobile
So you may provide communications during a power outage
So you will comply with the rules
So you may operate in contests where AC power is not allowed

So you may provide communications during a power outage is correct because emergency and public service work often occurs when mains power has failed. Having batteries, generators, or solar power lets you keep operating when others cannot. Memory Trick: "No mains = your station becomes the lifeline."
In an emergency, what additional equipment is crucial to maintaining communications with a hand held radio?
A microphone headset for hands free operation
An adequate supply of charged batteries

An adequate supply of charged batteries is correct because a hand held radio is useless once its battery is drained. Extra antennas or amplifiers may help performance, but power is the limiting factor in extended emergencies. Memory Trick: For handhelds, "No volts = no voice."
Which type of antenna would be a good choice as part of a portable HF station that could be set up in case of an emergency?

A dipole or a vertical is correct because both are relatively simple, lightweight, and quick to install in temporary or emergency locations, while still providing good performance. Multi element beams and dishes are heavier, more complex, and harder to erect in a hurry. Memory Trick: In emergencies think "simple wire or simple vertical," not big towers.
If you are communicating with another station and hear a station in distress break in, what should you do?
Acknowledge the station in distress and determine its location and what assistance may be needed
Continue your communication because you were on frequency first
Change to a different frequency so the station in distress may have a clear channel to call for assistance
Immediately cease all transmissions because stations in distress have emergency rights to the frequency

Acknowledge the station in distress and determine its location and what assistance may be needed is correct because your first duty is to help coordinate aid or relay the information if others can help more effectively. Simply leaving the frequency may result in nobody answering the distress call. Memory Trick: Hear distress = respond, gather facts, then help or relay.
In order of priority, a distress message comes before:

An emergency message is correct because in standard radio traffic priority, distress traffic (immediate danger to life) is highest, followed by urgent or emergency messages, then safety and routine traffic. This is true even compared to most other government or routine priority traffic. Memory Trick: Remember "Life first" at the top of any priority list.
If you hear distress traffic and are unable to render direct assistance you should:
tell all other stations to cease transmitting
contact authorities and maintain watch in case your assistance is needed
enter the details in the logbook and take no further action

Contact authorities and maintain watch in case your assistance is needed is correct because even if you cannot help directly, you can pass the information to the appropriate rescue or safety organization and continue to monitor in case you can relay further details. Memory Trick: "Hear MAYDAY = Inform and Monitor" even if you cannot personally respond.
A notice of an apparent infraction from Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada
A postcard reminding you when your certificate will expire
A letter or postcard from an amateur radio operator
A written proof of communication between two amateur radio operators

A written proof of communication between two amateur radio operators is correct because QSL cards serve as confirmations of contacts, often used for awards or as souvenirs. They are not official notices from regulators. Memory Trick: QSL = "I confirm receipt" — so a QSL card is a "contact confirmed" card.
A map projection centred on a given location
A map projection displaying Maidenhead grid squares
A map projection centred on the magnetic North Pole
A map projection centred on the geographic North Pole

A map projection centred on a given location is correct because an azimuthal map shows the world as seen from one central point, with directions and great circle paths radiating from that point. This is useful in amateur radio for aiming directional antennas. Memory Trick: Think "Azimuthal = All directions from me."
While making a contact in a VHF contest, the other operator asks for your grid square. What information is requested?
The elevation of your station in thirty metre increments
Your location expressed as a 4 or 6 character code
Your antenna azimuth stated in compass degrees
The number of contacts you have made

Your location expressed as a 4 or 6 character code is correct because grid squares (Maidenhead locators) encode latitude and longitude into a short code such as "FN25" or "FN25dk". They are not counts, elevation, or antenna headings. Memory Trick: "What grid?" = "What coded location?"
A directional antenna pointed in the long path direction to another station is generally oriented how many degrees from its short path heading?

180 degrees is correct because the long path is roughly the opposite direction around the Earth from the short path. Turning 180 degrees points the antenna along the other great circle route between the two stations. Memory Trick: Short path vs long path = "front" and "exactly opposite" (180 degrees).
What method is used by amateur radio operators to provide proof of communication with another station?
A letter detailing contact date, time, frequency, mode and power
A radiogram sent over amateur radio traffic nets
A brief email or text message
A QSL card or entries in web based logging systems

A QSL card or entries in web based logging systems is correct because these are the standard, widely accepted methods for confirming contacts, especially for awards and DX records. Letters or casual emails are not normally used as formal proof. Memory Trick: Think "QSL card or online QSL" as your official contact receipt.

Local stations are in contact with New Zealand, yet you cannot hear the New Zealand amateur radio operators with your antenna pointed in that direction. What other antenna direction could you try to hear them?
Point your antenna 180 degrees from the current bearing
Point your antenna 90 degrees west of the current bearing
Point your antenna 90 degrees east of the current bearing

Point your antenna 180 degrees from the current bearing is correct because sometimes propagation is better via the long path rather than the short path. Pointing 180 degrees opposite gives you a chance to work the same station by the other great circle route. Memory Trick: "No luck short? Try the opposite direction for long path."
Which statement about recording all contacts and unanswered CQ calls in a paper or computer based station logbook is NOT correct?
A logbook is important for handling neighbour interference complaints
A logbook is a regulatory requirement
A logbook is important for recording contacts for operating awards
A well kept logbook preserves your fondest amateur radio memories for years

A logbook is a regulatory requirement is the NOT correct statement because in Canada there is no general legal requirement to keep a logbook for ordinary amateur operation, although it is strongly recommended. The other statements describe real practical benefits of logging. Memory Trick: "Good practice, not law" — logging helps you, but is usually not mandatory.
What is the most useful function of an azimuthal world map centred on your location?
To associate distances with optimal ionospheric region
To show the azimuth to meteor showers throughout the year
To show the bearing to any location
To allow computing the radiation angle to any location

To show the bearing to any location is correct because an azimuthal map centred on your QTH lets you read the compass heading (azimuth) directly from you to any DX location. The other options talk about angles, ionospheric layers, or meteor showers, which are not what this map is primarily for. Memory Trick: Azimuthal map = azimuth (compass bearing) from me.
Activity schedules, time entries in logbooks and contact confirmations usually refer to UTC (Coordinated Universal Time). What is the location of the meridian from which this time is measured?

Greenwich, United Kingdom is correct because UTC is based on the zero degree longitude line, historically called the Greenwich Meridian. The other cities are important technically or politically, but not the reference for UTC. Memory Trick: Think of UTC as "Greenwich Mean Time" modernized.
Your time zone is UTC minus 6 hours. You want to join a net scheduled for 19:00 UTC. What is the local scheduled time?

1:00 PM is correct because you subtract 6 hours from 19:00 UTC: 19 − 6 = 13, which is 13:00 (1 PM) local time the same day. The other answers either add hours or shift to the wrong time of day. Memory Trick: Local time = UTC − 6, so "19 minus 6 equals 13".
What is the usefulness of stations CHU, WWV and WWVH to amateur radio operators?
Provide accurate and precise frequency and time signals
Provide received signal reports of your transmissions

Provide accurate and precise frequency and time signals is correct because CHU, WWV and WWVH transmit standard time and frequency signals that hams can use to set clocks and check frequency calibration. They may also announce propagation info, but their primary role is standards, not reports or bulletins. Memory Trick: Think "WWV = World Wide time and frequency."
To be most effective, where should a low-pass filter be connected in an HF station without an external power amplifier?
Between the antenna tuner and the antenna switch
As close as possible to the antenna switch output
As close as possible to the transceiver output
Between the SWR meter and the antenna tuner

As close as possible to the transceiver output is correct because the low pass filter should clean up the signal (remove harmonics) immediately after it is generated, before it goes into the rest of the RF chain. Placing it later may allow harmonics to be radiated or cause problems in other equipment. Memory Trick: First clean it, then send it down the line.
In an HF station that includes an external RF power amplifier, where should a low-pass filter be located?
Between the SWR meter and the antenna tuner
Between the antenna tuner and the antenna switch
As close as possible to the transceiver output
As close as possible to the external amplifier output

As close as possible to the external amplifier output is correct because the amplifier can also generate harmonics. The filter must sit right after the last stage that can create unwanted high frequency components. Filtering only at the exciter output (the transceiver) is not enough. Memory Trick: Last RF stage, then low-pass, then antenna.
Why do modern HF transmitters have a built-in low-pass filter in their RF output circuits?
To reduce RF energy below a cut-off point

To reduce harmonic emissions is correct because a low pass filter passes the wanted fundamental frequency and attenuates higher harmonic frequencies that would cause interference on other bands and services. It is not meant to reduce the main carrier itself. Memory Trick: Low-pass = let the main (low) band through, knock the high harmonics down.
Which component in an HF station is used to determine if the antenna system impedance is matched to the transmitter?

SWR meter is correct because it measures the standing wave ratio on the feed line, which directly indicates how well the antenna system impedance is matched to the transmitter. Frequency meters, multimeters and S-meters do not measure line matching. Memory Trick: SWR = Standing Wave Ratio = "how well the antenna line is matched."
What is the purpose of the antenna switch in an HF station?
To adjust the impedance of the antenna system
To select the orientation of the antenna
To select the desired antenna or dummy load
To adjust the antenna operating frequency

To select the desired antenna or dummy load is correct because an antenna switch simply routes the transmitter output to one of several antennas or to a dummy load. It does not tune, match, or rotate the antenna. Memory Trick: Switch = choose the path, not change the antenna itself.
In an HF station, what device might allow the use of an antenna on a band it was not designed for?

An antenna tuner is correct because it adjusts the impedance seen by the transmitter so that it can safely feed an antenna that is not resonant on that band. Filters only shape spectrum, and an SWR meter only measures match; neither one corrects the mismatch. Memory Trick: "Tuner tunes, meter measures."
In an HF station, which component is designed to dissipate RF energy and prevent radiation?

Dummy load is correct because it is a non-radiating 50 ohm (typically) load that converts RF power into heat so you can test or tune without radiating a signal. A lightning protector is for surges, a low pass filter shapes spectrum, and a heat sink only removes heat from components. Memory Trick: Dummy load = "invisible antenna" that only makes heat.
In an HF station, right after which component is the SWR meter inserted?
The last stage of RF amplification

The low-pass filter is correct because the usual order is: transmitter and final amplifier → low pass filter (to clean harmonics) → SWR meter (to monitor the signal going to the system) → tuner/switch → antenna. Placing the SWR meter after the filter lets you see what is actually being fed toward the antenna system. Memory Trick: Clean it, then measure it, then send it.
When using an HF transmitter with a solid-state final amplifier, which station component may need to be adjusted when changing frequency?

Antenna tuner is correct because when you change frequency, the antenna system may no longer be well matched, and the tuner must be readjusted to keep the SWR low and protect sensitive solid-state finals. The SWR meter and dummy load do not need "adjustment", and built-in filters are usually switched automatically. Memory Trick: New frequency, new tune.
What does the microphone produce in an FM transmitter?
An electrical signal driving the oscillator
A radio frequency signal driving the speech amplifier
A radio frequency signal driving the power amplifier
An electrical signal driving the speech amplifier

An electrical signal driving the speech amplifier is correct because the microphone converts sound (air pressure changes) into a low level audio voltage, which is then amplified and used to modulate the RF stages. The mic never generates RF itself. Memory Trick: Mic = audio only; RF is created later.
The microphone of an FM transmitter:
produces an electrical signal from air pressure changes
is quieter than AM or SSB microphones
has a different tone than other microphones
has a wider frequency range than other microphones

Produces an electrical signal from air pressure changes is correct because that is the basic function of any microphone: sound in, small audio voltage out. FM, AM and SSB microphones all work on the same physical principle; the mode is decided later in the transmitter. Memory Trick: Microphone = "air to volts" device.
produces amplitude changes in the oscillator
affects the frequency of the oscillator
has no effect on the frequency of the oscillator
alters the radio's output signal amplitude

Affects the frequency of the oscillator is correct because in frequency modulation (FM) the information is carried by changing the instantaneous frequency of the carrier, not its amplitude. The other options describe AM or no modulation at all. Memory Trick: FM = Frequency Moves.
How is the oscillator in the FM transmitter different from oscillators in AM, CW, and SSB transmitters?
The modulator changes its output amplitude
It runs at much higher frequencies

The modulator alters its frequency is correct because in an FM transmitter the audio signal causes the oscillator frequency to swing slightly above and below the centre frequency. In AM/SSB/CW systems the oscillator frequency is usually fixed and the amplitude or envelope is changed instead. Memory Trick: FM oscillator = "wiggling frequency" instead of "wiggling height."
In an FM transmitter, the frequency multiplier:
allows the oscillator to be run at very high frequencies
is the major load fed by the power supply
produces a low distortion audio response
produces the FM output carrier frequency

Produces the FM output carrier frequency is correct because the oscillator often runs at a lower frequency where modulation is easier and more stable, and a frequency multiplier (or chain of them) multiplies that modulated signal up to the final transmit frequency. The other options confuse its role with power or audio stages. Memory Trick: Multiplier = "frequency stretcher" that gets you to the band you want.
In an FM transmitter, which stage produces a useful harmonic?

Frequency multiplier is correct because it is specifically designed and tuned to use harmonics of the oscillator to generate a higher transmit frequency. Random harmonics from other stages are usually unwanted. Memory Trick: Only the multiplier wants harmonics; everywhere else, harmonics are trouble.
In an FM transmitter, which stage draws the most electric power?

Power amplifier is correct because it must deliver significant RF power to the antenna, so it draws the largest current from the power supply. Oscillator, speech amplifier, and multiplier stages operate at much lower power levels. Memory Trick: The stage that sends power to the antenna is the stage that eats most of the power from the supply.
In a superheterodyne receiver, which stage is called the front-end?

RF amplifier is correct because the "front end" is the first RF stage that the antenna signal meets. It sets the overall sensitivity and noise figure before the signal is converted to the IF. The other stages come later in the signal chain. Memory Trick: Front end = first RF stage after the antenna.
In a VHF superheterodyne receiver, which stage must be designed to produce very little noise?

RF amplifier is correct because noise added in the very first RF stage dominates the whole receiver's noise figure, especially at VHF. Later stages cannot "fix" noise that is already added. Memory Trick: Quietest stage must be the very first one.
In a superheterodyne receiver, which stage allows detection to function at a single frequency regardless of the received frequency?

Mixer is correct because it combines the incoming RF with the local oscillator to create a fixed intermediate frequency (IF). Detectors and IF filters can then be optimized for that single IF, no matter what RF you tune. Memory Trick: Mixer makes "many RF channels" into one standard IF.
In a superheterodyne receiver, which stage sets the received frequency?

Local oscillator is correct because changing its frequency changes the difference between LO and RF, and therefore which RF frequency is converted to the IF. The IF filter stays fixed. Memory Trick: You tune the LO, and the LO chooses which station gets mixed to IF.
In a superheterodyne receiver, which stage rejects signals on adjacent channels?

IF filter is correct because most of the selectivity in a superhet comes from sharp, fixed-frequency filters in the IF chain. They pass the wanted channel and greatly attenuate nearby ones. Memory Trick: "Selectivity lives in the IF."
In a superheterodyne receiver, which stage provides the final signal power to drive the detector?

IF amplifier is correct because it boosts the intermediate-frequency signal to the level needed for the detector to work properly. The RF amplifier works earlier in the chain, and the audio (speech) amplifier comes after detection. Memory Trick: RF → mixer → IF amp → detector → audio.
In an FM receiver, what is the purpose of the limiter?
Remove amplitude variations from the received signal
Maintain constant input level to the mixer

Remove amplitude variations from the received signal is correct because FM carries information in frequency, not amplitude. The limiter clips amplitude swings (noise, fading, AM interference) before the discriminator. Memory Trick: FM = frequency matters, so limiter "throws away" amplitude.
In an FM receiver, what is the purpose of the discriminator?
Provide most of the receiver's selectivity
Recover the original modulation from the carrier
Select narrowband or wideband FM reception
Remove amplitude modulation from the received signal

Recover the original modulation from the carrier is correct because the discriminator converts the frequency variations of the FM IF signal into the corresponding audio voltage. It is the FM detector. Memory Trick: Discriminator "decides" which frequency swing equals which audio voltage.
In a receiver, which stage is controlled by the volume control?

AF amplifier is correct because the volume control usually adjusts the gain of the audio-frequency stages, changing how loud the recovered signal sounds in the speaker or headphones. RF and IF gains are normally not used for basic volume control. Memory Trick: Volume knob = audio stage gain.
In an FM receiver, which stage includes a squelch circuit?

AF amplifier is correct because squelch generally mutes or un-mutes the audio path, often by controlling the audio amplifier stage. It keeps the speaker quiet when no usable signal is present. Memory Trick: Squelch = "shut the speaker up" unless a valid signal is heard.
In a basic CW transmitter, the output from the oscillator is:
at the transmitted signal's power level
at a submultiple of the operating frequency
less stable than the transmitted signal

At the transmitted signal's frequency is correct because in a simple CW rig the crystal or VFO oscillator runs directly on the operating frequency, and later stages only amplify it. Multipliers or mixers are not used in the basic design. Memory Trick: In the simplest CW set, "what the oscillator makes is what you transmit."
In a basic CW transmitter, what type of electricity directly powers each stage?

Direct current is correct because each stage is powered by DC from the power supply; RF and audio are signals riding on top of that DC, not the supply itself. Memory Trick: Think "DC feeds the circuits, RF is just the signal they create."
In a basic CW transmitter, why is the oscillator followed by a driver/buffer stage?
To filter out noise from the oscillator
To filter out spurious emissions from the oscillator
To prevent load changes from shifting the oscillator's frequency
To shape the oscillator waveform to prevent key clicks

To prevent load changes from shifting the oscillator's frequency is correct because the buffer or driver isolates the delicate oscillator from the varying load of later stages, keeping the frequency stable. Memory Trick: Buffer = "shock absorber" between oscillator and power stages.
In a basic three-stage CW transmitter, what does the key do?
It switches the oscillator on and off
It controls the amplitude of the carrier

It controls the amplitude of the carrier is correct because the key is usually placed in the keying line so that it turns RF output on and off, effectively controlling when carrier power is present. Other choices describe side effects that are handled by shaping networks, not the key itself. Memory Trick: Press key = RF amplitude present; release key = RF amplitude zero.
In a basic CW transmitter, what does the power amplifier stage do?
It increases the transmitter's output power
It removes CW chirps from the transmitted signal
It multiplies the oscillator frequency to the operating frequency
It reduces distortion in the transmitted signal

It increases the transmitter's output power is correct because the PA takes the small RF signal from the driver or buffer and boosts it to the level needed to feed the antenna. Chirps and spurs are controlled elsewhere. Memory Trick: Power amplifier = "muscle" of the transmitter.
In a basic CW transmitter, what does the key do?
It makes and breaks the antenna connection
It switches the carrier on and off
It switches the carrier between two frequencies
It switches the transmitted tone on and off

It switches the carrier on and off is correct because in CW operation the key makes and breaks the RF path (or keying line), producing the dots and dashes of Morse as short bursts of RF energy. It does not switch between two frequencies. Memory Trick: CW = carrier on for a dot or dash, carrier off for the space.
In an SSB/CW receiver, what is the purpose of the antenna?
Polarize signals received via sky-wave propagation
Convert electromagnetic waves into electrical currents

Convert electromagnetic waves into electrical currents is correct because an antenna acts as a transducer, picking up radio waves and turning them into RF voltages and currents that the receiver can process. It does not "filter out" noise by itself. Memory Trick: Antenna = ear that turns waves in space into signals in a wire.
In an SSB/CW receiver, what is the purpose of the radio frequency (RF) amplifier?
Provide sufficient drive for the automatic gain control circuit (AGC)
Increase the local oscillator signal to drive the mixer
Provide sufficient gain to activate the limiter circuit
Increase the sensitivity of the receiver

Increase the sensitivity of the receiver is correct because the RF amplifier boosts weak signals from the antenna before they reach the mixer, improving the receiver's ability to hear faint stations. The LO and limiter are handled elsewhere. Memory Trick: RF amp = "first magnifying glass" for weak signals.
In an SSB/CW receiver, what is the purpose of the mixer?
Convert the received signal into the intermediate frequency
Convert the beat frequency oscillator signal to audio
Provide USB and LSB signals for sideband selection
Remove the carrier from the received signal

Convert the received signal into the intermediate frequency is correct because the mixer combines RF and local oscillator to produce sum and difference frequencies, with the difference chosen as the IF. Sideband selection happens later in filters or product detectors. Memory Trick: Mixer = "frequency translator" to the IF.
In an SSB/CW receiver, what is the purpose of the signal generated by the local oscillator?
It is mixed with the intermediate frequency signal to produce a CW sidetone
It is mixed with the incoming signal to produce the intermediate frequency
It is mixed with the beat frequency oscillator signal to produce audio
It is fed to the receiver input to provide band edge markers

It is mixed with the incoming signal to produce the intermediate frequency is correct because the LO is the reference frequency used in the mixer to shift the desired RF signal down to the IF. The BFO and sidetone are separate oscillators used later in the chain. Memory Trick: LO + RF → IF; that's the heart of the superhet.
In an SSB/CW receiver, what is the purpose of the intermediate frequency (IF) filter?
Suppress spurious signals from the IF amplifier
Reject RF from the product detector, passing only audio
Provide most of the selectivity of the receiver
For SSB reception, select the desired sideband

Provide most of the selectivity of the receiver is correct because the IF filter is narrow and fixed in frequency, so it chooses which signals pass and which nearby signals are rejected. Memory Trick: Think "channel chooser" — the IF filter defines your receive channel.
In an SSB/CW receiver, what is the purpose of the intermediate frequency (IF) amplifier?
Boost the signal as required for the mixer
Increase the level of the recovered modulation
Provide sufficient gain to activate the limiter circuit
Provide most of the receiver gain

Provide most of the receiver gain is correct because most of the amplification happens at the fixed IF, where filters and stages are easiest to optimize. Memory Trick: RF amp "opens the door," but the IF amp "does the heavy lifting" for gain.
In an SSB/CW receiver, what is the purpose of the product detector?
For SSB reception, reject the unwanted sideband
Convert audio frequency electrical signals into sound
Detect frequency drift to control the local oscillator

Recover the transmitted modulation is correct because the product detector mixes the IF signal with the BFO to recover the original audio (SSB) or tone (CW). Memory Trick: Product detector = "mix IF + BFO = audio."
In an SSB/CW receiver, what is the purpose of the signal produced by the beat frequency oscillator (BFO)?
It is fed to the receiver input to provide band edge markers
It is mixed with the IF to recover the transmitted modulation
It is mixed with the incoming signal to produce the intermediate frequency
It drives the automatic gain control circuit to maintain a constant audio level

It is mixed with the IF to recover the transmitted modulation is correct because the BFO provides a "substitute carrier" to beat against the IF signal in the product detector and create audio or a CW tone. Memory Trick: BFO = "fake carrier" added back inside the receiver.
In an SSB/CW receiver, what is the purpose of the audio frequency (AF) amplifier?
Increase the BFO signal for driving the product detector
Provide audible warning of receiver overload
Increase the level of the recovered modulation
Convert audio frequency electrical signals into sound

Increase the level of the recovered modulation is correct because the AF amplifier boosts the small audio signal from the detector to a level that can drive a speaker or headphones. Memory Trick: Detector finds the audio, AF amp makes it loud enough to hear.
In an SSB/CW receiver, which stage could include an audio band-pass filter?

AF amplifier is correct because narrow audio band-pass filters (for CW or speech shaping) are often placed in or around the audio stages. Memory Trick: IF filters shape the RF channel, audio filters shape how it sounds to your ears.
In a single-sideband transmitter, what does the fixed RF oscillator do?
It directly drives the sideband filter
It balances the variable frequency oscillator

It produces an RF carrier is correct because the fixed RF (carrier) oscillator runs at the filter/IF frequency used to create the SSB signal before it is translated to the operating frequency. Memory Trick: Fixed RF oscillator = steady "carrier reference" inside the transmitter.
In a single-sideband transmitter, why is the speech amplifier needed?
Microphones usually have a low power output
To match the balanced modulator's output impedance
The sideband filter requires a large audio signal to work

Microphones usually have a low power output is correct because the mic signal is very small and must be boosted to a useful audio level for the balanced modulator. Memory Trick: Mic whispers, speech amp "talks louder" into the modulator.
In a typical single-sideband transmitter, what is the purpose of the filter that follows the balanced modulator?
Remove harmonics from the transmitted signal

Remove the unwanted sideband is correct because the balanced modulator produces a double-sideband suppressed-carrier signal, and the filter selects only one sideband. Memory Trick: Balanced modulator makes two sidebands, the filter chooses just one.
In a typical single-sideband transmitter, at what frequency is the sideband filter tuned?
Near the fixed RF oscillator frequency

Near the fixed RF oscillator frequency is correct because the SSB filter works at the "IF" or carrier frequency produced by the fixed RF oscillator, not at the final transmitted RF frequency. Memory Trick: The SSB filter lives in the IF section, not at the VFO or audio.
In a single-sideband transmitter, what is the purpose of the speech amplifier?
Amplify the audio you wish to transmit
Amplify one of the signal's two sidebands

Amplify the audio you wish to transmit is correct because the speech amplifier boosts microphone-level audio to the level needed to drive the balanced modulator. Memory Trick: Speech amp = "voice booster" stage before RF processing.
In a single-sideband transmitter, which stage transposes the single-sideband signal to the operating frequency?

Mixer is correct because it combines the fixed-frequency SSB signal with the VFO signal and moves it to the desired operating frequency. Memory Trick: Mixer = "frequency shifter" that moves the SSB signal up or down the band.
In a single-sideband transmitter, which stage allows you to adjust the final transmit frequency?

Variable frequency oscillator is correct because tuning the VFO changes the frequency that the mixer translates the SSB signal to, which sets the final transmit frequency. Memory Trick: VFO knob = the dial you turn to choose where you transmit.
In a single-sideband transmitter, which stage normally includes a circuit providing protection from excessive SWR?

Final amplifier is correct because high SWR can damage the output stage, so protection and power-foldback circuits are usually built into the PA. Memory Trick: The final is closest to the antenna, so it needs SWR protection.
In a single-sideband transmitter, which stage transposes the voice message from the audio spectrum to the radio spectrum?

Balanced modulator is correct because it combines the audio from the speech amplifier with the RF carrier from the fixed oscillator to produce RF sidebands that "carry" the voice. Memory Trick: Balanced modulator = "audio to RF" converter.
Which of the following is a function of the sound card interface in a station operating computer-based digital modes?
To convert the received analog audio signal from the transceiver into a digital signal for the computer
To convert the received digital signal from the transceiver into an analog signal for the computer
To amplify the digital signals to be sent by the transceiver

To convert the received analog audio signal from the transceiver into a digital signal for the computer is correct because the sound card samples the audio and turns it into bits the software can decode. Memory Trick: Think of the sound card as the "ears" of the computer.
Which of the following is a function of the sound card interface in a station operating computer-based digital modes?
To amplify the digital signals to be sent by the transceiver
To convert the digital signal from the computer into an audio signal that can be transmitted
To convert the analog signal from the computer into a digital signal that can be transmitted

To convert the digital signal from the computer into an audio signal that can be transmitted is correct because the sound card takes the software-generated digital data and outputs audio tones for the radio. Memory Trick: Computer "thinks in bits," radio "talks in tones" — the sound card connects the two.
Which of the following is one function of most sound card interfaces in a station operating computer-based digital modes?
Translate the digital signal into alphanumeric characters
Switch the transceiver between receive and transmit modes

Switch the transceiver between receive and transmit modes is correct because most interfaces also provide a keying or control line (such as PTT) to toggle the radio between RX and TX. Memory Trick: Interface = audio plus "push-to-talk" control.
Which of the following is a function of the sound card interface in a station operating computer-based digital modes?
To provide audio frequency coupling between a computer and a transceiver
To provide radio frequency coupling between a computer and a transceiver
To amplify the digital signals to be sent by the transceiver

To provide audio frequency coupling between a computer and a transceiver is correct because the interface passes audio both ways (to and from the radio) at low frequencies. Memory Trick: Think of the interface as an "audio bridge" between rig and PC.
Why are isolation transformers often included in the sound card interface of a station operating computer-based digital modes?
To provide a source of DC power for the circuitry in the interface
To prevent the coupling of the transceiver and computer from introducing hum and interference into the transmitted signals
To increase the signal voltage generated by the computer to the level required by the transceiver
To match the impedance of the computer output signal to the impedance of the input of the computer

To prevent the coupling of the transceiver and computer from introducing hum and interference into the transmitted signals is correct because isolation transformers break ground loops and reduce noise. Memory Trick: Transformers "pass the audio, block the hum."
Why are some transceivers capable of operating computer-based digital modes without a separate sound card?
Because digital signal processing (DSP) is built-in
Because they support CAT (Computer Aided Transceiver)
Because they incorporate an audio codec
Because they provide a USB connector

Because they incorporate an audio codec is correct because the radio already performs the same audio A/D and D/A conversion that a separate sound card interface would provide, often via a built-in USB audio device. Memory Trick: Think "radio with its own sound card" — built-in codec means no extra box.
If a linear power supply provides overvoltage protection, where is the voltage monitored?
At the output of the filter
At the input of the rectifier
At the input of the transformer
At the output of the regulator

At the output of the regulator is correct because overvoltage protection must watch the final DC output that actually feeds the equipment and shut down if it rises too high. Memory Trick: Protect what you power — measure at the regulated output.
What is the purpose of the transformer in a linear power supply?
Convert the AC mains voltage up or down as required and provide isolation
Convert alternating current into direct current
Smooth out the pulsating direct current
Ensure that the voltage stays constant when a heavy demand is placed on the supply

Convert the AC mains voltage up or down as required and provide isolation is correct because the transformer sets a safe working voltage and isolates the supply from the mains. Memory Trick: Transformer = "voltage changer and safety wall" between you and the outlet.
What is the purpose of the rectifier in a linear power supply?
Convert alternating current into direct current
Ensure that the voltage stays constant when a heavy demand is placed on the supply
Convert the AC mains voltage up or down as required and provide isolation

Convert alternating current into direct current is correct because the rectifier (diodes or bridge) lets current flow in only one direction to create a pulsating DC waveform from AC. Memory Trick: Rectifier = "AC to DC one-way valve."
What is the purpose of the filter in a linear power supply?
Ensure that the voltage stays constant when a heavy demand is placed on the supply
Absorb the power produced by the supply
Convert alternating current into direct current

Smooth out pulsating direct current is correct because capacitors and sometimes inductors in the filter reduce ripple, turning bumpy DC into smoother DC. Memory Trick: Filter caps act like a reservoir that "fills the dips" in the rectified waveform.
What is the purpose of the regulator in a linear power supply?
Convert the AC mains voltage up or down as required and provides isolation
Convert alternating current into direct current
Absorb the power produced by the supply
Ensure that the voltage stays constant when the demand on the supply varies

Ensure that the voltage stays constant when the demand on the supply varies is correct because the regulator adjusts its internal resistance or pass element to keep the output voltage steady. Memory Trick: Regulator = "automatic volume knob" for voltage.
In a linear power supply, which stage typically requires a heat sink?

Voltage regulator is correct because it often drops significant voltage at substantial current and must dissipate that power as heat, so it needs a heat sink. Memory Trick: The part that "burns off extra volts" gets hottest.
Which component of a 3-element Yagi antenna is primarily for mechanical support?
The boom is correct because it is the non-radiating support that holds all the elements in place and sets their spacing. Memory Trick: Elements "talk," the boom just "holds the team together."
In a 3-element Yagi antenna, what is the longest radiating element?

The reflector is correct because in a typical Yagi the reflector is slightly longer than the driven element and the director is slightly shorter. Memory Trick: Reflector = "big umbrella" behind the driven element.
In a 3-element Yagi antenna, which is the shortest radiating element?
The director is correct because in a typical Yagi the director element is cut a bit shorter to pull the main lobe forward. Memory Trick: Director = "small arrow" pointing the beam direction.
In a 3-element Yagi antenna, which element is connected to the transmission line?
The driven element is correct because it is the only element actually fed by the transmitter; the reflector and director are parasitic elements. Memory Trick: "Driven" = "wired to the feedline."
Which series of emission modes listed below is in order from the narrowest bandwidth to the widest bandwidth?
SSB voice, CW and FM voice
CW, SSB voice and FM voice
CW, FM voice and SSB voice
FM voice, SSB voice and CW

CW, SSB voice and FM voice is correct because CW is very narrow, SSB voice is a few kilohertz wide, and FM voice on VHF/UHF uses the widest bandwidth of the three. Memory Trick: Think "beep, voice, fat FM" as bandwidth grows.
The figure in a receiver's specifications which indicates its sensitivity is the:
bandwidth of the IF in kilohertz
RF input signal needed to achieve a given signal-to-noise ratio

RF input signal needed to achieve a given signal-to-noise ratio is correct because sensitivity is defined by how weak a signal the receiver can still copy with acceptable SNR. Memory Trick: Sensitivity = "how little signal it needs to hear you."
What are the two signal parameters presented to the user on the waterfall display (spectrogram) of a modern receiver?

Amplitude and frequency is correct because a waterfall shows frequency along one axis and signal strength (amplitude) as changing colour or brightness over time. Memory Trick: Waterfall = "how strong at what frequency" as time scrolls by.
What is the function of automatic gain control (AGC) in a receiver?
Limit the change in volume due to large signal strength variations
Improve the signal-to-distortion ratio of the detector
Maximize overall gain for greater sensitivity

Limit the change in volume due to large signal strength variations is correct because AGC reduces gain for strong signals and increases it for weak ones, keeping audio more constant. Memory Trick: AGC = "automatic volume leveling" for RF.
For which of the following emission modes is it important for the receiver to be tuned accurately (within 100 Hz)?

SSB is correct because tuning even slightly off frequency makes SSB audio sound distorted or "off-pitch," so you must be much closer than with AM or FM. Memory Trick: SSB is picky — a small knob twist makes big voice changes.

A superheterodyne receiver has an intermediate frequency (IF) of 455 kHz. The local oscillator runs above the operating frequency. To which frequency should it be tuned to receive a signal on 3.54 MHz?
3.995 MHz is correct because the local oscillator frequency equals the signal frequency plus the IF: 3.54 MHz + 0.455 MHz = 3.995 MHz. Memory Trick: For a high-side LO, think "LO = signal + IF."
When receiving a modulated signal, what is the adverse consequence of too narrow a receiver bandwidth?

Loss of information is correct because a bandwidth narrower than the signal chops off parts of the modulation, making speech or data distorted or unreadable. Memory Trick: "Filter too tight, words don't sound right."
Apart from sensitivity and selectivity, which of these is the third main indicator of communications receiver performance?

Dynamic range is correct because it describes how well the receiver handles both very weak and very strong signals at the same time without overload or desensitization. Memory Trick: Dynamic range = "from whispers to shouts without breaking a sweat."
A communications receiver has four filters installed in it, respectively designated as 250 Hz, 500 Hz, 2.4 kHz, and 6 kHz. If you were listening to single sideband, which filter would you utilize?

2.4 kHz is correct because SSB voice typically needs about 2 to 3 kHz of bandwidth, while 250 Hz and 500 Hz are CW/data widths and 6 kHz is more suitable for AM. Memory Trick: "SSB voice likes about 2.4 kHz of space."

A communications receiver has four filters installed in it, respectively designated as 250 Hz, 500 Hz, 2.4 kHz and 6 kHz. You are copying a CW transmission and there is a great deal of interference. Which one of the filters would you choose?

250 Hz is correct because CW is a very narrow signal and the narrowest filter will cut out the most adjacent interference while still passing your CW tone. Memory Trick: For CW in heavy QRM, think "go narrow or go nowhere" — choose the smallest bandwidth.
When receiving CW, which of these frequency ranges is optimum for a band-pass filter?

750 Hz to 850 Hz is correct because most operators prefer a CW tone around 700–800 Hz; a narrow band-pass centered there gives a pleasant tone and good rejection of nearby signals. Memory Trick: Aim for a "musical" CW tone around 800 Hz and filter tightly around it.
A small change in the output frequency of a transmitter each time a dit or dah is sent
A high-pitched tone which is received along with every CW dit and dah
A slow change in transmitter frequency as the oscillator warms up
An overload in a receiver's audio circuit whenever CW is received

A small change in the output frequency of a transmitter each time a dit or dah is sent is correct because chirp is that sliding or warbling of frequency at each keying, heard as a "cheep" instead of a pure tone. Memory Trick: Think of a bird "chirping" up or down in pitch with every element.
What can be done to keep a CW transmitter from chirping?
Keep the power supply voltages very steady under varying loads
Keep the oscillator impedance very steady under the transmit load

Keep the power supply voltages very steady under varying loads is correct because voltage sag or variation when you key causes the oscillator frequency to shift, producing chirp. Memory Trick: Stable volts, stable notes — good regulation keeps the tone clean.
What is the advantage of using a variable frequency oscillator in a basic CW transmitter?
Frequency is not constrained to the available crystals
Use of higher speed Morse code is supported

Frequency is not constrained to the available crystals is correct because a VFO lets you tune anywhere in the band instead of being stuck on fixed crystal frequencies. Memory Trick: VFO = "Vary Frequency Often" — you are no longer crystal-bound.
Which type of transmitter modulation changes the amplitude of an RF wave for the purpose of conveying information?
Amplitude modulation is correct because AM varies the height (amplitude) of the RF envelope in step with the audio signal. Memory Trick: AM = "Amplitude Moves" up and down with your voice.
In what emission mode does the instantaneous amplitude (envelope) of the RF signal vary with the modulating audio?
Amplitude modulation is correct because the RF envelope gets stronger and weaker as the audio waveform changes. Memory Trick: Picture the RF "mountain tops" growing and shrinking to match the sound.
Morse code is usually transmitted by radio as:
an interrupted carrier is correct because CW keying simply turns the carrier on and off to form dots and dashes. Memory Trick: CW = "carrier on, carrier off" like a flashlight blinking in RF.
You are transmitting using amplitude modulation. What bandwidth does your signal occupy if the highest frequency of your voice is 3 kHz?

6 kHz is correct because AM generates two sidebands, one above and one below the carrier, each extending to the highest audio frequency: total RF bandwidth = 2 × 3 kHz. Memory Trick: For AM, think "two for one" — double the highest audio frequency.
What frequency components are present in the bandwidth of an amplitude modulated signal?

Carrier and two sidebands is correct because conventional AM produces an upper sideband, a lower sideband, and the unmodulated carrier in the middle. Memory Trick: Classic AM = "carrier plus twins" above and below.
An RF oscillator should be electrically and mechanically stable. This is to ensure that the oscillator does NOT:

drift in frequency over time is correct because instability causes the signal to wander in frequency, making reception difficult and annoying other operators. Memory Trick: A "wobbly" oscillator makes a "wandering" signal — stability prevents drift.
The DC power to the final stage of your transmitter is 200 watts and the RF output is 125 watts. What has happened to the rest of the power?
It has been used to provide positive feedback
It has been dissipated as heat
It has been used to provide greater efficiency
It has been used to provide negative feedback
It has been dissipated as heat is correct because the difference between DC in and RF out is lost as heat in the active devices and circuitry. Memory Trick: Power in = RF out + warm components.
The difference between DC input power and RF output power of a transmitter RF amplifier:
is lost in the transmission line

appears as heat is correct because no amplifier is 100% efficient; the unused power ends up warming the transistors, tubes, and surrounding hardware. Memory Trick: "Missing" watts went into the heat sink.
What may happen if an SSB transmitter is operated with the microphone gain set too high?
It may cause harmonic interference on higher bands
It may cause interference to other stations operating on lower bands
It may cause digital interference to computer equipment
It may interfere with other stations operating near its frequency

It may interfere with other stations operating near its frequency is correct because excessive mic gain overdrives the stages and creates splatter, spreading your signal wider than normal. Memory Trick: "Mic gain too hot" makes your signal "spatter the lot."
What may happen if an SSB transmitter is operated with too much speech processing?
It may cause audio distortion or splatter interference to other stations operating near its frequency
It may cause digital interference to computer equipment
It may cause insufficient modulation of the carrier
It may cause interference to other stations operating on a higher frequency band

It may cause audio distortion or splatter interference to other stations operating near its frequency is correct because overdone processing flattens peaks, adds distortion, and widens your occupied bandwidth. Memory Trick: "Cranked" processor = "crunched" audio and splatter.
What is the term for the average power during one RF cycle, at the crest of the modulation envelope?
Peak envelope power is correct because PEP refers to the RF power averaged over one RF cycle at the highest point of the modulation envelope. Memory Trick: Think PEP = "Power at the Envelope Peak."
What is the usual bandwidth of an amateur radio single-sideband signal?

Between 2 kHz and 3 kHz is correct because typical SSB voice signals use about 2.4–2.8 kHz of bandwidth for intelligible audio without wasting spectrum. Memory Trick: Remember SSB voice as "about 2 and a bit kHz" wide.
Why does the power amplifier of the SSB transmitter need to be linear?
Power demand on the power supply is regulated
Power output variations due to voice peaks are reduced
Voice is unintelligible when amplified by a non-linear amplifier

Voice is unintelligible when amplified by a non-linear amplifier is correct because non-linearity distorts the complex SSB waveform, creating splatter and making speech hard to understand. Memory Trick: SSB "shape" must be preserved, so the amplifier must be linear.
What is one advantage of carrier suppression in a double sideband voice transmission?
More of the output power can be put into the sidebands
Only half the bandwidth is needed for the same information content
Greater modulation percentage is obtainable with lower distortion
Simpler equipment can be used to receive a double sideband suppressed carrier signal

More of the output power can be put into the sidebands is correct because the carrier carries no information; by suppressing it, more of your transmitter power goes into the sidebands that actually convey the audio. Memory Trick: "Kill the carrier, feed the sidebands."
What does overmodulation do to a single-sideband signal?
It has higher fidelity and an improved signal-to-noise ratio
It becomes distorted and occupies more bandwidth
It increases the range of your signal
It occupies less bandwidth and has a poor high frequency response

It becomes distorted and occupies more bandwidth is correct because driving an SSB transmitter too hard creates splatter and extra unwanted side components, spreading into adjacent channels. Memory Trick: Overmodulate and your signal "bulges" into your neighbors.
How should the microphone gain control be adjusted for voice operation on a single-sideband transmitter?
For 100% frequency deviation on voice peaks
For a dip in the drain or collector current
Such that the maximum range on the ALC meter is never exceeded on voice peaks
For full deflection of the ALC meter

Such that the maximum range on the ALC meter is never exceeded on voice peaks is correct because ALC protects the transmitter from overdrive and distortion. You want the ALC to just move on peaks, but not slam to the end of the scale. Memory Trick: Think of ALC as a ceiling — touch it on voice peaks, never punch through it.
The purpose of a balanced modulator in an SSB transmitter is to:
make sure that the carrier and both sidebands are 180 degrees out of phase
ensure that the percentage of modulation is kept constant
suppress the carrier and pass one sideband
suppress the carrier and pass the two sidebands

suppress the carrier and pass the two sidebands is correct because a balanced modulator cancels the carrier, leaving only the upper and lower sidebands. A later filter removes one of those sidebands to create SSB. Memory Trick: Balanced modulator = "balanced out" carrier, sidebands remain.
Your SSB transmitter is set to operate lower sideband at 7100 kHz. With a single 1000 Hz tone as modulation, at which frequency is RF transmitted?

7099 kHz is correct because lower sideband components appear below the carrier by the audio frequency. A 1 kHz tone on LSB at 7100 kHz produces RF 1 kHz lower, at 7099 kHz. Memory Trick: LSB = "Lower than carrier by audio."
The automatic level control (ALC) in an SSB transmitter:
limits the input audio peaks so that the transmitter is not overdriven

limits the input audio peaks so that the transmitter is not overdriven is correct because ALC samples the RF output and reduces gain when peaks get too high, preventing distortion and splatter. Memory Trick: ALC = "Automatic Level Control" — it automatically pulls back the reins on your signal.
What causes the loud noise heard from an FM receiver in the absence of a signal?
The nature of atmospheric noise in the VHF range
The higher intermediate frequency used in FM receivers
The very large gain of stages ahead of the discriminator
The additional gain following the discriminator

The very large gain of stages ahead of the discriminator is correct because wideband IF stages with lots of gain amplify internal and external noise when no carrier is present, producing loud hiss. Memory Trick: No signal + big gain = big hiss.
You are using an FM repeater configured for 5 kHz deviation, but your transmitter is set to 2.5 kHz deviation. What is the consequence?

Your audio will be low is correct because with only half the expected deviation, the receiver slices out a narrower portion of frequency swing, so your voice sounds quiet and thin. Memory Trick: Too little deviation = "whisper" audio.
What term defines the change in frequency caused by modulation in an FM transmitter?

Deviation is correct because it is the name for how far the FM carrier moves above and below its center frequency with modulation. Memory Trick: FM "deviates" from the center — that change is the deviation.
What kind of emission would your FM transmitter produce if its microphone failed to work?
An unmodulated carrier is correct because without audio, the FM modulator does not vary the frequency, so the transmitter simply emits a steady carrier. Memory Trick: No audio in = no deviation out.
Why is FM voice best for local VHF/UHF radio communications?
It is more resistant to distortion caused by reflected signals
Its RF carrier stays on frequency better than the AM modes
It provides a good signal-to-noise ratio at low RF signal levels

It provides a good signal-to-noise ratio at low RF signal levels is correct because FM has a noise threshold and capture effect that keep audio clean until the signal drops very low. Memory Trick: For local work, FM often sounds "clean or gone," which is great for readability.
What is the approximate bandwidth of a frequency modulated signal using 5 kHz deviation?

Between 10 kHz and 20 kHz is correct because, by Carson's rule, FM bandwidth is roughly twice the deviation plus a bit for the highest audio frequency, which for typical narrowband FM falls in that 10–20 kHz range. Memory Trick: 5 kHz deviation → think "roughly double and then some."
How is a higher level of the modulating signal represented in an FM signal?
By a larger deviation of the carrier frequency
By a larger amplitude of the carrier
By a larger pulse width in the transmitted wave train
By a larger peak envelope power

By a larger deviation of the carrier frequency is correct because, in FM, louder audio does not change the amplitude, it changes how far the carrier swings in frequency. Memory Trick: FM = Frequency Moves; louder voice = bigger moves.
What modulation method is most closely related to frequency modulation?

Phase modulation is correct because FM and PM are mathematically related; each can be generated from the other with appropriate pre-emphasis of the audio. Memory Trick: Think of FM and PM as "cousins" in the angle modulation family.
Why is't FM used as an amateur radio emission mode below 28 MHz?
Harmonics could not be attenuated to practical levels
The frequency stability would not be adequate
The bandwidth would exceed limits in the regulations
The transmitter efficiency for this mode is low

The bandwidth would exceed limits in the regulations is correct because FM with several kilohertz of deviation needs much more bandwidth than narrow HF allocations allow. Memory Trick: Big FM swing + narrow HF bands = not compatible by rule.
Several stations report that your FM transmission is loud and distorted, but on frequency. Which of the following is the most probable cause of the distortion?
Speaking too loudly into the microphone

Speaking too loudly into the microphone is correct because overdriving the mic input causes excessive deviation and audio distortion, even though the RF carrier is exactly on frequency. Memory Trick: If others say "too loud and crunchy," first suspect your mic level.
When more than one signal is present, the FM receiver is likely to demodulate only the strongest signal. What is this behaviour called?

Capture effect is correct because an FM receiver tends to "capture" the stronger of two signals on nearly the same frequency and suppress the weaker one. Memory Trick: Strongest signal "captures" the receiver.
What do many amateur radio operators use to help form good Morse code characters?
