Electronic keyer is correct because a keyer automatically times dits and dahs and provides consistent spacing, helping the operator send clean, readable code. Memory Trick: Let the keyer handle the timing so you can focus on the message.
How does an electronic keyer help form good Morse code characters?
By improving the tone of the CW signal
By ensuring that the dots and dashes have the same amplitude
By regulating the lengths of the dits and dahs

By regulating the lengths of the dits and dahs is correct because the keyer generates elements of fixed, proper duration based on the speed setting. Memory Trick: You tap once, the keyer "draws" a perfect dit or dah for you.
What do you need to adjust before using a microphone for the first time with a transceiver?

Microphone gain level is correct because each microphone and voice is different, so you must set mic gain so that ALC and modulation are correct without distortion. Memory Trick: New mic, new voice — always set the gain first.
What noise management system analyzes noise and signal characteristics to partially remove noise?

DSP noise reduction is correct because digital signal processing can distinguish noise from desired audio and reduce the noise component while leaving speech more intact. Memory Trick: Think of DSP as "smart filtering" that learns what to turn down.
What circuit causes a transmitter to automatically transmit when an operator speaks into its microphone?

VOX is correct because VOX (Voice Operated Transmit) senses your voice audio and keys the transmitter automatically. The other circuits are oscillators used for frequency control, not for voice-operated keying. Memory Trick: VOX = "Voice Operated Xmit" — voice makes it transmit.
What is the reason for using a properly adjusted speech processor with a single-sideband voice transmitter?
It reduces unwanted noise pickup from the microphone
It improves the intelligibility of your signal
It reduces average transmitter power requirements

It improves the intelligibility of your signal is correct because a speech processor compresses the audio peaks, raising average talk power so your signal punches through noise and QSB better. The other options either misunderstand what a processor does or describe side effects, not the main benefit. Memory Trick: Think "processor = punch" — clearer copy at the other end.
If a single-sideband voice transmitter is 100% modulated, how will using a speech processor affect the transmitter's output?

Increase the average power is correct because compression squeezes loud peaks and lifts the softer parts, so the peaks stay about the same while the average power goes up. Memory Trick: Speech processor "fills in the valleys" — average climbs while peaks stay put.
In a receiver, what noise management circuit recognizes high-amplitude short-duration pulses and removes them?

Noise blanker is correct because a blanker detects sharp pulse noise (like ignition clicks) and briefly mutes or clips the signal during each pulse. The other circuits reduce overall level or bandwidth, but do not specifically target pulses. Memory Trick: Blanker = "blank out the bangs."
What type of interference is a noise blanker circuit most effective in eliminating?
Interfering signals on the same frequency

Short-duration impulse-type noise is correct because blankers are designed for things like spark plug or power-line crackle. They do not cure steady hiss, other stations on-frequency, or distortion. Memory Trick: Think "pop" or "click" noise — that's the blanker's job.
What is the function of transmit/receive switching in a transceiver?
To prevent RF currents entering the transmitter circuits
To allow more than one transmitter to be used
To enable one antenna to be used for both transmitting and receiving
To change antennas for operation on other frequencies

To enable one antenna to be used for both transmitting and receiving is correct because the T/R switch quickly connects the antenna to the transmitter when you key up, and back to the receiver when you unkey. Memory Trick: One antenna, two jobs — T/R does the switching.
What type of microphone has internal components similar to a loudspeaker?

Dynamic is correct because a dynamic mic uses a moving coil in a magnetic field, just like a loudspeaker in reverse. The others use crystals or capacitors instead of a voice-coil. Memory Trick: Speaker and dynamic mic are "mirror images" of each other.
Why can a modern digital radio system transmit voice and images, not just data?
Any analog information can be converted to digital data
Digital protocols can fall back to analog as needed
Digital signals are continuously variable signals
Modern transceivers have the necessary high efficiency amplifiers

Any analog information can be converted to digital data is correct because sound, pictures, and sensor readings can all be sampled and encoded as numbers. Once it is bits, the radio only sees digital data. Memory Trick: If it can be sampled, it can be sent as digital.
What is the fundamental difference between digital and analog data?
Digital data requires complex waveforms for transmission
Digital data is encoded as discrete pre-agreed values
Digital data represents information as a continuously variable quantity
Digital data easily translates into digital signals

Digital data is encoded as discrete pre-agreed values is correct because digital uses specific symbols (like 0 and 1), while analog can smoothly vary over a range. Memory Trick: Analog = "any value"; digital = "pick from the list."
What is the function of a digipeater?
To receive analog FM, convert to digital data and retransmit
To receive digital data, convert to analog FM and retransmit
To receive digital data and retransmit data marked for retransmission
To receive digital data and export to the internet

To receive digital data and retransmit data marked for retransmission is correct because a digipeater repeats only packets addressed or "via" that station, extending range of those specific frames. Memory Trick: Digi + repeater = "digital repeater" for selected packets.
What does "network" mean in packet radio?
A way of connecting terminal-node controllers by telephone so data can be sent over long distances
The programming in a terminal-node controller that rejects other callers if a station is already connected
A way of connecting packet-radio stations so data can be sent over long distances

A way of connecting packet-radio stations so data can be sent over long distances is correct because multiple nodes and digipeaters link together to forward traffic beyond direct range. Memory Trick: Think "many packet nodes linked" when you hear network.
Why can dozens of FT8 communications occur simultaneously in the space needed for one single-sideband transmission?
Narrow bandwidth of an FT8 signal
Formatting of the messages into packets
Message structure with limited contact information

Narrow bandwidth of an FT8 signal is correct because each FT8 signal is only a few tens of hertz wide, so many can fit side by side in a 2.5 to 3 kHz SSB passband. Memory Trick: FT8 = "tiny slices" of spectrum.
Which of these modes can work at the lowest signal-to-noise ratio as measured in a 2500 Hz bandwidth?

FT8 is correct because it is designed to decode signals many dB below the noise floor, lower than typical PSK31, RTTY or casual CW operation. Memory Trick: When signals are "down in the mud," think FT8.
When selecting an RTTY transmitting frequency, what minimum frequency separation from a contact in progress should you allow (centre to centre) to minimize interference?

250 Hz to 500 Hz is correct because RTTY signals are a few hundred hertz wide, so this spacing keeps your signal from overlapping a nearby QSO. Memory Trick: For narrow digital modes, think "a few hundred hertz apart" to play nice.
When using a digital mode based on a computer sound card, how can you verify that the transmit audio level is NOT excessive?
Ensure your transmitter's audio compression is set to maximum
Verify that the automatic level control (ALC) is actively limiting every transmission
Ask a local station to confirm your signal can be successfully decoded
Ask a local station to confirm your signal is free of splatter

Ask a local station to confirm your signal is free of splatter is correct because overdriving the audio makes your signal wide and messy, which another station will clearly hear, even if decoding still works. Memory Trick: "How do I sound?" reports are the best overdrive detector.
What feature of packet radio makes it especially useful for emergency communications?
Reliable messaging (guaranteed delivery or notification of failure)
Packet functionality is included in most modern radios
Capable of simultaneous voice, image and data transmission

Reliable messaging (guaranteed delivery or notification of failure) is correct because packet protocols use acknowledgements and retries so you know whether a message arrived intact. Memory Trick: Packet = "did it get there? yes or no" — very valuable in emergencies.
A digital protocol implements automatic repeat request (ARQ). What does it permit?

Error correction is correct because ARQ asks the sender to retransmit when errors are detected, effectively correcting the data by replacing bad packets with good ones. Memory Trick: ARQ = "Ask to Repeat Quickly" when bits get scrambled.
With a digital communication mode based on a computer sound card, what is the result of feeding excessive audio into the transmitter?

Splatter or out-of-channel emissions is correct because overdriving the audio chain overmodulates the signal, creating distortion products that spread into adjacent frequencies. Memory Trick: Too much audio = "paint outside the lines" in the band.
What approximate voltage does a standard automobile starter battery usually supply?

12 volts is correct because typical car "12 V" systems run from about 12.0 V at rest to around 14 V while charging, but are nominally rated as 12 V. Memory Trick: Think of all "12 volt" mobile rigs — they are designed to run from a car battery.
Which of the following has a positive terminal and a negative terminal?

A battery is correct because it has clearly marked positive and negative terminals that define the direction of conventional current flow. The other components are not polarized in that way for basic DC use. Memory Trick: Think of a battery as having a "plus" and "minus" sign like on a math line.
A battery, that can be repeatedly recharged by supplying it with electrical energy, is known as a:

Storage battery is correct because it refers to a rechargeable secondary cell, unlike a primary battery which is meant to be used once and discarded. Memory Trick: "Store and restore" — a storage battery can be restored (recharged).
Which of the following is a source of electromotive force (EMF)?

Lithium-ion battery is correct because a battery is an active source of EMF, able to supply voltage and current. The other devices are passive or controlled components that require an external source. Memory Trick: If it can power a circuit by itself, it is a source of EMF.
Why is the NiMH battery often preferred over a conventional alkaline battery?
It can be discarded without precautions

It can be repeatedly recharged is correct because NiMH cells are rechargeable secondary cells, whereas alkaline cells are generally single-use. Memory Trick: "NiMH" — think "New charge, Many Hours" to remember it is rechargeable.
The voltage at a battery's terminals will drop when it supplies current. What is the cause of the drop?

Internal resistance is correct because the battery behaves like an ideal voltage source in series with a small internal resistor, so Vdrop = I × Rinternal when current flows. Memory Trick: More current means more "sag" because of that hidden resistor inside.
For portable operation, what is the primary advantage of lithium-based batteries over lead-acid batteries?

High battery capacity per kilogram is correct because lithium-based batteries have much higher energy density than lead-acid batteries, making them lighter for the same capacity. Memory Trick: Think "lithium = light" for light weight and high capacity.
Battery capacity is commonly stated as a value of current delivered over a specified period of time. What is the effect of exceeding that specified current?
The battery will accept the subsequent charge in a shorter time
The voltage delivered will be higher
The battery will discharge more rapidly than specified
One or more cells may become short-circuited

The battery will discharge more rapidly than specified is correct because drawing more current than the rated value empties the stored charge in less time and can reduce the effective capacity. Memory Trick: Think of current like "drinking faster from the tank" — it empties sooner.
What voltage and capacity will you achieve by connecting two 12 volts, 20 ampere-hour batteries in parallel?

12 volts, 40 ampere-hours is correct because parallel connection keeps the voltage the same and adds the capacities: Vsame, Ahsum. So 12 V stays 12 V, and 20 Ah + 20 Ah = 40 Ah. Memory Trick: Parallel = "side by side tanks" with the same height (voltage) but more volume (Ah).
What voltage and capacity will you achieve by connecting two 12 volts, 20 ampere-hour batteries in series?

24 volts, 20 ampere-hours is correct because series connection adds voltage but keeps capacity the same: Vsum, Ahsame. So 12 V + 12 V = 24 V, capacity remains 20 Ah. Memory Trick: Series = "stacked batteries" — taller stack (voltage), same tank size (Ah).
A lithium-ion battery should never be:

Short-circuited is correct because a short can cause very high current, overheating, venting, or fire in lithium-ion packs. The other conditions are normal or even required for safe operation. Memory Trick: Li-ion + short = "very bad day" — always avoid shorts.
You construct a simple DC power supply using a transformer, rectifier and filter capacitor. If you use the supply to power a CW transmitter, what problem with signal quality could it cause?

Chirp is correct because a poorly regulated supply lets the voltage change each time you key the transmitter, slightly shifting the oscillator frequency and causing a "chirp" at the start of each element. Memory Trick: Think "voltage wobble = frequency wobble = chirp."
What device converts 120 volts AC to 12 volts DC?

Power supply is correct because a DC power supply (often called a "12 V supply") rectifies and regulates mains AC into low-voltage DC. An inverter does the opposite, creating AC from DC. Memory Trick: "Supply" supplies DC to your rig.
When selecting a 13.8 V DC power supply for a transceiver, what design specification is most important?

Output current capability is correct because the supply must safely deliver the maximum current your transceiver needs on transmit without sagging or overheating. Memory Trick: First ask "Can it deliver enough amps?" — then worry about extras.
Compared to a switching (switch mode) power supply, why may a linear power supply be preferred?
Lower risk of radio frequency noise

Lower risk of radio frequency noise is correct because linear supplies operate at mains frequency and are much less likely to radiate switching hash into HF and VHF bands than switch-mode supplies. Memory Trick: "Linear = quieter" on the air.
In a mobile installation, why should the fuse in the DC line to the transceiver be located as near to the battery as possible?
To prevent the vehicle's electronic systems causing noise
To reduce the voltage drop in the radio's DC supply

To protect the entire circuit is correct because placing the fuse close to the battery ensures that any short anywhere along the cable will blow the fuse before the wire overheats. Memory Trick: Fuse at the source so the whole run is protected.
Apart from efficiency, what is one advantage of a switching (switch mode) power supply over a linear power supply?
Lower risk of radio frequency noise

Reduced physical dimensions and weight is correct because switching supplies use high-frequency transformers, which can be much smaller and lighter than the large iron cores used in linear supplies. Memory Trick: "Switchers are slim" compared to heavy linears.
Why are heavy-gauge wires used for a 100-watt transceiver's DC power connection?

To minimize the voltage drop is correct because thick wire has lower resistance, so Vdrop = I × R is smaller at the high currents drawn by a 100 W rig. Memory Trick: More amps = fatter wire to keep the volts up at the radio.
What are the nominal power-line voltages supplied to homes?

120 volts and 240 volts is correct because typical North American residential service provides 120 V for standard outlets and 240 V for large appliances. Memory Trick: Think of common labels: "120 V outlet" and "240 V dryer/stove".

Your transceiver's user guide suggests limiting the voltage drop to 0.5 volts and the vehicle battery is 3 metres away. Given the losses listed below at the required current of 22 amperes, which minimum wire gauge must you use?

Number 10, 0.07 V per metre is correct because the round-trip length is 6 metres (there and back). The voltage drop would be 6 × 0.07 = 0.42 V, within the 0.5 V limit. Number 12 and 14 would drop too much, and number 8, while acceptable, is larger than necessary. Memory Trick: Remember to count "there and back" (double the distance) when calculating voltage drop.
Why must the positive lead from the vehicle battery to your transceiver be fused?
To prevent interference to the vehicle's electronic systems
To reduce the voltage drop in the radio's DC supply
To protect the radio from transient voltages
To prevent an overcurrent situation from starting a fire

To prevent an overcurrent situation from starting a fire is correct because if the cable shorts, the car battery can supply very high current; the fuse opens the circuit before the wire or components overheat. Memory Trick: Think of the fuse as a "burn before the car does" safety link.
You have a very loud low-frequency hum appearing on your transmission. In what part of the transmitter would you first look for the trouble?

The power supply is correct because low-frequency hum is usually caused by poor filtering or a fault in the power supply (often 50/60 Hz and its harmonics). The other stages generally do not create this kind of steady low-frequency hum on their own. Memory Trick: Hear a deep "mains" hum? Think "check the supply first."
How could you best keep unauthorized persons from using your station at home?
Put fuses in the main power line
Use a key-operated on/off switch in the main power line
Use a carrier-operated relay in the main power line
Put a "Danger - High Voltage" sign in the station

Use a key-operated on/off switch in the main power line is correct because it physically prevents the station from being powered up without the key. Signs and fuses do not actually stop someone from trying to operate the station. Memory Trick: If it needs a key, only you can "unlock" the rig.
How could you best keep unauthorized persons from using a mobile station in your car?
Turn the radio off when you are not using it
Put a "Do not touch" sign on the radio
Remove the microphone when you are not using it
Tune the radio to an unused frequency when you are done using it

Remove the microphone when you are not using it is correct because, without the microphone, most people cannot easily transmit. Simply turning the radio off or changing frequency is easy for someone to undo. Memory Trick: No mic = no talk.
What electrical hazard, if any, does the starter battery in a vehicle present?

High short-circuit current is correct because a vehicle starter battery can deliver very large currents, enough to melt metal and start fires if shorted, even though the voltage is low. Memory Trick: Car batteries may be "only 12 V" but they are "hundreds of amps" dangerous.
Why would there be a switch in a high-voltage power supply to turn off the power if its cabinet is opened?
To keep anyone opening the cabinet from getting shocked by dangerous high voltages
To keep dangerous RF radiation from leaking out through an open cabinet
To keep dangerous RF radiation from coming in through an open cabinet
To turn the power supply off when it is not being used

To keep anyone opening the cabinet from getting shocked by dangerous high voltages is correct because an interlock switch removes power before hands can reach live parts. Memory Trick: "Cabinet open = power broken" for safety.
What is the minimum electrical current that can be fatal to the human body?

20 milliamperes is correct because currents in this range passing through the heart can cause fibrillation and be fatal. Much lower currents are usually just a shock; much higher values are clearly dangerous but 20 mA is around the threshold of real danger. Memory Trick: Remember "about 20 mA through the heart can be deadly."
Which body organ can be fatally affected by a very small amount of electrical current?

The heart is correct because small currents can disrupt its normal rhythm, leading to fibrillation and cardiac arrest. Other organs are harmed too, but the heart is the most critical at low current levels. Memory Trick: Think "electricity scrambles the heartbeat" first.
What is the lowest voltage that is usually considered hazardous to humans?

30 is correct because, under typical conditions, voltages above about 30 V can drive enough current through the human body to be dangerous, especially if the skin is wet. Memory Trick: Remember "30 volts and up: treat it with respect."
What should you do if you discover someone who is being burned by high voltage?
Turn off the power, call for emergency help and provide first aid if needed
Wait for a few minutes to see if the person can get away from the high voltage on their own, then try to help
Immediately drag the person away from the high voltage
Run from the area so you won't be burned too

Turn off the power, call for emergency help and provide first aid if needed is correct because you must first remove the source of danger, then get medical help, and only then safely assist the victim. Grabbing them while the power is on risks shocking yourself. Memory Trick: "Power off, phone, then first aid."
What is the safest method to remove an unconscious person from contact with a high-voltage source?
Remove the person by pulling an arm or a leg
De-energize the power source before touching the person
Wrap the person in a blanket and pull him to a safe area

De-energize the power source before touching the person is correct because you must not become part of the circuit. Only after the source is safely turned off or disconnected is it safe to touch them. Memory Trick: "Kill the power before you play hero."
Before checking a fault in a mains-operated power supply unit, it would be safest to first:
check the action of the capacitor bleeder resistance
remove and check the fuse from the power supply
turn off the power and unplug the power cord
short out the leads of the filter capacitor

Turn off the power and unplug the power cord is correct because physically disconnecting from the mains is the first step before any safe troubleshooting. The other actions still leave a risk if the unit is plugged in. Memory Trick: "Plug out before probe in."
What is the risk involved in troubleshooting a live power supply?

Electric shock is correct because exposed live parts in a powered supply can carry lethal voltages. While the other issues are possible, shock is the primary personal hazard. Memory Trick: Live supply = live danger.
For best protection from electrical shock, what should be grounded in your station?

All station equipment is correct because bonding all chassis to a common ground ensures that exposed metal parts stay at the same potential and are less likely to give you a shock. Memory Trick: "If it has a metal case, tie it to the same place."
Established practice demands that all ground electrodes be bonded together with heavy conductors. What protection does this provide in case of a lightning strike?
Reduces induced current by adding impedance
Establishes a ground (reference) plane at the station
Drains static electricity on a continuous basis

Prevents voltage differences between devices is correct because bonding keeps all grounds at nearly the same potential during a strike, reducing dangerous currents flowing between pieces of equipment. Memory Trick: One "big" ground system is safer than several separate ones.
Why should you never use a fuse with a higher current rating than specified?
Voltage delivered to the circuit would be limited
A low current circuit may not function properly
A fault may cause permanent damage, including a fire
The fuse may open during normal operation

A fault may cause permanent damage, including a fire is correct because a too-large fuse allows excessive current to flow without blowing, letting wiring or components overheat. Memory Trick: The fuse must "fail first" — if it is too big, something else will.
Which of these materials is best for a ground rod driven into the earth?

Copper-clad steel is correct because it combines good conductivity (copper) with mechanical strength (steel), and resists corrosion in the soil. Plastic and fibreglass are insulators, and plain steel corrodes quickly. Memory Trick: Think "copper outside, steel inside" for a long-lasting ground rod.
You need to work on a power supply that has been taken offline. What is the first thing you should do once the cabinet is open?
Place the unit on an insulating mat
Short the AC input leads together

Discharge the filter capacitors is correct because large capacitors can retain dangerous voltages even after the unit is unplugged. Safely discharging them removes this hidden shock hazard. Memory Trick: "Caps can stay charged – discharge them first."
Where should the green wire in a three-wire AC line cord be connected in a power supply?
To the "hot" side of the power switch

To the chassis is correct because the green wire is the safety ground, which must be bonded to the metal chassis so exposed metal stays at ground potential. Memory Trick: Green = safety ground = chassis.
Your third-floor station has a ground wire running 10 metres down to a ground rod. You get an RF burn when you touch your HF transceiver while transmitting. What is the likely cause?
The gauge of the ground wire used is insufficient
The ground connection of the wall outlet is defective
The ground wire has high impedance on your operating frequency
The transmitting antenna is not the correct wavelength

The ground wire has high impedance on your operating frequency is correct because a long, thin ground conductor can act like part of an antenna at HF, developing RF voltage along it. That can put RF on the chassis and cause burns. Memory Trick: Long "grounds" can behave like bad antennas at HF.
Where should the chassis ground terminals on all station equipment be connected?
To adjacent devices in a chain

To the station's single-point ground is correct because a single common bonding point minimizes circulating currents and voltage differences between equipment. Memory Trick: "One star ground" is better than a daisy-chain mess.
What is a safe method to discharge power supply filter capacitors?
Use an insulated shorting stick with an inline resistor
Use a long screwdriver with an insulated handle
Use an insulated wire with alligator clips on each end
Allow time for bleeder resistors to discharge the capacitors

Use an insulated shorting stick with an inline resistor is correct because it lets the stored energy bleed off in a controlled way, reducing the risk of a big spark, damage, or shock. A bare screwdriver or plain wire can cause arcing, and bleeder resistors may fail or not fully discharge. Memory Trick: "Stick plus resistor = safe discharge."
On mains-operated power supplies, the ground wire of the AC line is connected to the power supply chassis. What protection does this provide if a fault occurs in the power supply?
Prevents the equipment fuse from blowing unnecessarily
Ensures the chassis does not become energized
Protects connected equipment from over voltage
Prevents damage to the AC supply circuit breaker

Ensures the chassis does not become energized is correct because the safety ground forces fault current to flow to earth and trip the breaker or blow the fuse, keeping exposed metal from sitting at dangerous voltage. Memory Trick: Green wire to chassis = metal stays at "earth" potential.
Why do fuses have a voltage rating?
To limit current leakage to ground while in operation
To ensure voltage transients can be safely dissipated
To specify the voltage that can be interrupted without arcing
To prevent dielectric breakdown of the fuse holder

To specify the voltage that can be interrupted without arcing is correct because above that rating, when the fuse blows, the gap may not stop the higher voltage from jumping across. Memory Trick: Current rating = how much it carries, voltage rating = how much it can safely break.
Why should you ground all antenna and rotator cables when your station is not in use?
To lock the antenna system in one position
To prevent unauthorized persons from using the station
To help protect the station equipment and building from lightning damage

To help protect the station equipment and building from lightning damage is correct because grounding gives lightning surges a low-impedance path to earth instead of through your shack. Memory Trick: Cables to ground when idle = surge energy goes outside, not inside.
You want to install a lightning surge protector on your transmission line, where should it be inserted?
Outside, as close to earth grounding as possible

Outside, as close to earth grounding as possible is correct because the protector must dump the surge directly to ground before it enters the building. Memory Trick: "Stop the lightning at the wall" — surge protector by the ground rod.
How can your station equipment best be protected from lightning damage?
Disconnect the ground system from all radios
Disconnect all equipment from the power lines and antenna cables
Use heavy insulation on the wiring

Disconnect all equipment from the power lines and antenna cables is correct because lightning can travel in through both mains and feedlines. Physical disconnection greatly reduces the path into your gear. Memory Trick: "Unplug and unhook" before the storm.
What equipment should be worn for working on an antenna tower?

Approved fall arrest equipment is correct because it is specifically designed to stop or catch a fall safely. Belts, vests, or gloves do not replace proper harness and lanyard systems. Memory Trick: Tower work = full harness, not just a belt.
Why should you wear approved fall arrest equipment if you are working on an antenna tower?
To bring any tools you might use up and down the tower safely
To keep the tower from becoming unstable while you are working
To hold your tools so they don't fall and injure someone on the ground
To limit injuries if you fall

To limit injuries if you fall is correct because fall arrest gear is there to catch you and reduce impact forces. Tool handling and tower stability are separate issues. Memory Trick: Harness = "you fall, it saves all."
For safety, how high should you place a horizontal wire antenna?
High enough so that no one can touch any part of it from the ground
Just high enough so you can easily reach it for adjustments or repairs
As close to the ground as possible

High enough so that no one can touch any part of it from the ground is correct because touching a radiating conductor can cause RF burns or shock hazards. Memory Trick: If hands can reach the wire, it is not high enough.
Why should you wear a hard hat if you are on the ground helping someone work on an antenna tower?
So someone passing by will know that work is being done on the tower and will stay away
To protect your head from something dropped from the tower
So you won't be hurt if the tower should accidentally fall
To keep RF energy away from your head during antenna testing
To protect your head from something dropped from the tower is correct because tools or hardware can fall and cause serious injury. Memory Trick: "Work above, hard hat for love" (of your skull).
Why should your outside antennas be high enough so that no one can touch them while you are transmitting?
Touching the antenna might radiate harmonics
Touching the antenna might cause television interference
Touching the antenna might cause RF burns
Touching the antenna might reflect the signal back to the transmitter and cause damage
Touching the antenna might cause RF burns is correct because strong RF currents can heat tissue at contact points. Memory Trick: "Hot RF, hot metal, hot skin" — keep people away.
Why should you make sure that no one can touch an open-wire transmission line while you are transmitting with it?
Because contact might break the transmission line
Because contact might cause spurious emissions
Because contact might cause a short circuit and damage the transmitter
Because high-voltage radio energy might burn the person

Because high-voltage radio energy might burn the person is correct because open-wire lines can have high RF voltages between conductors, especially at high power. Memory Trick: Open wire + high RF = "do not touch" zone.
What safety precautions should you take before beginning repairs on an antenna?
Be sure to turn off the transmitter and disconnect the transmission line
Be sure the antenna structure is properly grounded
Plan the operation in the shortest possible time to minimize fatigue
Ensure all masts to be installed are sufficiently light

Be sure to turn off the transmitter and disconnect the transmission line is correct because you must remove RF power before working on any part of the antenna system. Memory Trick: "Dead rig, loose feed" before you climb.
What safety precaution is especially important for a ground-mounted antenna?
All radials should be buried at least 15 cm deep
Ensure people are kept at a safe distance
Ensure the feed point is at eye level
Ensure the location is as dry as possible

Ensure people are kept at a safe distance is correct because ground-mounted antennas are easy to touch and can expose people to strong RF fields. Memory Trick: Fence it, rope it, or sign it so people stay back.
What should you do for safety when operating at UHF and microwave frequencies?
Make sure the standing wave ratio is low before you conduct a test
Never use a horizontally polarized antenna
Keep antenna away from your eyes when RF is applied
Make sure that an RF leakage filter is installed at the antenna feed point

Keep antenna away from your eyes when RF is applied is correct because eyes are particularly sensitive to heating from high-frequency RF energy. Memory Trick: "Microwave RF: don't treat your eyes like food in an oven."
What should you do for safety if you put up a UHF transmitting antenna?
Make sure the antenna is near the ground to keep its RF energy pointing in the correct direction
Make sure you connect an RF leakage filter at the antenna feed point
Make sure that RF field screens are in place
Make sure the antenna will be in a place where no one can get near it when you are transmitting

Make sure the antenna will be in a place where no one can get near it when you are transmitting is correct because close exposure to strong UHF fields can be unsafe. Memory Trick: High frequency, high fence.
What should you do for safety, before removing the shielding on a UHF power amplifier?
Make sure the amplifier cannot accidentally be turned on
Make sure that RF leakage filters are connected
Make sure the amplifier output connector is grounded
Make sure all RF screens are in place at the amplifier output connector

Make sure the amplifier cannot accidentally be turned on is correct because you must prevent any chance of RF being produced while the shielding is off. Memory Trick: "Lock it out before you take it apart."
Why should you make sure the antenna of a hand-held transceiver is not close to your head when transmitting?
To help the antenna radiate energy equally in all directions
To reduce your exposure to the radio frequency energy
To use your body to reflect the signal in one direction
To keep static charges from building up

To reduce your exposure to the radio frequency energy is correct because near-field RF levels are highest close to the antenna, and your head is sensitive tissue. Memory Trick: "Talk near your mouth, keep RF away from your brain."
How should you position the antenna of a hand-held transceiver while you are transmitting?
Pointed down to bounce the signal off the ground
Away from your head and away from others
Pointed towards the station you are contacting
Away from your head and away from others is correct because it minimizes RF exposure to you and people nearby. Memory Trick: "Arm out, antenna out" to keep a bit of distance.
How can exposure to a large amount of RF energy affect body tissue?

It heats the tissue is correct because RF energy is absorbed and converted to heat, similar to how a microwave oven works. Memory Trick: Think "RF = radio-frequency heating" when levels are high enough.
Which body organ is the most likely to be damaged from the heating effects of RF radiation?

Eyes is correct because the lens and surrounding tissues have poor blood circulation and cannot carry heat away efficiently, making them especially vulnerable to RF heating. Memory Trick: Think "RF cooks like a microwave" — you protect your eyes first.
How does the power density of an electromagnetic wave change as it propagates away from an antenna in free space?
It decreases at a rate depending on ground absorption
It decreases as the square of the distance
It decreases linearly with the distance
It decreases in inverse proportion to the distance

It decreases as the square of the distance is correct because in free space the wave spreads out over a larger sphere, and the surface area grows with the square of the radius. Memory Trick: Double the distance = one-quarter the power density (inverse square law).
If you operate your station with indoor antennas, what precautions should you take when you install them?
Position the antennas along the edge of a wall where it meets the floor or ceiling to reduce parasitic radiation
Locate the antennas close to your operating position to minimize transmission line length
Locate the antennas as far away as possible from living spaces that will be occupied while you are operating
Position the antennas parallel to electrical power wires to take advantage of parasitic effects

Locate the antennas as far away as possible from living spaces that will be occupied while you are operating is correct because distance reduces RF exposure and the chance of accidental contact. Memory Trick: Indoor antennas = "out of reach and out of the room."
Why should directional high-gain antennas be mounted higher than nearby structures?
So static electricity buildup is minimized
So they will not damage nearby structures with RF energy
So they will receive more sky waves and fewer ground waves
So they will not direct RF energy toward people in nearby structures

So they will not direct RF energy toward people in nearby structures is correct because high-gain antennas concentrate RF in a narrow beam, and you want that beam above people, not through their living spaces. Memory Trick: High gain = high mount so the main beam clears the buildings.
For best RF safety, where should the ends and centre of a dipole antenna be located?
As high as possible to prevent people from coming in contact with the antenna
Near or over moist ground so RF energy will be radiated away from the ground
As close to the transmitter as possible so RF energy will be concentrated near the transmitter
Close to the ground so simple adjustments can be easily made without climbing a ladder

As high as possible to prevent people from coming in contact with the antenna is correct because it minimizes RF exposure and reduces the risk of shock or burns from touching the wire. Memory Trick: Dipole safety = "out of hand" height.
What term describes a circuit designed to increase the amplitude of a signal?
Amplifier is correct because its primary function is to make a signal larger in voltage, current, or power. Memory Trick: "Amp" in amplifier = "amplify" = make bigger.
If an amplifier becomes non-linear, the output signal would:

Become distorted is correct because in a non-linear amplifier, the output no longer follows the input proportionally, creating unwanted harmonics and distortion. Memory Trick: Linear = clean; non-linear = "bent" and distorted.
To increase the level of very weak radio signals from an antenna, you would use:
An RF amplifier is correct because it is designed to amplify radio-frequency signals coming from the antenna before further processing. Memory Trick: RF in, RF up — that is the RF amplifier's job.
To increase the level of very weak signals from a microphone you would use:
An audio amplifier is correct because a microphone produces low-level audio signals that must be boosted to a usable level. Memory Trick: Mic = audio; therefore, "audio amp" is the helper.
What range of frequencies does the speech amplifier of an amateur radio transceiver typically process?

300 Hz to 3 000 Hz is correct because that range contains most of the energy needed for intelligible human speech on communications circuits. Memory Trick: Remember "300 to 3000" as the classic voice-communications band.
Apart from power and current, which signal property can amplifiers be specifically designed to increase?

Voltage is correct because some amplifiers (like audio or RF voltage amplifiers) are designed primarily to increase signal voltage rather than current. Memory Trick: V = I × R — and some stages are mainly boosting the V.
The increase in signal level by an amplifier is called:
Gain is correct because it describes how much larger the output is compared to the input. Memory Trick: Think "gain = get more" from the signal.
A device with gain has the property of:
Amplification is correct because a device with gain makes the signal bigger; attenuation would make it smaller. Memory Trick: Gain and amplification always go together.
A device labelled "Gain = 10 dB" is likely to be an:

Amplifier is correct because a positive gain value (like +10 dB) means the device increases signal level; attenuators typically have negative dB values. Memory Trick: "+ dB" = amplifier, "- dB" = attenuator.
What term describes the ratio of output power to DC input power of an amplifier?

Efficiency is correct because it tells you what fraction of the DC input power is turned into useful RF output power instead of heat. Memory Trick: High efficiency = more watts out, fewer watts as heat.
What is the result of excessive positive feedback in an amplifier stage?

Oscillations appear is correct because too much positive feedback can cause the amplifier to feed on its own output and act like an RF or audio oscillator. Memory Trick: Positive feedback loop = "runaway" oscillation.
A diode is in series in the positive power lead to a transceiver. What is its purpose?

Reverse polarity protection is correct because the diode will block current if the supply is accidentally connected backwards, helping to prevent damage. Memory Trick: "One-way gate" so power flows only in the safe direction.
One important application for diodes is recovering information from transmitted signals. This is referred to as:

Detection is correct because the diode can rectify and "detect" the modulation envelope from a radio-frequency carrier, turning RF back into audio or data. Memory Trick: Detector diode = "demodulator" for AM signals.
The primary purpose of a Zener diode is to:
provide a path through which current can flow
regulate or maintain a constant voltage

Regulate or maintain a constant voltage is correct because a Zener diode conducts in reverse at a specific breakdown voltage, holding that voltage nearly constant. Memory Trick: "Zener = zero drift" voltage reference.
The action of changing alternating current to direct current is called:
Rectification is correct because diodes or rectifier circuits convert AC into pulsating DC, which can then be filtered. Memory Trick: "Rectifier" = "straightens" AC into one-way current.
The electrodes of a semiconductor diode are known as:

Anode and cathode is correct because those are the two terminals of any diode. Current flows from anode to cathode (conventional current), while electrons flow from cathode to anode. Memory Trick: "A → C" (Anode to Cathode) — just like ABC.
If alternating current is applied to the anode of a diode, what would you expect to see at the cathode?
Pulsating direct current is correct because a diode only passes one half of the AC waveform, creating a rectified (pulsating DC) output. Memory Trick: Diode = “one-way”; AC becomes “half-AC.”
In a semiconductor diode, electrons flow from:
Electrons flow from cathode to anode in a diode because electrons move from negative to positive. Memory Trick: Electrons are negative → they head toward the positive side (anode).
What semiconductor device glows different colours, depending upon its chemical composition?

A light-emitting diode is correct because different semiconductor materials produce different photon energies, resulting in different colours. Memory Trick: LED = "Light Every Device" — always the glowing one.
Which property of a semiconductor diode permits its use for reverse-polarity protection?
It conducts in one direction only
It has a high response speed
Its peak inverse voltage is below 1 volt
It conducts in one direction only is correct because that prevents damage when the polarity is reversed — the diode simply blocks current. Memory Trick: Diode = electrical “one-way door.”
In order for a diode to conduct, it must be:
Forward biased is correct because current flows only when the anode is more positive than the cathode. Reverse bias stops conduction. Memory Trick: “Forward = Flow.”
Which of these components can amplify a small signal using low voltages?

A bipolar transistor can amplify a small signal using low voltages because it operates as a linear amplifier in low-power circuits. The other components are switching or control devices and cannot provide linear amplification. Memory Trick: Think "BJT = Boosts Just a Tiny signal."
What term describes the most basic semiconductor component used to amplify?
Transistor is correct because amplification is one of its fundamental functions. Memory Trick: “Transistors TRANSfer power.”
What are the three electrodes of a bipolar transistor?
Collector, emitter and base are correct because these are the standard terminals on all BJTs. Memory Trick: C–B–E (sounds like “CB Radio”—easy to remember).
If a low-level signal is placed at the input to a transistor and a higher level of the signal is produced at the output, what is this effect called?
Amplification is correct because the transistor boosts the input signal’s power. Memory Trick: Amplification = “amp it up.”
What prevents the substitution of a PNP transistor with an NPN transistor?
The frequency response would be limited
The current gain would be too low
The polarities are reversed is correct because PNP and NPN require opposite biasing. They cannot be swapped without redesign. Memory Trick: NPN = arrow “Not Pointing iN,” PNP = arrow “Pointing iN.”
A semiconductor device is labelled as a "general purpose audio NPN device." What is it?
Bipolar transistor is correct because “NPN” refers specifically to BJT construction. Memory Trick: NPN → BJT.
What are the two basic types of bipolar transistors?
NPN and PNP are the two standard BJT types. Memory Trick: “N–P–N and P–N–P” — mirror opposites.
Which of these operating conditions is most likely to cause a transistor to fail?
Excessive heat is correct because heat destroys semiconductor junctions. Memory Trick: Semiconductors hate heat.
Which electrode of the bipolar transistor controls the output current?
Base is correct because tiny variations in base current control much larger collector-emitter currents. Memory Trick: Base = “boss” of the transistor.
When a bipolar transistor is used as a switch, which electrode controls its state?
Base is correct because applying current drives the transistor into either ON (saturation) or OFF (cut-off). Memory Trick: Flip the switch → flip the base.
If a transistor is alternatively driven into saturation and cut-off, what does it behave like?
A switch is correct because saturation = ON, cut-off = OFF. Memory Trick: Two states = switch.
When considering the material between source and drain, what are two basic types of field-effect transistors (FET)?
N channel and P channel is correct because these describe the polarity of the charge carriers in the channel. Memory Trick: FETs are "channel" devices.
Which semiconductor device has a gate, a drain and a source?
Field-effect transistor is correct because these are the standard FET terminal names. Memory Trick: FET = “G–D–S.”
In a field-effect transistor, which electrode controls the resistance of the device's channel?
Gate is correct because its voltage changes the channel width, controlling current flow. Memory Trick: Gate = “controls the flow like a water gate.”
In a field-effect transistor, from which electrode do charge carriers enter the channel?
Source is correct because by definition charge carriers “start” from the source and flow through the channel toward the drain. Memory Trick: Think “source = starting point.”
In a field-effect transistor, from which electrode do charge carriers leave the channel?
Drain is correct because charge carriers flow through the channel from source to drain, where they are “drained away.” Memory Trick: Source → channel → Drain (like water).
Why is a field-effect transistor considered a high impedance device?

The gate never conducts current is correct because the FET gate is insulated or reverse-biased, so almost no current flows into it, giving it a very high input impedance. Memory Trick: FET gate = “voltage control, not current hungry.”
What is the control electrode in a field-effect transistor?
Gate is correct because changing the gate voltage controls the channel’s conductivity and therefore the drain current. Memory Trick: A “gate” controls what gets through.
In a field-effect transistor, what circuit parameter change causes the current to increase?

The reverse bias is decreased is correct because reducing the reverse bias on the gate makes the channel less pinched off, allowing more current to flow. Memory Trick: Less reverse bias = less “pinch,” more current.
Which electrode of a bipolar transistor corresponds to the source of a field-effect transistor?
Emitter is correct because, like the FET source, it is the terminal from which charge carriers enter the device region. Memory Trick: Source ↔ Emitter = “starting side” of the device.
Which electrode of a bipolar transistor corresponds to the drain of a field-effect transistor?
Collector is correct because, like the FET drain, it is the terminal that “collects” carriers after they pass through the device region. Memory Trick: Drain ↔ Collector = “ending side” of the device.
In a field-effect transistor, which two electrodes are connected to the ends of the channel?

Source and drain is correct because the conductive channel is physically between these two terminals, with current flowing from source to drain. Memory Trick: Channel runs from S to D like a “Sidewalk.”
What is one reason a triode vacuum tube might be used instead of a transistor in a circuit?
It may be able to handle higher power

It may be able to handle higher power is correct because larger transmitting tubes can withstand high voltages and high RF power where many transistors cannot. Memory Trick: Think “big glass bottles = big power.”
Which two elements of a triode carry the output current?
Cathode and plate is correct because electrons are emitted by the cathode and collected by the plate (anode), forming the main current path. Memory Trick: C → P = current Path in a tube.
A feature common to triode tubes and transistors is that both:
use heat to cause electron movement
have electrons drifting through a vacuum
Can amplify signals is correct because both devices are active components that can provide gain. Memory Trick: Tubes and transistors both “turn small in → big out.”
Which electrode on a vacuum tube is operated with the highest positive voltage?

Plate is correct because in normal operation the plate (anode) is at the highest positive potential to attract electrons from the cathode. Memory Trick: Plate pulls electrons, so it must be most positive.
Which semiconductor device has characteristics most similar to a triode vacuum tube?
Field-effect transistor is correct because both triodes and FETs are voltage-controlled devices with a high-impedance control electrode (grid ↔ gate). Memory Trick: Grid ↔ Gate = “G to G.”
Which electrode of a vacuum triode is the control element?
Grid is correct because small changes in grid voltage control the much larger plate current. Memory Trick: Grid “guards” the flow.
In a vacuum tube, which electrode emits electrons?
Cathode is correct because it is heated (directly or indirectly) to emit electrons into the vacuum. Memory Trick: “Cat” throws (emits) electrons, plate catches them.
What is inside the envelope of a triode tube?
A vacuum is correct because removing air prevents collisions with gas molecules and allows electron flow to be controlled by the electrodes. Memory Trick: Vacuum tube literally needs a vacuum.
What term describes a vacuum tube with a cathode, a single grid and a plate?
Triode is correct because it has three active elements: cathode, grid and plate. Memory Trick: “Tri” = three.
On resistors with four colour bands, which colour band specifies the tolerance?
Fourth is correct because the last band in the 4-band code always indicates tolerance (for example, gold = ±5%). Memory Trick: “Last band = how accurate.”
On a resistor with four colour bands, what do the first three colour bands indicate?
The value of the resistor in ohms
The value of the resistor in ohms is correct because the first two bands are digits and the third band is the multiplier. Memory Trick: 1st + 2nd = numbers, 3rd = how many zeros.
On a resistor with four colour bands, what does the fourth colour band indicate?
The value of the resistor in ohms

The resistance tolerance in percent is correct because the fourth band shows how close the real value should be to the nominal value. Memory Trick: Think of the last band as the “trust band” — how much you can trust the printed value.
What are the possible values of a 100-ohm resistor with a 10% tolerance?
10% of 100 ohms is 10 ohms, so the resistor may vary from 100 - 10 = 90 ohms up to 100 + 10 = 110 ohms. Memory Trick: “10% of 100 = 10, so the range is 100 ± 10.”
On resistors with four colour bands, which colour band differentiates two resistors rated at 33 ohms and 39 ohms respectively?
The second band is the second digit of the resistor value. 33 = 3 & 3, 39 = 3 & 9 — only the second band changes. Memory Trick: “Second band = second digit.”
Out of the list of resistor tolerances below, which has the highest precision?
A lower percentage means a tighter tolerance. 0.10% is extremely precise. Memory Trick: “Small percent = small error.”
Out of the list of resistor tolerances below, which has the lowest precision?
20% tolerance means the value can vary the most, making it the least precise. Memory Trick: “Big percent = big wiggle room.”
How does the resistance of a resistor change with rising ambient temperature?
It depends on its temperature coefficient
Some resistors rise in value with heat; others drop. The direction depends entirely on the temperature coefficient. Memory Trick: “TC decides the trend.”
Which resistor rating is specified as a given fraction per degree Celsius?
The temperature coefficient (TC) describes how resistance changes per °C. Memory Trick: “TC = Temperature Change.”
On resistors with four colour bands, which colour band differentiates two resistors rated at 120 ohms and 1200 ohms respectively?
The third band is the multiplier. 120 = 12 × 10¹; 1200 = 12 × 10² — only the multiplier changes. Memory Trick: “Third band = multiplier.”
Given that red=2, violet=7 and yellow=4, what is the nominal value of a resistor whose colour code reads "red," "violet" and "yellow"?
Digits: 2, 7 → "27". Multiplier yellow = ×10⁴ → 27 × 10,000 = 270,000 ohms = 270 kΩ. Memory Trick: “Yellow = four zeros.”
If a dial marked in megahertz shows a reading of 3.525 MHz, what would it show if it were marked in kilohertz?
1 MHz = 1000 kHz, so multiply by 1000: 3.525 MHz → 3525 kHz. Memory Trick: “MHz to kHz = ×1000.”
If an ammeter marked in amperes is used to measure a 3000-milliampere current, what reading would it show?
3000 mA = 3 A (since 1000 mA = 1 A). Memory Trick: “milli → divide by 1000.”
1,000,000 pF = 1 µF. (1 µF = 1,000,000 pF). Memory Trick: “Six zeros = one micro.”
If you have a hand-held transceiver that puts out 500 milliwatts, how many watts would this be?
Convert mW to W by dividing by 1000: 500 mW = 0.5 W. Memory Trick: “milliwatts / 1000 = watts.”
“kilo” means 1000 → 1 kΩ = 1000 Ω. Memory Trick: “k = thousand.”
Divide by 1000: 7040 kHz → 7.040 MHz. Memory Trick: “kHz to MHz = ÷1000.”
A current of one quarter ampere may be written as:
0.25 A = 250 mA. Memory Trick: “Quarter amp → 250 mA.”
How many millivolts equal two volts?
1 V = 1000 mV → 2 V = 2000 mV. Memory Trick: “Volts × 1000 = millivolts.”
How can a frequency in megahertz be stated in gigahertz?
1 GHz = 1000 MHz, so MHz → GHz by dividing by 1000. Memory Trick: “GHz is bigger, so divide.”
1000 µH = 1 mH → 10,000 µH = 10 mH. Memory Trick: “Move the decimal three places for micro → milli.”
Which of these groups lists three good electrical conductors?
Gold, silver and aluminum all conduct electricity extremely well; the other materials listed include insulators. Memory Trick: “Metals shine, and metals conduct.”
Which of these groups lists three good electrical insulators?
Glass, air and porcelain are all very poor conductors, so they act as good insulators. Memory Trick: Think of power lines: glass, air and porcelain are used around them, not metals.
What do we call the flow of electric charge in a circuit?
Current is the name given to the flow of electric charge through a conductor. Memory Trick: Picture "a river of charge" flowing = current.
What is the best conductor among the following materials?
Copper has very low resistance and is widely used for wiring because it conducts better than the other options. Memory Trick: House wires = copper.
Which of these types of materials readily allows the flow of electric current?
A conductor is specifically defined as a material that allows electric current to flow easily. Memory Trick: "Conductor" conducts.
What electrical property causes an object to conduct electricity very well?
The lower the resistance, the easier current flows, so low resistance means good conduction. Memory Trick: Small R = easy I.
The letter "R" is the symbol for:
In basic circuit formulas and diagrams, R is used to represent resistance. Memory Trick: R for Resistance.
What is the inverse of resistance?
Conductance is defined as 1 / resistance and measures how easily current flows. Memory Trick: Big conductance = small resistance.
Any point in a circuit that has zero voltage
The difference in voltage at the output terminals of a transformer
The voltage output of a step-down transformer
The loss of voltage caused by the flow of current through a circuit
As current flows through a resistance, some voltage is "used up" across it; this is called voltage drop. Memory Trick: V drops across things in the path.
The resistance of a conductor changes with:
Resistance depends on temperature; metals usually increase in resistance as temperature rises. Memory Trick: Hot wire, higher R.
Which term describes the direction of current in a DC circuit?
Polarity indicates which side is positive and which is negative, and therefore the direction of DC current. Memory Trick: Polarity = plus/minus direction.
What term describes the rate at which electrical energy is used?
Power is the rate of using or delivering energy, measured in watts. Memory Trick: Power = energy per second.
If you have light bulbs marked 40 watts, 50 watts, 60 watts and 100 watts, which one will consume electrical energy at the highest rate?
The watt rating tells you how fast a device uses power; 100 W is the largest value, so it uses energy the fastest. Memory Trick: Bigger W = bigger bill.
What is the basic unit of electrical power?
Power in electrical systems is measured in watts (W). Memory Trick: Light bulbs are rated in watts.
A circuit consists of a battery and load resistor. What circuit malfunction would cause no current to be drawn from the battery?
An open circuit means the path is broken, so no current can flow at all. Memory Trick: "Open" = switch open = no current.
Which electrical circuit draws too much current?
A short circuit bypasses the normal load, leaving almost no resistance, so a very large current flows. Memory Trick: "Short" = shortcut path, huge current.
The standard unit for power is the watt. Memory Trick: P in W.
Which of the following two quantities should be multiplied together to find power?
Electrical power is given by P = V × I (voltage times current). Memory Trick: "Power triangle" starts with P = V I.
Which two electrical units multiplied together give the unit "watts"?
Multiplying volts by amperes gives watts (P = V × I). Memory Trick: V × A = W.
A resistor in a circuit becomes very hot and starts to burn. This is because the resistor is dissipating too much:
The resistor is converting too much electrical power into heat, exceeding its power rating. Memory Trick: Too many watts = too much heat.
When speaking of electrical circuits, what does the term "continuity" mean?
The circuit is designed for direct current (DC)
The circuit is supplied with backup power
The circuit is rated for continuous operation
The circuit is a closed circuit
Continuity means the circuit path is complete, allowing current to flow. Memory Trick: Continuity = “continuous path.”
You have acquired a transceiver and connected it to a power supply. When you switch on the power supply, its fuse blows immediately. What circuit malfunction caused the fuse to blow?
A short circuit causes excessive current, which immediately blows the fuse. Memory Trick: Short = sudden surge.
What is the voltage across a 2-ohm resistor if a current of 0.5 amperes flows through it?
Using Ohm’s Law: V = I × R = 0.5 × 2 = 1.0 V. Memory Trick: Double the ohms, double the volts.
How is the current in a DC circuit calculated when the voltage and resistance are known?
Current equals resistance divided by voltage
Current equals power divided by voltage
Current equals voltage divided by resistance
Current equals resistance multiplied by voltage
Ohm’s Law: I = V / R. Memory Trick: “I’m Very Ready” = I = V ÷ R.
How is the resistance in a DC circuit calculated when the voltage and current are known?
Resistance equals current multiplied by voltage
Resistance equals power divided by voltage
Resistance equals current divided by voltage
Resistance equals voltage divided by current
Ohm’s Law rearranged: R = V / I. Memory Trick: Resistance Resists = voltage over current.
How is the voltage in a DC circuit calculated when the current and resistance are known?
Voltage equals current multiplied by resistance
Voltage equals current divided by resistance
Voltage equals resistance divided by current
Voltage equals power divided by current
Ohm’s Law: V = I × R. Memory Trick: “Volts Increase with Resistance.”
What is the resistance of a circuit that draws 0.25 amperes from a 12-volt source?
R = V / I = 12 / 0.25 = 48 ohms. Memory Trick: Divide volts by amps for resistance.
What value of resistance is required to drop 9 volts with a current of 10 milliamperes?
10 mA = 0.01 A. R = 9 / 0.01 = 900 ohms. Memory Trick: Small current → big resistance.
If the current flowing through a 50-ohm resistor is 0.44 amperes, what voltage would you measure across the resistor?
V = I × R = 0.44 × 50 = 22 V. Memory Trick: 0.44 ≈ 0.5 → half of 50 ≈ 25 → close to 22.
A 30-ohm resistor is connected across a 6-volt battery. What current does it draw?
I = V / R = 6 / 30 = 0.2 A. Memory Trick: 6/30 = 1/5.
What voltage is needed to supply a current of 200 milliamperes to operate a relay that has a resistance of 25 ohms?
200 mA = 0.2 A. V = I × R = 0.2 × 25 = 5 V. Memory Trick: Multiply amps by ohms.
What formula calculates the resistance of a circuit when the voltage and current are known?
Standard Ohm’s Law form: R = V / I (E is another symbol for voltage). Memory Trick: R on top in the “Ohm’s Triangle.”
What is the resistance of a circuit if it draws 300 milliamperes from a 3-volt battery?
In a parallel circuit with a voltage source and several branch resistors, how is the total current related to the current in the branch resistors?
It equals the sum of the branch current through each resistor
It equals the average of the branch current through each resistor
It decreases as more parallel resistors are added
It is the sum of each resistor's voltage drop multiplied by the number of resistors
In parallel, currents add: I_total = I₁ + I₂ + I₃ … Memory Trick: “Parallel Paths → Parallel Currents.”
You connect four 100-ohm resistors in parallel across a 12-volt battery. How many milliamperes of current are drawn from the battery?
Each branch draws 12/100 = 0.12 A. Four branches: 0.12 × 4 = 0.48 A = 480 mA. Memory Trick: Multiply one path by four.
Several resistors of various values are connected in parallel. How does the total resistance of the combination compare to the individual resistors?
It equals the square root of the sum
It is less than the smallest resistor
It is greater than the largest resistor
Parallel resistance always drops below the lowest resistor in the group. Memory Trick: “Parallel pulls R down.”
Two 1000-ohm resistors are connected in parallel across a 12-volt battery. What is the total current?
Two 1000-ohm resistors in parallel = 500 ohms. I = 12/500 = 0.024 A = 24 mA. Memory Trick: Two in parallel halves the resistance.
The total resistance of resistors connected in series is:
greater than the resistance of any one resistor
less than the resistance of any one resistor
equal to the highest resistor present
equal to the lowest resistor present
Series resistances add, making the total always larger than any individual resistor. Memory Trick: “Series stacks.”
What is the total resistance of five 10-ohm resistors in series?
Add them: 10 + 10 + 10 + 10 + 10 = 50 ohms. Memory Trick: Series = simple sum.
Which of these series combination of resistors would replace a single 120-ohm resistor?

To replace a 120 ohm resistor using series resistors, their values must add up to 120 ohms. Five 24 ohm resistors in series give 24 × 5 = 120 ohms, making option C correct. The other combinations add up to higher values and cannot substitute a 120 ohm resistor. Memory Trick: Think "24 times 5 equals 120."
If ten resistors of equal value "R" are wired in parallel, what formula yields the total resistance?

Ten identical resistors in parallel give a total resistance of R / 10 because the resistance is divided by the number of equal branches. Memory Trick: Equal resistors in parallel → R divided by how many.
What is the total resistance of four 68-ohm resistors wired in parallel?
Four equal resistors in parallel give R_total = R / 4, so 68 / 4 = 17 ohms. Memory Trick: Equal-parallel shortcut: divide by the number of resistors.
Two resistors are in parallel. Resistor "A" carries twice the current of resistor "B," which means that:
B has half the resistance of "A"
A has half the resistance of "B"
the voltage across "B" is twice that across "A"
the voltage across "A" is twice that across "B"
In parallel, both resistors have the same voltage, so current is inversely proportional to resistance. Twice the current means half the resistance. Memory Trick: More current → less resistance.
The total current in a parallel circuit is equal to the:
source voltage divided by the sum of the resistive elements
current in any one of the parallel branches
sum of the currents through all the parallel branches
source voltage divided by the value of one of the resistive elements
In a parallel circuit, the source current splits into branches and then recombines, so the total is the sum of all branch currents. Memory Trick: Parallel paths → parallel currents add.
Why would a large size resistor be used instead of a smaller one of the same resistance?
For less impedance in the circuit
A physically larger resistor can safely turn more power into heat without burning up. Memory Trick: Bigger body, better heat-handling.
A load requires 12 volts DC at 5 amperes. What is the minimum required power transformer rating?
Power P = V × I = 12 × 5 = 60 watts. Memory Trick: Volts times amps gives watts.
What is the DC input power of a transmitter operating at 12 volts and drawing 500 milliamperes?
500 mA = 0.5 A, so P = 12 × 0.5 = 6 watts. Memory Trick: Convert mA to A, then multiply V × A.
When two 500-ohm 1-watt resistors are connected in series, the maximum total power that can be dissipated by the resistors is:
Each resistor can safely dissipate 1 W; in series, both still handle 1 W each, so the total is 2 W. Memory Trick: Same power in series → add wattages.
When two 500-ohm 1-watt resistors are connected in parallel, they can dissipate a maximum total power of:
Each resistor can still safely dissipate 1 W, so two in parallel can handle 2 W total. Memory Trick: Same power in parallel → add wattages.
If the voltage applied to two resistors in series is doubled, how much will the total power change?
Power in a fixed resistance is P = V² / R, so doubling voltage makes V² four times bigger. Memory Trick: Double the volts → 4× the watts.
Which of these combinations of resistors could make up a 50-ohm dummy load capable of safely dissipating 5 watts?
Four 200-ohm resistors in parallel give 200 / 4 = 50 ohms, and 4 × 2 W = 8 W capacity, which is safely above 5 W. Memory Trick: Check resistance first, then make sure total watts > needed watts.
How much current is drawn by a 12-volt, 30-watt light bulb?
I = P / V = 30 / 12 = 2.5 A. Memory Trick: Rearrange P = V × I to I = P / V.
What is the power consumption of two 10-ohm resistors connected in series with a 10-volt battery?
Series resistance is 10 + 10 = 20 Ω. Current I = 10 / 20 = 0.5 A, so P = V × I = 10 × 0.5 = 5 W. Memory Trick: Find total R → current → then power.
What is the advantage of replacing a 50-ohm resistor with a parallel combination of two 100-ohm resistors of the same power rating?
Same resistance but greater power rating
Same resistance but lesser power rating
Greater resistance and same power rating
Lesser resistance and same power rating
Two 100-ohm resistors in parallel give 50 ohms, and their wattage adds, so the total power rating is higher. Memory Trick: Parallel halves the ohms, doubles the watts.
variable in steps of one hundred
calculated according to physical size and tolerance rating
Wattage rating tells how much heat the resistor can safely dissipate without damage. Memory Trick: More watts = more heat it can handle.
What is the term for the number of times per second an alternating current completes a positive to negative cycle?
Frequency is how many complete cycles occur per second, measured in hertz (Hz). Memory Trick: “How often?” per second = frequency.
What approximate range of frequencies can most humans hear?
The normal human hearing range is roughly 20 Hz to 20 kHz. Memory Trick: Think “20 to 20k” for audio.
Why is the range of frequencies from 20 Hz to 20 kHz termed audio frequencies?
Because the human ear can sense sound in this range
Because this is the speaker response range of a modern SSB receiver
Because sound can be in this range but it's too low for RF signals
Because RF signals in this range can be directly converted to sound
Audio frequencies are defined by what the human ear can hear, about 20 Hz to 20 kHz. Memory Trick: Audio = audible.
Electrical energy at a frequency of 7125 kHz is in what frequency range?
7125 kHz = 7.125 MHz, which lies in the HF band (3–30 MHz). Memory Trick: 7 MHz lives in the HF “shortwave” band.
What is the name for the distance an AC signal travels during one complete cycle?
Wavelength is the physical distance from one cycle peak (or phase point) to the next. Memory Trick: One full wave in space = wavelength.
What happens to a signal's wavelength as its frequency increases?
It decreases proportionally to frequency squared
It increases proportionally to frequency squared
It decreases is correct because wavelength and frequency are inversely related (λ = c / f). Higher frequency → shorter wavelength. Memory Trick: Think “frequency up, wavelength down” like a seesaw.
What happens to a signal's frequency as its wavelength gets shorter?
It decreases proportionally to frequency squared
It increases proportionally to frequency squared
It increases is correct because when wavelength shrinks, frequency rises (λ = c / f). Memory Trick: Shorter wave → faster wiggle.
60 cycles per second is correct because hertz literally means “cycles per second.” Memory Trick: Hz = How many cycles per second.
Two AC waveforms have the same frequency, but their cycles do not begin at the same instant. What term describes that timing difference?
Phase is correct because phase describes timing differences between waveforms at the same frequency. Memory Trick: “Out of phase” = out of sync in time.
What is the shape of the waveform of the electricity supplied from a household receptacle?
Sine wave is correct because AC mains power is generated as a smooth sinusoid. Memory Trick: Utility companies love clean sine waves.
A signal is composed of a fundamental frequency of 2 kHz and another of 4 kHz. What name is given to the 4 kHz signal?
Harmonic is correct because 4 kHz is exactly 2× the 2 kHz fundamental (second harmonic). Memory Trick: Harmonics = multiples.
A two-times increase in power results in a change of how many dB?
3 dB corresponds to doubling power. Memory Trick: 3 dB ≈ 2×, 6 dB ≈ 4×.
What change in transmitter power results in a 3 dB decrease?
A 3 dB drop halves the power. Memory Trick: 3 dB = ×2 or ÷2 depending on direction.
What change in transmitter power results in a 6 dB increase?
6 dB = 4× power. Memory Trick: Double twice → 2×2 = 4.
If a signal transmitted with a power of 200 watts is received with an S-meter reading of "10 dB over S9," what would be the new reading if power was reduced to 20 watts?
20 W is 1/10 of 200 W → 10 dB reduction → reading drops from +10 dB to S9. Memory Trick: 10× change = 10 dB.
If a signal transmitted with a power of 150 watts is received with an S-meter reading of "20 dB over S9," what would be the new reading if power was reduced to 15 watts?
15 W is 1/10 of 150 W → 10 dB drop → S9+20 dB becomes S9+10 dB. Memory Trick: Move one decimal → subtract 10 dB.
To describe very high frequency radio waves
To measure a single sideband signal
To measure the ratio of two signals
To describe a waveform on an oscilloscope
dB measures ratios, not absolute quantities. Memory Trick: dB = difference between two things.
The power output from a transmitter increases from 1 watt to 2 watts. How many decibels does that increase represent?
Doubling power → 3 dB increase. Memory Trick: 3 dB = 2×.
The power of a transmitter is increased from 5 watts to 50 watts by a linear amplifier. The power gain, expressed in dB, is:
50 / 5 = 10× → 10× = 10 dB gain. Memory Trick: One zero = +10 dB.
You add a 9 dB gain amplifier to your 2-watt hand-held. What is the power output of the combination?
9 dB ≈ 8× gain. 2 W × 8 = 16 W. Memory Trick: 9 dB ~ “almost 10 dB,” but actually 8×.
The power of your transmitter is 100 watts and your transmission line introduces a loss of 6 dB. How much power is delivered to the antenna?
6 dB loss = ÷4. 100 W ÷ 4 = 25 W. Memory Trick: –6 dB cuts power to a quarter.
A local amateur reports receiving your 100-watt 2-metre simplex transmission with an S-meter reading of "30 dB over S9." What power could you use to reduce that reading to S9?
Reducing from +30 dB to 0 dB requires cutting power by 30 dB → 1000× reduction. 100 W / 1000 = 0.1 W. Memory Trick: 30 dB = 10×10×10 = 1000×.
If two equal-value inductors are connected in series, what is their total inductance?
Twice the value of one inductor
Half the value of one inductor
The value of one inductor times 4
The value of one inductor divided by 4
Series inductance adds, just like resistors in series. Memory Trick: Inductors behave like resistors for series/parallel math.
If two equal-value inductors are connected in parallel, what is their total inductance?
The value of one inductor divided by 4
Half the value of one inductor
Twice the value of one inductor
The value of one inductor times 4
Parallel inductors behave like parallel resistors. Two equal inductors → L/2. Memory Trick: Same rule as resistors.
If two equal-value capacitors are connected in series, what is their total capacitance?
The value of one capacitor times 4
The value of one capacitor divided by 4
Half the value of either capacitor
Twice the value of one capacitor
Capacitors in series behave like resistors in parallel → value decreases. Two equal caps → C/2. Memory Trick: Opposite of inductors.
If two equal-value capacitors are connected in parallel, what is their total capacitance?
Half the value of either capacitor
The value of one capacitor times 4
The value of one capacitor divided by 4
Twice the value of one capacitor

Twice the value of one capacitor is correct because parallel capacitances add (Ctotal = C1 + C2). For two equal caps, that becomes 2C. Memory Trick: Capacitors in parallel behave like buckets side by side – more total capacity.
You are constructing an air-core inductor using a coil of wire. What parameters determine its inductance?
Coil diameter, coil length and number of turns of wire
Coil diameter, coil length and operating frequency
Type of wire, coil length and number of turns of wire
Coil diameter, coil orientation and number of turns of wire
Coil diameter, coil length and number of turns of wire is correct because L depends mainly on the geometry of the coil. Memory Trick: Think "big, long, and many turns" → bigger inductance.
A capacitor is made of two identical metal plates separated by air. What parameters determine its capacitance?
Surface area of the plates and applied voltage
Surface area of the plates and spacing between the plates
Operating frequency and spacing between the plates
Type of metal and spacing between the plates
Surface area of the plates and spacing between the plates is correct because C grows with plate area and shrinks as spacing increases. Memory Trick: Big plates close together = big capacitance.
What precaution must you take when using polarized electrolytic capacitors?
Use them exclusively at radio frequencies
Do not use them in series combinations
Do not parallel with capacitors other than electrolytics
Never apply a reverse voltage is correct because a reversed electrolytic can overheat, leak or explode. Memory Trick: "Plus to plus" on an electrolytic – never backwards.
If you wire two 12-millihenry chokes in series, what is the inductance of the combination?
