24 millihenries is correct because inductors in series add (Ltotal = L1 + L2). Two 12 mH chokes → 12 + 12 = 24 mH. Memory Trick: Inductors in series act like resistors in series.
If you wire two 20-millihenry inductors in parallel, what is the inductance of the combination?
10 millihenries is correct because equal inductors in parallel give half the value (Ltotal = L / 2). Memory Trick: Same rule as resistors in parallel – two equal values become half.
If you wire two 20-microfarad capacitors in series, what is the capacity of the combination?
10 microfarads is correct because capacitors in series behave like resistors in parallel. Two equal caps → Ctotal = C / 2 = 10 µF. Memory Trick: Opposite of inductors – series makes C smaller.
If you wire two 24-microfarad capacitors in parallel, what is the capacity of the combination?
48 microfarads is correct because capacitors in parallel add (24 µF + 24 µF = 48 µF). Memory Trick: Parallel = plates side by side → more total capacitance.
How does an inductor react to AC?
As the amplitude of the applied AC increases, the reactance decreases
As the amplitude of the applied AC increases, the reactance increases
As the frequency of the applied AC increases, the reactance decreases
As the frequency of the applied AC increases, the reactance increases

As the frequency of the applied AC increases, the reactance increases is correct because XL = 2πfL. Higher f → higher XL. Memory Trick: Inductor = "high pass" for reactance: more frequency, more opposition.
How does a capacitor react to AC?
As the frequency of the applied AC increases, the reactance decreases
As the frequency of the applied AC increases, the reactance increases
As the amplitude of the applied AC increases, the reactance increases
As the amplitude of the applied AC increases, the reactance decreases

As the frequency of the applied AC increases, the reactance decreases is correct because XC = 1 / (2πfC). Higher f → smaller XC. Memory Trick: Capacitor is opposite the inductor: more frequency, less opposition.
The reactance of capacitors increases as:
Frequency decreases is correct because XC = 1 / (2πfC). Lower f → larger XC. Memory Trick: For capacitors: "frequency down, reactance up."
What is the term for the opposition to alternating current caused by the combined effect of reactance and resistance?
Impedance is correct because it is the vector combination of resistance (R) and reactance (X) seen by AC. Memory Trick: Z (impedance) is the AC version of R.
What term equals the ratio of AC voltage to AC current in a system or circuit?
Impedance is correct because Z = V / I for AC, just as R = V / I for DC, but including reactance effects. Memory Trick: Same Ohm's Law form, but Z instead of R.
What circuit parameter change causes an inductor's reactance to increase?
An increase in frequency is correct because XL = 2πfL, so XL grows as frequency increases. Memory Trick: For inductors: "frequency up, XL up."
What property allows a coil wound on a ferrite core to mitigate the effects of an offending radio signal?

A coil wound on a ferrite core presents high reactance at radio frequencies, which blocks or attenuates unwanted RF signals while allowing low-frequency currents to pass. The other options describe reactance at audio frequencies, which is not relevant for RF interference suppression. Memory Trick: Ferrite fights RF by raising reactance at high frequencies.
What property allows a bypass capacitor in an audio circuit to divert an interfering RF signal?
Low reactance at radio frequencies is correct because the capacitor looks like a short to RF, sending it to ground instead of into the audio path. Memory Trick: Bypass cap = RF drain.
What property allows an RF bypass capacitor to have little effect on an audio circuit?

High reactance at audio frequencies is correct because the capacitor looks like a very high impedance at low (audio) frequencies, so it does not shunt the wanted audio. Memory Trick: Big reactance at audio = leaves the audio alone.
What property allows an RF choke coil to have little effect on signals meant to flow through the coil?
Low reactance at low frequencies is correct because an RF choke is designed to block RF (high f, high XL) but pass low-frequency or DC (low f, low XL). Memory Trick: Choke blocks RF, not DC.
In general, the reactance of inductors increases with:
Increasing AC frequency is correct because inductive reactance follows XL = 2πfL. Memory Trick: Inductor = "more reactance with more cycles."
A transformer with a 120-volt primary voltage supplies 250 watts to a transmitter. Neglecting losses, what is the approximate primary current?
2.1 amperes is correct because I = P / V = 250 W / 120 V ≈ 2.08 A, which rounds to 2.1 A. Memory Trick: For power lines, think "I = P over V."
How can a transformer with two windings change impedance?
By using the correct magnetic coupling between windings
By allowing the difference to be dissipated in core losses
By matching winding resistance to impedance
By carrying different voltages and currents in each winding

By carrying different voltages and currents in each winding is correct because impedance transformation occurs through the turns ratio: Z₂/Z₁ = (N₂/N₁)². Memory Trick: "Turns ratio squares the impedance."
A transformer with a single 12-volt secondary draws 0.5 amperes through its 120-volt primary. Assuming no losses, what current is drawn from the secondary?
5 amperes is correct because power in = power out (ideal). P = 120 V × 0.5 A = 60 W. Secondary current = 60 W / 12 V = 5 A. Memory Trick: "Same watts in and out."
The primary winding of a transformer has 250 turns, and the secondary has 500 turns. If the input voltage is 120 volts, what is the secondary voltage?
240 V is correct because doubling the number of turns doubles the voltage. Turns ratio = 500/250 = 2. Memory Trick: "Turns up → voltage up."
The strength of the magnetic field around a conductor in air is:
directly proportional to the diameter of the conductor
inversely proportional to the voltage on the conductor
directly proportional to the current in the conductor
inversely proportional to the diameter of the conductor
Magnetic field strength increases with current (H ∝ I). Memory Trick: "More amps = more magnet."
Maximum induced voltage in a coil occurs when:
the current through the coil is DC
current is going through its least rate of change
the magnetic field around the coil is not changing
current is going through its greatest rate of change
Induced voltage follows Faraday's Law: more rapid magnetic change = more induced voltage. Memory Trick: "Fast change = big voltage."
A transformer primary winding consumes 10 watts. Neglecting losses, if the secondary voltage is 5 volts, what is the secondary current?
Power out = power in = 10 W. Current = P/V = 10/5 = 2 A. Memory Trick: "Divide watts by volts."
A step-up transformer with a primary to secondary turns ratio of 1:5 delivers 50 milliamperes to a load. Assuming 100% efficiency, what is the primary current?
Currents scale inversely with turns ratio. Secondary current = 50 mA → primary current = 5 × 50 = 250 mA. Memory Trick: "Step-up voltage = step-down current."
When is coupling (induction) between two wires maximum?
When the wires are separated and parallel
When the wires are separated and at right angles
When the wires are close and parallel
When the wires are close and at right angles
Coupling increases when fields overlap fully: close + parallel. Memory Trick: "Side by side = strongest ride."
A permanent magnet would most likely be made from:
Steel retains magnetism because of its ferromagnetic properties. Memory Trick: "Steel sticks."
What confirms the fact that the transfer of energy from the primary to the secondary of a transformer is not perfect?
Warm laminations show core losses (eddy currents & hysteresis). Memory Trick: "Heat = loss."
Resonance is the condition that exists when:
resistance is equal to the reactance
inductive reactance and capacitive reactance are equal
inductive reactance is the only opposition in the circuit
At resonance, XL = XC. Memory Trick: "X’s cancel."
At resonance, what impedance does a parallel tuned circuit exhibit?
Impedance equal to reactance of the circuit
Impedance equal to resistance of the circuit
Parallel resonant circuits block current → high impedance. Memory Trick: "Parallel = peak impedance."
While the resonant frequency is a single value, the effect extends across a range of frequencies. What is this range called?
Bandwidth defines the useful operating range near resonance. Memory Trick: "Resonance spreads."
What two components are required to form a tuned circuit?
LC combinations determine resonant frequency. Memory Trick: "L + C = f₀."
When a parallel coil-capacitor combination is supplied with AC of different frequencies, the frequency giving highest impedance is the:
Parallel LC has maximum impedance at resonance. Memory Trick: "Peak Z at f₀."
In a parallel-resonant circuit at resonance, the circuit has:
Parallel LC blocks current at resonance. Memory Trick: "Parallel = chokes at f₀."
In a series resonant circuit at resonance, the circuit has:
Series LC passes current easily at resonance: impedance minimum. Memory Trick: "Series = short at f₀."
A coil and air-spaced capacitor form a resonant circuit. The resonant frequency will remain the same if we:
add a resistor to the circuit
increase the area of the plates
wind more turns on the coil
Resistance does not change LC resonance; only L or C affect f₀. Memory Trick: "R doesn’t tune f."
Resonant circuits in a receiver are used to:
Tuned circuits pick out specific frequencies. Memory Trick: "Resonance = radio selectivity."
Resonance is the condition that exists when:
inductive reactance and capacitive reactance are equal and opposite in sign
inductive reactance is the only opposition
XL = +X and XC = –X; at resonance they cancel. Memory Trick: "The X’s cancel each other."
What happens to current when a series RLC circuit is tuned to the frequency of the source?
It is limited by inductive reactance
It is limited by capacitive reactance

It reaches maximum is correct because at series resonance the inductive and capacitive reactances cancel each other, leaving only resistance. With minimum impedance, the current is at its highest for a given applied voltage. Memory Trick: Series resonance = “Z minimum, I maximum.”
How is a voltmeter usually connected to a circuit under test?

In parallel with the circuit is correct because a voltmeter must measure the potential difference between two points, so it is placed across (in parallel with) the component or section of interest. Memory Trick: Voltage = “across,” so the meter goes across.
How is an ammeter usually connected to a circuit under test?

In series with the circuit is correct because an ammeter must measure the current flowing through a conductor, so that conductor is routed through the meter. Memory Trick: Current = “through,” so the meter goes in series.

Voltage, current and resistance is correct because these three basic quantities (V, I, R) are the standard functions of a typical multimeter. Memory Trick: Think “VIR” like Ohm’s Law – those are your three basics.
What is the correct instrument to measure the final power amplifier current?

An ammeter is correct because current is measured in amperes, and an ammeter is inserted in series with the PA supply line to show how much current the stage draws. Memory Trick: “Amp in Amps” – use an ammeter for amplifier current.
When measuring the voltage across a circuit component, what does the voltmeter appear to be in the circuit?

A high value resistance is correct because a voltmeter is designed with very high internal resistance so that it draws minimal current and does not disturb the circuit. Memory Trick: Voltmeter ≈ “barely there” load.
When measuring current drawn from a DC power supply, what does the ammeter placed in the circuit appear as?

A low value resistance is correct because an ammeter is designed with very low internal resistance so that it does not significantly change the current it is measuring. Memory Trick: Ammeter ≈ “almost a short” inside.
What instrument can provide a direct measurement of power at the output of a transmitter?
RF wattmeter is correct because it is specifically designed to measure RF power in watts in a transmission line between transmitter and load. Memory Trick: Need watts? Use a wattmeter.
Potential difference is measured by means of:
A voltmeter is correct because potential difference is voltage, and a voltmeter is calibrated directly in volts between two points in a circuit. Memory Trick: V → voltmeter.
What instrument is used to measure electrical current?
Ammeter is correct because it is specifically designed to measure current in amperes when inserted in series with the circuit. Memory Trick: “Amps → Ammeter.”
What term describes the ability of an instrument to display values that are true to reality?

Accuracy is correct because it refers to how close a measurement is to the true value. Precision is repeatability, resolution is smallest step, stability is how it holds calibration over time. Memory Trick: Accuracy = “truth closeness.”
What connects your transceiver to your antenna?

A transmission line is correct because it is the dedicated feedline (such as coax or open wire) used to carry RF energy from the transmitter to the antenna. Memory Trick: “Radio highway” = transmission line.
The characteristic impedance of a transmission line is determined by the:
frequency at which the line is operated
load placed at the end of the line
physical dimensions and relative positions of the conductors

Physical dimensions and relative positions of the conductors is correct because Z₀ depends on conductor diameters, spacing, and the dielectric between them, not on line length or load. Memory Trick: Z₀ is “built-in geometry,” not how long the line is.
The characteristic impedance of a 20-metre piece of transmission line is 52 ohms. What would the impedance be if 10 metres were cut off?

52 ohms is correct because characteristic impedance is a property of the line’s construction (diameter, spacing, dielectric), and does not change with length. Memory Trick: Cutting the line changes length and loss, not Z₀.
Why can coaxial cables of different diameters have the same characteristic impedance?
Their characteristic impedance depends on operating frequency
Their characteristic impedance depends on the ratio of conductor diameters
Characteristic impedance is independent of line diameter
Characteristic impedance is set by the choice of conducting material

Their characteristic impedance depends on the ratio of conductor diameters is correct because Z₀ depends on the ratio of inner to outer conductor size and the dielectric constant. Different diameters with the same ratio and dielectric can yield the same Z₀. Memory Trick: “Same ratio = same Z₀.”
What commonly available transmission line can be buried directly in the ground for some distance without adverse effects?

Coaxial cable is correct because its shielded construction and jacket allow limited direct burial when properly rated, unlike open-wire and twin-lead lines which are highly affected by moisture and nearby objects. Memory Trick: Coax is “rugged and jacketed.”

A transmitter is delivering radio frequency (RF) energy into a coaxial cable with a characteristic impedance of 50 ohms. The cable is terminated by a purely resistive load. What value of load resistance will absorb all the RF energy it receives?
50 ohms is correct because maximum power transfer and no reflections occur when the load impedance equals the line’s characteristic impedance. Memory Trick: “Match Z to move all the power.”
What is the major factor influencing the velocity factor of a coaxial cable?
Size and spacing of the conductors
Use of a solid or braided shield

Dielectric material is correct because the wave speed in the cable depends on the dielectric constant of the insulation between conductors, which directly sets the velocity factor. Memory Trick: “VF follows the plastic (dielectric), not the copper.”
The characteristic impedance of an open-wire transmission line depends, in part, on the diameter of its conductors. What other dimension determines its characteristic impedance?

Spacing of the conductors is correct because Z₀ for open-wire line is set by conductor diameter, spacing, and dielectric (air). Height above ground and length affect patterns and loss but not Z₀ itself. Memory Trick: “Diameter and distance apart set the ohms.”
A transmission line is terminated by an impedance that differs significantly from the characteristic impedance of the line. What impedance will be measured at the input of the line?
An impedance nearly equal to the characteristic impedance
A value of impedance influenced by line length

A value of impedance influenced by line length is correct because when the load is mismatched, standing waves form and the input impedance becomes a complex value that varies with line length and frequency. Memory Trick: “Mismatch makes the input Z wander along the line.”
What factors determine the characteristic impedance of an open-wire transmission line?
The distance between the centres of the conductors and the length of the line
The radius of the conductors and the frequency of the signal
The frequency of the signal and the length of the line
The distance between the centres of the conductors and the diameter of the conductors

The distance between the centres of the conductors and the diameter of the conductors is correct because the characteristic impedance of open-wire line is set by its geometry (wire size and spacing) and the dielectric, not by length or operating frequency. Memory Trick: For open wire, think “D & d” – Distance and diameter decide Z0.
What factors determine the characteristic impedance of a coaxial transmission line?
The ratio of the diameter of the outer shield to the diameter of the inner conductor
The diameter of the shield and the length of the line
The diameter of the shield and the frequency of the signal
The frequency of the signal and the length of the line

The ratio of the diameter of the outer shield to the diameter of the inner conductor is correct because Z0 for coax is set by the inner/outer diameter ratio and the dielectric constant, not by line length or frequency. Memory Trick: “Ratio and plastic” – ratio of diameters plus dielectric sets Z0.
What kind of transmission line has a centre wire inside an insulating material that is covered by a metal shield or sleeve?
Coaxial cable is correct because its structure is a central conductor, insulating dielectric, and surrounding cylindrical shield. Memory Trick: “Co-axial” = conductors share the same axis.
What kind of transmission line has two wires side-by-side embedded in insulating material?

Window line is correct because it is a type of twin-lead where two parallel conductors are held in a flat insulating ribbon with “windows” (holes) punched out. Memory Trick: Think of a flat ladder with windows – that’s window line.
What kind of transmission line is made of two conductors held apart by insulated rods?

Open-wire line is correct because it consists of two bare or insulated conductors separated by insulating spacers or rods, exposed to the air. Memory Trick: “Open” as in open to the air with spreaders.
What is the purpose of a balun?

Connect balanced and unbalanced systems is correct because “balun” literally comes from BALanced–UNbalanced and is used to interface coax (unbalanced) to antennas or lines that are balanced. Memory Trick: BAL-UN = BALanced to UNbalanced.
Where would you install a balun to feed a dipole antenna with 50-ohm coaxial cable?
Between the coaxial cable and the ground
Between the coaxial cable and the antenna
Between the transmitter and the coaxial cable
Between the antenna and the ground

Between the coaxial cable and the antenna is correct because the balun must sit at the transition point between the unbalanced coax and the balanced dipole. Memory Trick: Put the BAL-UN right where the “balance changes” – at the feedpoint.
What causes a transmission line to be unbalanced?
One conductor has a poor connection at the antenna
One conductor is connected to ground

One conductor is connected to ground is correct because an unbalanced line (like coax) has one conductor at RF ground and the other “hot,” unlike balanced lines where both conductors float equally. Memory Trick: If one side is grounded, the line is unbalanced.
What device can be installed to feed a balanced antenna with an unbalanced transmission line?
A balun is correct because it interfaces unbalanced coax to a balanced antenna or feedline, providing proper current balance. Memory Trick: Again, BAL-UN = balanced ↔ unbalanced.
What device should you use to connect a coaxial cable to window line?

A balun is correct because coax is unbalanced and window line is balanced; the balun converts between the two types of lines. Memory Trick: Whenever you go coax ↔ twin-lead/window line, think “balun bridge.”
is made of one conductor only
is made of two parallel wires
has one conductor inside the other
carries RF current on one wire only

Is made of two parallel wires is correct because balanced lines (like open-wire or twin-lead) have two identical conductors carrying equal and opposite currents. Memory Trick: “Balanced = twin parallels.”
Your antenna tuner does not have a balanced output and you wish to use window line to feed an HF antenna. What device should you use between the tuner and the transmission line?
Balun is correct because the tuner’s unbalanced output must be converted to a balanced feed for the window line. Memory Trick: Unbalanced tuner → balanced line = balun in between.
What kind of transmission line has two conductors maintained side by side, a constant distance apart, using insulated spreaders?

Open-wire line is correct because its two conductors are kept separated by small insulating spacers at intervals, with air as the main dielectric. Memory Trick: Open wires plus spreaders = classic open-wire line.
A transmission line must be supported for several metres by attaching it to a metal fence. What type of transmission line will NOT be adversely affected by proximity to the fence?

Coaxial cable is correct because its outer shield contains the RF fields, making it relatively immune to nearby metal objects, unlike balanced open lines which are easily detuned. Memory Trick: “Coax is shielded, so it tolerates metal.”
A common-mode current choke can be made by winding coaxial cable on a ferrite toroid. Why is cable with solid dielectric preferred over foam dielectric?
Less risk of a short due to centre conductor movement
Less impedance inserted in the signal path
More flexible and easier to handle

Less risk of a short due to centre conductor movement is correct because bending coax tightly around ferrite can deform foam dielectric and let the centre conductor drift toward the shield, causing failure; solid dielectric is mechanically more stable. Memory Trick: “Solid stays solid” under bending.
Why do most amateur radio antenna systems use coaxial cable, rather than other types of transmission line?
More usable in a wide variety of settings

More usable in a wide variety of settings is correct because coax is easy to route, can run near metal and through walls, and is mechanically robust, making it practical for many station layouts. Memory Trick: Coax = “convenient in cluttered places.”
What type of connector is commonly installed on RG-213 coaxial cable for connection to an HF transceiver?

A PL-259 connector is correct because it is the standard “UHF-type” plug used on most HF transceivers and commonly fitted to larger HF coax types such as RG-213. Memory Trick: Think “big HF coax, big PL-259.”
What type of connector usually joins a modern hand-held transceiver to its antenna?
An SMA connector is correct because compact SMA jacks are widely used on modern VHF/UHF hand-held radios where small size is important. Memory Trick: “Small radio, small SMA.”
Which popular RF connector is designed to be moisture resistant?

N is correct because Type N connectors were specifically designed for weather resistance and consistent 50-ohm performance at higher frequencies, making them suitable for outdoor use. Memory Trick: “N for ‘Nice in the rain’.”
What type of RF connector is commonly used for low-power transceivers and test instruments?

BNC is correct because BNC bayonet connectors are standard on many low-power radios, oscilloscopes, and RF test gear due to their quick-connect action and good high-frequency performance. Memory Trick: “Bench gear = BNC.”
Why should you regularly clean and tighten all antenna connectors?
To help keep their contact resistance at a minimum

To help keep their contact resistance at a minimum is correct because dirt, oxidation, or loose fittings increase resistance, causing heating, loss, and possible intermittent faults. Memory Trick: Bright, tight connectors = better signals.
What type of coaxial outer conductor offers the best shielding?

Solid shield is correct because a continuous metal tube provides the highest isolation from external RF fields. Braids and foil have gaps or imperfections that reduce shielding effectiveness. Memory Trick: “Solid = sealed = strongest shield.”
If your location is frequently affected by icing conditions, which type of transmission line would be the most suitable?

Coaxial cable is correct because ice buildup severely detunes and loads open-wire, twin-lead, and window line. Coax is enclosed and protected from environmental changes. Memory Trick: “Ice likes wires — but coax is inside a coat.”
What is the primary advantage of choosing a coaxial cable with a foam dielectric instead of a solid dielectric?

Lower loss is correct because foam dielectric has a lower dielectric constant, reducing RF loss. However, foam is less mechanically stable than solid dielectric. Memory Trick: “Foam = fluffy = fewer losses.”
What is the major adverse consequence of using RG-58 coaxial cable for a transmission line operating on the 70 cm band?
Excess reflections at the antenna feed point
Excess RF radiation from the transmission line
Excess RF loss in the transmission line

Excess RF loss is correct because RG-58 has significantly higher loss at UHF frequencies like 70 cm compared to larger-diameter coax such as RG-213. Memory Trick: “Small coax + high frequency = big loss.”
What is the major advantage of open-wire transmission line?
It can be operated at high SWR without excessive loss
It can be located near metal objects without problems
It has low impedance, which facilitates matching to a transceiver
It does not radiate RF energy
Open-wire line is extremely low loss, even with high SWR, unlike coax which suffers large losses when mismatched. Memory Trick: “Open-wire doesn’t care — SWR anywhere.”
If your transmitter and antenna are 15 metres apart, but are connected by 60 metres of RG-58 coaxial cable, what should be done to reduce transmission line loss?
Install a low-pass filter at the transceiver
Install a balun at the antenna feed point
Roll the excess cable into a coil

Shortening the excess cable is correct because transmission line loss is directly proportional to line length. Coiling the excess or adding components does nothing for loss. Memory Trick: “Shorter cable = stronger signal.”
As the length of a transmission line is changed, what happens to signal loss?
Signal loss is least when the line equals 1 wavelength
Signal loss is the same for any length
Signal loss increases as the length increases
Signal loss decreases as the length increases
Loss increases with length because more conductor and dielectric means more attenuation. Memory Trick: “More line = more loss.”
As the frequency of a signal is changed, what happens to signal loss in a transmission line?
Signal loss increases with decreasing frequency
Signal loss increases as the square of frequency
Signal loss is the same for any frequency
Signal loss increases with increasing frequency
Loss rises with frequency due to skin effect and dielectric loss. Memory Trick: “Higher frequency = higher friction.”
Assuming the same transmitter and RF output power are used, what is the effect of changing the transmission line from RG-213 coaxial cable to RG-58?
Less RF power is radiated from the antenna
More RF power is radiated from the antenna
Less power reaches the antenna because RG-58 has higher attenuation than RG-213. SWR is unchanged because mismatch is independent of coax type. Memory Trick: “Thinner cable = thinner signal.”
The lowest loss transmission line on HF is:
Open-wire has the lowest HF loss because most of its dielectric is air. Memory Trick: “Air is the best insulator — and the best at keeping loss low.”
In what values are RF transmission line losses expressed?
Transmission line loss is specified in dB per 100 ft, per metre, etc. Memory Trick: “Loss comes in dB — always.”
If the length of a coaxial transmission line is increased from 20 m to 40 m, how would this affect the line loss?
Doubling the line length doubles the loss — a 100% increase. Memory Trick: “Double the cable = double the loss.”
If the operating frequency is increased, how does the transmission line loss change?
Loss increases, due to internal line losses
Loss increases, due to increased wave velocity
Loss decreases, due to skin effect
Loss decreases, due to decreased SWR
Loss increases with frequency due to increased conductor and dielectric losses, especially from the skin effect. Memory Trick: “Higher frequency = hotter cable.”
What does an SWR reading of 1:1 mean?
The best impedance match has been attained
A 1:1 SWR means full match, with no reflected power. Memory Trick: “1:1 = perfect one-to-one.”
What does an SWR reading of less than 1.5:1 mean?
An impedance match that is too low
Less than 1.5:1 is considered acceptable on almost all amateur bands. Memory Trick: “Under 1.5 — you're alive.”
What is the most likely cause of erratic readings on an SWR meter?
Intermittent connection in the antenna system
Intermittent opens or shorts, especially in connectors, cause unstable readings. Memory Trick: “If SWR jumps, a connection bumps.”
Which of the following can cause a high SWR reading?
An open or short circuit in the antenna system
Grounding the shield at the building entrance
Using a very long transmission line
High SWR results from mismatch conditions like opens, shorts, or severe detuning. Memory Trick: “Open or short = SWR abort.”
What is the main adverse effect due to operating with high SWR?
High SWR creates large standing waves, increasing loss especially in coax. Memory Trick: “High SWR cooks coax.”
What instrument is useful in adjusting the physical length of an antenna?
An antenna analyzer shows SWR, resonance, and impedance while tuning antenna length. Memory Trick: “If you want to tune it — analyze it.”
If the characteristic impedance of the transmission line does not match the antenna input impedance then:
heat is produced at the junction
standing waves are produced in the transmission line
Mismatch causes reflections, creating standing waves along the line. Memory Trick: “Mismatch = waves standing like soldiers.”
The result of the presence of standing waves on a transmission line is:
reduced transfer of RF energy to the antenna
perfect impedance match between transmitter and transmission line
maximum transfer of energy to the antenna from the transmitter
lack of radiation from the transmission line

reduced transfer of RF energy to the antenna is correct because standing waves mean some of the power is being reflected back toward the transmitter instead of being delivered to the load. Memory Trick: “SWR standing tall = less power overall.”
What does an SWR meter measure to determine the SWR?
Forward and reflected voltage is correct because SWR is derived from the ratio of forward to reflected waves on the line. Memory Trick: “SWR cares about two voltages: forward vs. back.”
What information can be obtained with an antenna analyzer?
SWR of the antenna system over a range of frequencies

SWR of the antenna system over a range of frequencies is correct because an antenna analyzer sweeps frequency and shows where the system is well matched. Memory Trick: “Analyzer = SWR vs. frequency on a screen.”
What is the effect of line loss on the SWR reading at the station?
It decreases the SWR, because less power reaches the antenna
It has no effect, because SWR compares voltages
It has no effect, because forward and reflected power are both affected
It decreases the SWR, because reflected energy is attenuated

It decreases the SWR, because reflected energy is attenuated is correct: losses in the line eat part of the reflected wave before it returns to the meter, making the measured SWR look better than it really is. Memory Trick: “Loss hides reflections.”
Which of the following antenna system conditions will cause a modern solid-state HF transceiver to automatically reduce power?
Excessive impedance mismatch between transceiver and transmission line
Transmitting to a balanced antenna with an unbalanced transmission line
Open circuit in lightning surge protector ground connection
Excessive antenna element movement in high winds

Excessive impedance mismatch between transceiver and transmission line is correct because high SWR causes internal protection circuits to reduce power to protect the PA transistors. Memory Trick: “High SWR = radio backs off.”
What does an antenna tuner do?
It switches multiple transceivers to a common transmission line and antenna
It matches a transceiver to a mismatched antenna system
It helps a receiver automatically tune in stations that are far away
It switches an antenna system to a transmitter when sending, and to a receiver when listening

It matches a transceiver to a mismatched antenna system is correct because the tuner transforms impedance so the radio sees something close to 50 ohms. Memory Trick: “Tuner doesn’t tune the antenna — it tunes what the radio sees.”
An end-fed half-wave antenna (EFHW) has a very high feed point impedance. What device could be used to provide a good match to 50-ohm coaxial cable?
A good ground on the coax shield

A transformer is correct because an EFHW can have an impedance in the kilo-ohm range, and a step-down RF transformer can convert that high impedance to about 50 ohms. Memory Trick: “End-fed = extreme ohms = needs a transformer.”
If both source and load impedances are purely resistive, what value of load impedance will result in maximum power delivery to the load?
Load impedance equal to half of the source impedance
Load impedance equal to twice the source impedance
Load impedance equal to the square root of source impedance
Load impedance equal to the source impedance

Load impedance equal to the source impedance is correct because the maximum power transfer theorem says maximum power flows when source and load resistances are equal. Memory Trick: “Match R to R for max power.”
What is the advantage of locating an antenna tuner near the antenna feed point, over locating it near the transceiver?

Less transmission line loss is correct because the tuner transforms the mismatch right at the antenna, so the line between tuner and rig sees a near-perfect 50-ohm match and therefore less loss. Memory Trick: “Fix the mismatch first, then run the cable.”
How does an antenna tuner compensate for an impedance mismatch in an antenna system?
By adjusting the resonant frequency of the antenna
By adding capacitive or inductive reactance
By diverting reflections to a dummy load
By increasing the conductance of the transmission line

By adding capacitive or inductive reactance is correct because the tuner is essentially an adjustable LC network that transforms one impedance into another. Memory Trick: “Tuner = adjustable L and C.”
What advantage does a transformer present when used for impedance matching at radio frequencies?
It provides constant voltage to the load
It isolates the source from reflections
It can be designed to do so over a wide bandwidth
It supports larger power than reactive components

It can be designed to do so over a wide bandwidth is correct because broadband RF transformers can provide relatively flat matching over a large frequency range. Memory Trick: “Transformer = wideband match in one block.”
Where does impedance matching need to be done to minimize transmission line losses in an antenna system?
At the junction between the transmitter and the transmission line
At a quarter wavelength from the transmitter
At the junction between the transmission line and antenna

At the junction between the transmission line and antenna is correct because matching at the antenna prevents large standing waves (and extra loss) along the feed line. Memory Trick: “Match at the feedpoint, save the feedline.”
If an antenna is correctly matched to a transmission line, the length of the transmission line:
will have no effect on the matching
must be a full wavelength long
must be an odd number of quarter-wavelengths
must be an even number of half-wavelengths

Will have no effect on the matching is correct because with a perfect match, no standing waves exist and the impedance is the same at all points along a lossless line. Memory Trick: “Perfectly matched? Line length doesn’t matter.”
Why is an antenna tuner (external or internal) frequently used with modern solid-state transceivers?
It absorbs the reflected energy from a mismatched antenna system
It enables the transceivers to deliver rated power to a mismatched antenna system
It reduces losses in the line to the antenna

It enables the transceivers to deliver rated power is correct because the tuner “hides” mismatch from the radio, keeping SWR at the radio’s output low enough that protection circuits don’t reduce power. Memory Trick: “Tuner keeps the rig happy, even if the antenna isn’t.”
If a transmission line with a characteristic impedance of 50 ohms feeds a folded dipole with a feed point impedance close to 300 ohms, what impedance transformation ratio is needed to match the two?
6:1 is correct because 300 Ω ÷ 50 Ω = 6, so you need a 6:1 impedance step-down from antenna to line (or 1:6 step-up the other way). Memory Trick: “300 to 50 — divide by 6, nice and nifty.”
What does horizontal wave polarization mean?
The electric and magnetic lines of force of a radio wave are perpendicular to the Earth's surface
The electric lines of force of a radio wave are perpendicular to the Earth's surface
The magnetic lines of force of a radio wave are parallel to the Earth's surface
The electric lines of force of a radio wave are parallel to the Earth's surface

The electric lines of force parallel to the Earth's surface is correct because polarization is defined by the orientation of the electric field. Memory Trick: “Horizontal = E-field lying flat like the horizon.”
What does vertical wave polarization mean?
The electric lines of force of a radio wave are perpendicular to the Earth's surface
The magnetic lines of force of a radio wave are perpendicular to the Earth's surface
The electric and magnetic lines of force of a radio wave are parallel to the Earth's surface
The electric lines of force of a radio wave are parallel to the Earth's surface
The electric lines of force perpendicular to the Earth's surface is correct because again, polarization tracks the electric field. Memory Trick: “Vertical = E-field standing upright.”
What electromagnetic wave polarization does a Yagi antenna have when its elements are parallel to the Earth's surface?
Horizontal is correct because a Yagi’s polarization follows the orientation of its elements, which in this case are parallel to the ground. Memory Trick: “Elements lie flat = horizontal RF hat.”
What electromagnetic wave polarization does a half-wavelength antenna have when it is perpendicular to the Earth's surface?
Vertical is correct because a half-wave radiator standing straight up has its electric field oriented vertically. Memory Trick: “Whip standing tall = vertical for all.”
Polarization of an antenna is determined by:
the orientation of the electric field relative to the transmission line
the orientation of the magnetic field relative to the Earth's surface
the orientation of the electric field relative to the magnetic field
the orientation of the electric field relative to the Earth's surface

The orientation of the electric field relative to the Earth's surface is correct because by definition, polarization is referenced to the E-field, not the H-field. Memory Trick: “Polarization = position of the E-field.”
an infinitely long piece of wire

A hypothetical point source is correct because an isotropic radiator is an idealized antenna used as a reference for comparing gain. Memory Trick: Picture a perfect point glowing equally in all directions.
What is the three-dimensional radiation pattern of an isotropic radiator?
A sphere is correct because an isotropic radiator emits equally in all directions. Memory Trick: Think “isotropic = sphere-tropic.”
VHF signals from a mobile station using a vertical whip antenna will normally be best received using a:
A vertical ground-plane antenna is correct because polarization must match; VHF FM mobile communication uses vertical polarization. Memory Trick: “Vertical talks to vertical.”
A dipole antenna will emit a vertically polarized wave if it is:
Mounted vertically is correct because the antenna’s polarization follows its orientation. Memory Trick: “Antenna stands up → polarization stands up.”
If an electromagnetic wave leaves an antenna vertically polarized and reaches the receiving location by ground wave, what will be its final polarization?
Vertical is correct because ground-wave propagation preserves polarization. Memory Trick: “Ground wave keeps things as they began.”
Compared with a horizontal antenna, a vertical antenna will receive a vertically polarized radio wave:
at a strength depending on the height above ground
At higher strength is correct because maximum signal transfer occurs when transmit and receive polarizations match. Memory Trick: “Match = maximum.”
A wire dipole has a resonant frequency of 3900 kHz. How can you change its resonant frequency to 3600 kHz?
Make it longer is correct because a longer antenna resonates at a lower frequency. Memory Trick: “Longer wire = lower choir.”
A wire dipole has a resonant frequency of 3600 kHz. How can you change its resonant frequency to 3900 kHz?
Make it shorter is correct because shortening the antenna raises its resonant frequency. Memory Trick: “Shorter wire = higher choir.”
What is the wavelength in free space of a 25 MHz signal?
12 metres is correct using λ = 300 / f(MHz). Memory Trick: Think “300 rule”: 300 / 25 ≈ 12.
The velocity of propagation of radio frequency energy in free space is:
300 000 km/s is the speed of light, which is also the speed of RF in free space. Memory Trick: RF rides on light-speed rails.
Adding a series inductance to an antenna would:
Decrease the resonant frequency is correct because inductance makes the antenna behave electrically longer. Memory Trick: “Add L → lower f.”
The resonant frequency of an antenna may be increased by:
increasing the height of the radiating element
Shortening the antenna raises its natural resonant frequency. Memory Trick: “Short = sharp (higher pitch).”
The speed of a radio wave:
is the same as the speed of light
is less than half the speed of light
RF waves in free space travel at the speed of light. Memory Trick: “RF *is* light, just invisible.”
Why are insulators used at the ends of a suspended wire antenna?
To reduce capacitive coupling with the ground
To limit the electrical length of the antenna
To decrease the effective antenna length
To limit the electrical length is correct because the insulator prevents the wire from coupling electrically into the supporting structure. Memory Trick: “Insulators isolate the ends.”
To lower the resonant frequency of an antenna, the operator should:
Lengthen it is correct because a longer antenna resonates lower. Memory Trick: “Lower freq = longer wire.”
Some antennas are constructed with traps. What is a trap?
A coil wrapped around a ferrite rod
A coil and capacitor in parallel
A coil and capacitor in parallel is correct because a trap is a parallel LC circuit that blocks (resonates at) a specific frequency. Memory Trick: “Trap = tuned LC stop.”
What is the wavelength in free space of a 2 MHz signal?
150 metres is correct using λ = 300 / f(MHz). Memory Trick: 300 / 2 = 150.
How is a parasitic antenna element energized?
By inductive coupling from a wave trap
By induction or radiation from a driven element
By direct connection to a driven element
By direct connection to the transmission line
By induction or radiation from a driven element is correct because parasitic elements re-radiate energy without being directly fed. Memory Trick: “Parasitic = passive but powered by proximity.”
How can the directivity of a half-wave dipole be increased?
By adding traps to the radiating element
By adding one or more parasitic elements
By using a radiating element with a larger diameter
Adding parasitic elements forms a Yagi, increasing directional gain. Memory Trick: “Add neighbors → stronger beam.”
If a half-wave dipole is converted to a Yagi by adding a slightly shorter parasitic element, in what direction(s) does the radiation strength increase?
From the new element towards the dipole
In both directions at right angles to the elements
In both directions parallel to the elements
From the dipole towards the new element
Radiation increases toward the director (the shorter parasitic element). Memory Trick: “Shorter element = director → points the beam.”
If a half-wave dipole is converted to a Yagi by adding a slightly longer element, in what direction(s) does the radiation strength increase?
From the new element towards the dipole
From the dipole towards the new element
In both directions at right angles to the elements
In both directions parallel to the elements

From the new element towards the dipole is correct because the longer added element acts as a reflector, so the main lobe is directed from the reflector (new element) toward the driven element. Memory Trick: Think "reflector behind, beam in front."
The property of an antenna that defines the range of frequencies to which it will respond, is called its:
Bandwidth is correct because it is the frequency range over which the antenna performs acceptably (good match and pattern). Memory Trick: Bandwidth = "band of usable width" in frequency.
What is the approximate gain of a half-wave dipole in free space relative to an isotropic radiator?
2.1 dB is correct because a half-wave dipole concentrates energy broadside compared to an isotropic point source, giving about 2.1 dB of gain. Memory Trick: Remember "dipole over iso" ≈ 2 dB.
What is meant by antenna gain?
The ratio of the signal in the forward direction to the signal in the back direction
The ratio of the power radiated by an antenna compared to the transmitter power
The power amplifier gain minus the transmission line losses
The ratio of the radiated signal strength of an antenna to that of a reference antenna

The ratio of the radiated signal strength of an antenna to that of a reference antenna is correct because gain always compares an antenna to a standard (isotropic or dipole). Memory Trick: Gain is always "this antenna vs reference antenna."
What is meant by antenna bandwidth?
The frequency range over which the antenna may be expected to perform well
Antenna length divided by the number of elements
The angle between the half-power radiation points
The angle formed between two imaginary lines drawn through the ends of the elements

The frequency range over which the antenna may be expected to perform well is correct because bandwidth describes the useful frequency span for good SWR and pattern. Memory Trick: Bandwidth = "how wide in frequency the antenna behaves nicely."
In free space, what is the radiation pattern of a half-wave dipole?
Maximum radiation broadside from the antenna
Maximum radiation from the ends of the antenna

Maximum radiation broadside from the antenna is correct because a dipole has nulls off the ends and strongest field at right angles. Memory Trick: Stand at the side of the dipole, not at the tip, to get max signal.
The gain of an antenna, especially on VHF and above, is quoted in dBi. The "i" in this expression stands for:
Isotropic is correct because dBi means gain compared to an ideal isotropic (equal in all directions) radiator. Memory Trick: "i" = isotropic.
An antenna is said to have a gain of 4.1 dBi. How much gain is this over a half-wave dipole antenna?
2.0 dB is correct because a dipole has about 2.1 dBi, so 4.1 dBi − 2.1 dBi ≈ 2 dB more than a dipole. Memory Trick: Subtract "dipole 2 dB" from the dBi number to get gain over a dipole.
How do you calculate the approximate length in metres of a quarter-wavelength antenna for use on frequencies below 30 MHz?
Divide 71.3 by the operating frequency in MHz
Divide 468 by the operating frequency in MHz
Divide 300 by the operating frequency in MHz
Divide 143 by the operating frequency in MHz

Divide 71.3 by the operating frequency in MHz is correct because 71.3 is approximately 300 divided by 4, adjusted for practical factors, giving the quarter-wave length in metres. Memory Trick: For a quarter-wave in metres, use "71.3 over f."
If you made a quarter-wavelength vertical antenna for 21.125 MHz, approximately how long would it be?
3.37 metres is correct using the quarter-wave formula: 71.3 / 21.125 ≈ 3.37 m. Memory Trick: Plug into L = 71.3 / f and round to two decimals.
If you made a half-wavelength vertical antenna for 223 MHz, approximately how long would it be?
67 cm is correct because a half-wave length is about 150 / f(MHz): 150 / 223 ≈ 0.67 m, i.e. 67 cm. Memory Trick: For half-wave in metres, use "150 over f."
Why is a five-eighths wavelength vertical antenna better than a quarter-wavelength vertical antenna for VHF or UHF mobile operations?
Because it has a high radiation angle
Because it does not require impedance matching
Because it can handle more power

Because it has more gain is correct because a 5/8-wave vertical squashes the radiation pattern lower toward the horizon, increasing useful gain for mobile work. Memory Trick: "Five-eighths = flatter, farther."
If a quarter-wavelength vertical antenna is placed on the roof of a car, in what direction does it send out radio energy?
It goes out equally well in all horizontal directions
Most of it goes vertically straight-up
Most of it goes equally in two opposite directions
Most of it goes in one direction

It goes out equally well in all horizontal directions is correct because the car roof acts as a ground plane, giving an almost omnidirectional horizontal pattern. Memory Trick: Think "mobile whip = doughnut around the car."
What is an advantage of downward sloping radials on a ground plane antenna?
It brings the feed point impedance closer to 50 ohms
It brings the feed point impedance closer to 300 ohms

It brings the feed point impedance closer to 50 ohms is correct because sloping the radials down raises the feedpoint impedance from about 36 ohms toward 50 ohms. Memory Trick: "Tip the radials down, bring the match up."
What configuration of radials will match an elevated quarter-wave vertical antenna to a 50-ohm coaxial cable?
Downward sloping quarter-wave radials is correct because this configuration gives a feedpoint impedance close to 50 ohms, matching common coax. Memory Trick: "Quarter-wave down for 50-ohm crown."
Which of the following transmission lines will give the best match to the base of a quarter-wave ground-plane antenna?
50-ohm coaxial cable is correct because the base impedance of a properly built quarter-wave ground plane is close to 50 ohms. Memory Trick: Quarter-wave ground plane loves 50-ohm coax.
How can a vertical antenna, 2 metres in length, be made to resonate in the 80-metre band for mobile use?
Install an inductor in series with the antenna
Use a solid radiating element instead of tubing
Install a capacitor in series with the antenna
Connect the transmission line shield to the vehicle's chassis

Install an inductor in series with the antenna is correct because the vertical is much shorter than a quarter-wave on 80 m and needs inductive loading to cancel its capacitive reactance. Memory Trick: Short HF mobile whip = add coil in series.
Why is a loading coil often used with an HF mobile vertical antenna?
To tune out capacitive reactance is correct because a short vertical looks capacitive; the coil adds inductance to bring it to resonance. Memory Trick: "Coil cancels cap" on short mobile whips.
When using a ground mounted vertical HF antenna, what can you do to reduce ground losses?
Improve the impedance match at the base
Raise the antenna one eighth of a wavelength
Install a wire ground system (radials) at the antenna base
Use an insulator with a higher breakdown voltage

Install a wire ground system (radials) at the antenna base is correct because radials provide a low-loss return path for currents, reducing ground resistance. Memory Trick: "More radials, less losses."
What design feature allows a single Yagi antenna to function on the 20-metre, 15-metre and 10-metre bands?

Element traps is correct because parallel LC traps in the elements isolate parts of the elements at higher bands, letting one physical antenna resonate on several HF bands. Memory Trick: "Traps = tune one boom for many bands."
What is the approximate length of the driven element of a Yagi antenna for 14.0 MHz?

10.21 metres is correct because a half-wave in free space at 14 MHz is about 10.7 metres, and a Yagi driven element is normally made slightly shorter than a half-wave to resonate properly. Memory Trick: Use "150 / f (MHz)" for half-wave in metres, then think "a bit shorter" for a Yagi driven element.
What is the approximate length of the director element of a Yagi antenna for 21.1 MHz?

6.44 metres is correct because a half-wave at 21.1 MHz is about 7.1 metres, and a director is made slightly shorter than the driven element to direct the beam. Memory Trick: Think "director = shorter than half-wave to point the beam."
What is the approximate length of the reflector element of a Yagi antenna for 28.1 MHz?

5.34 metres is correct because a half-wave at 28.1 MHz is about 5.3 metres, and a reflector is usually about a half-wave, often slightly longer than the driven element to reflect energy. Memory Trick: "Reflector = about 1/2 wavelength, a little longer than the driven element."
What is one effect of increasing the boom length and adding directors to a Yagi antenna?

Gain increases is correct because more directors and a longer boom concentrate more energy in one main lobe, increasing forward gain. Memory Trick: "More directors on a longer boom = more punch in one direction."
What is the major advantage of increasing element spacing on a Yagi antenna?

Higher gain is correct because, up to a point, increasing element spacing helps form a narrower main lobe, which increases forward gain. Memory Trick: "Spread the elements a bit, squeeze the beam, gain goes up."
Why are Yagi antennas often used on HF bands from 20 metres to 10 metres?
Their high angle of radiation facilitates long-range communications
Rotatable high-gain antennas become feasible due to shorter element lengths
Excellent omnidirectional coverage in the horizontal plane
Their wide bandwidth provides a good match over an entire band

Rotatable high-gain antennas become feasible due to shorter element lengths is correct because elements are physically small enough on 20 to 10 metres to put several on a boom and rotate the whole array. Memory Trick: "Shorter HF bands = shorter elements = practical rotatable Yagis."
What does "antenna front-to-back ratio" mean in reference to a Yagi antenna?
The ratio of the length of the director element, to the length of the reflector element
The ratio of the driven element-to-director spacing, to the driven element-to-reflector spacing
The ratio of the power radiated in the forward direction to the power radiated in the opposite direction
The ratio of the power radiated by the director element, to the power radiated by the reflector element

The ratio of the power radiated in the forward direction to the power radiated in the opposite direction is correct because front-to-back describes how much stronger the main lobe is compared to the lobe behind the antenna. Memory Trick: "Front-to-back = forward power divided by backward power."
How can the bandwidth of a Yagi antenna be increased?
Install loading coils in the elements
Increase the diameter of the elements
Increase the diameter of the elements is correct because thicker elements have lower Q and therefore a wider usable frequency range. Memory Trick: "Fat elements = fatter bandwidth."
For a three-element Yagi antenna, what approximate element spacing (in wavelengths) provides the best compromise between gain and front-to-back ratio?

0.20 is correct because about 0.2 wavelengths spacing between elements is a common design compromise that gives good forward gain and reasonable front-to-back ratio. Memory Trick: "Three element Yagi sweet spot: about 0.2 lambda spacing."
If the forward gain of a six-element Yagi is about 10 dBi, what would the gain of two of these antennas be if they were "stacked"?

13 dBi is correct because stacking two identical antennas ideally adds about 3 dB of gain, which doubles the effective power in the main lobe. 10 dBi plus 3 dB gives 13 dBi. Memory Trick: "Two identical antennas = plus 3 dB."
If you made a half-wavelength dipole antenna for 28.150 MHz, approximately how long would it be?
5.08 metres is correct because the usual dipole formula in metres is 143 divided by the frequency in MHz: 143 / 28.15 is about 5.1 metres. Memory Trick: "For dipoles in metres, remember 143 / f."
What is one disadvantage of a random wire antenna?
It usually produces vertically polarized radiation
It must be longer than 1 wavelength
It must be installed in a straight line, without bends
You may experience RF feedback in your station

You may experience RF feedback in your station is correct because random wires can have high RF voltage on the feedline and equipment, causing RF to appear on the rig and microphone. Memory Trick: "Random wire can put random RF where you do not want it."
What is the three-dimensional radiation pattern of a half-wavelength dipole in free space?
A torus (donut shape) around the antenna
A major lobe off each end of the antenna
Major lobes at 45-degree angles to the antenna

A torus (donut shape) around the antenna is correct because a horizontal dipole in free space radiates strongest broadside, forming a donut-shaped pattern around the wire. Memory Trick: Picture the dipole as the "hole" in a donut of RF.
What is the impedance at the feed point of a half-wave dipole in free space?

73 ohms is correct because theory and measurements show that a thin, half-wave dipole in free space has a feed point resistance of about 73 ohms. Memory Trick: "Half-wave dipole in free space: about 73 ohms, close to 75-ohm line."
Ignoring ground effects, what is the radiation pattern of a horizontal half-wave dipole installed with the ends pointing North/South?
Radiates mostly to the East and West
Radiates mostly to the South and North

Which ionospheric region is closest to the Earth?

Which region of the ionosphere separates into two sub-regions in the daytime?
