They are completely absorbed by the ionosphere

They are bent back to the Earth is correct because as long as the frequency is below MUF (and above the lower usable frequency for that path), the ionosphere refracts the wave enough for it to return to Earth. Frequencies above MUF tend to pass through. Memory Trick: “Below MUF? It comes back. Above MUF? It goes out.”
At what point in the solar cycle does the 20-metre band usually support worldwide propagation during daylight hours?
Only at the maximum point of the solar cycle
At the beginning of the solar cycle
At any point in the solar cycle
Only at the minimum point of the solar cycle

At any point in the solar cycle is correct for exam purposes because 20 m is a “workhorse” HF band: even at solar minimum it often still supports long-distance daylight paths somewhere in the world, and at solar maximum it becomes even better. The other answers limit 20-m usefulness too much. Memory Trick: Think “20 m = 24/7/365 workhorse,” usable throughout the whole cycle.
What happens daily when the solar UV radiation increases?

The maximum usable frequency increases is correct because stronger UV radiation means more ionization, which allows higher frequencies to be bent back to Earth. The other options are not the primary direct effect of increased solar UV on HF propagation. Memory Trick: “More UV → more ions → higher MUF.”
When is propagation on the 80-metre band generally the LEAST effective?

Daytime in summer is correct because 80 m suffers heavy D-layer absorption in the day, and this is worst when the days are longest and the Sun is highest (summer). Evenings and winter nights typically give much better 80-m conditions. Memory Trick: “80 m hates hot, bright days.”
The optimum working frequency provides the best long-range HF communication. Compared with the maximum usable frequency (MUF), it is usually:

Slightly lower is correct because using a frequency just below MUF gives more reliable, stable communications with less fading and fewer dropouts than operating right at the limit. Values like 0.8–0.9 × MUF are often used as a rule of thumb. Memory Trick: “Aim just under the ceiling: OWF = MUF minus a little.”
During summer daytime, which bands are the most difficult for communications beyond ground wave?

160 metres and 80 metres is correct because strong D-layer absorption during long, bright summer days greatly attenuates low-frequency HF sky waves, leaving mostly ground-wave coverage. Higher bands can still refract via E or F regions. Memory Trick: “Lowest bands lose most in summer sun.”
Which ionospheric region most affects sky-wave propagation on the 6-metre band?

The E region is correct because on 6 m, notable long-distance sky-wave propagation is often due to sporadic-E, where dense patches of ionization in the E layer reflect VHF signals. F-layer propagation on 6 m happens but is less common; D-layer mainly absorbs, not refracts. Memory Trick: “Six metres loves Es—E layer, especially sporadic-E.”
What effect does tropospheric bending have on 2-metre radio waves?
It lets you contact stations farther away
It causes them to travel shorter distances

It lets you contact stations farther away is correct because slight bending or “ducting” in the troposphere can extend the radio horizon beyond simple line-of-sight, giving unusually long VHF paths. While there can be some distortion, the key exam idea is extended range. Memory Trick: “Tropo bend = bonus distance.”
What causes tropospheric ducting of radio waves?
Lightning between the transmitting and receiving stations

A temperature inversion is correct because layers of warm air above cooler air create sharp changes in refractive index that can trap VHF/UHF signals and guide them over long distances, like a “duct.” Lightning and auroras are unrelated mechanisms. Memory Trick: “Warm-over-cold air = radio duct.”
What term describes that portion of a transmitted wave kept close to the Earth's surface due to bending in the atmosphere?

Tropospheric wave is correct because this refers to VHF/UHF signals that follow Earth’s surface via refraction in the lower atmosphere (the troposphere). “Ground wave” in HF usually refers to surface/ground-hugging propagation from the antenna, not specifically bending by the troposphere. Memory Trick: “Near-surface but air-bent at VHF = tropospheric wave.”
Occasional duct formation in the E region
Variations in E-region height caused by sunspot variations
A brief decrease in VHF signals caused by sunspot variations
Patches of dense ionization at E-region height

Patches of dense ionization at E-region height is correct because sporadic-E occurs when irregular, highly ionized “clouds” form in the E layer, reflecting HF and lower-VHF signals over long distances on otherwise “dead” bands. The other answers confuse it with ducts or sunspot effects. Memory Trick: “Sporadic-E = surprise ionized patches in the E layer.”
On which amateur radio band is the extended-distance propagation effect of sporadic-E most often observed?

6 metres is correct because sporadic-E often creates dramatic “openings” on the low-VHF range, especially around 50 MHz. HF bands like 20 metres are usually dominated by F-layer propagation, and 160 metres is too low in frequency for typical sporadic-E effects. Memory Trick: Think “Sporadic-E = Summer Six Metres.”
In the northern hemisphere, in which direction should a directional antenna be pointed to take maximum advantage of auroral propagation?

North is correct because auroral propagation occurs in the auroral zone around the geomagnetic poles. From most locations in the northern hemisphere, that lies to the north, so you point your beam toward the aurora. Memory Trick: “Aurora = Northern Lights = point the beam north.”
Where in the ionosphere does auroral activity occur?

At E-region height is correct because auroral emissions and related radio effects occur mainly in the E region, roughly 90–150 km up. The F region is higher, and the D region is lower and mainly associated with absorption, not aurora. Memory Trick: “Aurora and E both sit in the middle of the alphabet: A–D–E–F.”
Which analog emission mode is the most reliable in auroral propagation?
FM, because it is readable even when distorted
CW, because it is readable even when distorted

CW, because it is readable even when distorted is correct since auroral signals are often rough, hissy, and severely distorted. A simple on/off Morse signal is still recognizable through that distortion, whereas voice or FM can become unintelligible. Memory Trick: “When signals get ugly in the aurora, CW still cuts through.”
Excluding enhanced propagation modes, what is the approximate range of normal VHF tropospheric propagation?

800 km is correct as a typical upper limit for extended but still “normal” tropospheric propagation at VHF. Longer paths usually require special modes such as strong ducting or other enhancements. Memory Trick: Think of “VHF normal limit” as “about 800 km or so” before you start suspecting special conditions.
What effect is responsible for propagating a VHF signal over 800 km?

Tropospheric ducting is correct because unusual temperature and humidity layers in the lower atmosphere can trap and guide VHF signals far beyond the normal radio horizon, often out to 800 km or more. Faraday rotation affects polarization, and D-region or ionospheric refraction is mainly an HF phenomenon. Memory Trick: “Super-long VHF over water or temperature inversions? That’s a duct.”
What kind of unusual HF propagation allows weak signals from the skip zone to be heard?

Scatter-mode is correct because some of the transmitted energy is scattered in many directions by irregularities in the ionosphere or atmosphere, letting a small amount fall into the skip zone—an area normally silent between ground wave and first sky-wave hop. Memory Trick: “Skip zone sound? Think scattered around.”
If you receive a weak, distorted signal close to the maximum usable frequency, what type of propagation is probably occurring?

Scatter is correct because near the MUF, normal F-layer refraction is marginal and more of the energy is scattered. That scattered component tends to sound weak, fluttery, and distorted. Ground wave and line-of-sight are typically stronger and cleaner. Memory Trick: “Near MUF + weak and rough = scatter stuff.”
What type of VHF/UHF propagation depends upon small variations in density and water-vapour content?

Tropospheric scatter is correct because tiny irregularities in the lower atmosphere’s density and humidity cause a small fraction of the signal to scatter in many directions, enabling weak but reliable beyond-horizon VHF/UHF paths. Ducting uses more pronounced layers; sporadic-E and ionospheric scatter happen much higher. Memory Trick: “Tiny tropo ripples = tiny scattered signals.”
What makes HF scatter signals often sound distorted?
The state of the E-region at the point of refraction
Energy scattered into the skip zone through several radio-wave paths
Auroral activity and changes in the Earth's magnetic field
Propagation through ground waves that absorb much of the signal

Energy scattered into the skip zone through several radio-wave paths is correct because multiple scattered paths with slightly different delays combine at the receiver, causing phase distortion, flutter, and a “burbling” sound. Memory Trick: “Many tiny paths, many tiny delays = messy audio.”
Why are HF scatter signals usually weak?
The F region of the ionosphere absorbs most of the signal energy
Auroral activity absorbs most of the signal energy
Only a small part of the signal energy is scattered into the skip zone
Propagation through ground waves absorbs most of the signal energy

Only a small part of the signal energy is scattered into the skip zone is correct because most of the transmitted power keeps going on the main paths; only a tiny fraction is deflected to serve the skip zone, so received signals are weak. Memory Trick: “Scatter is scraps—only scraps of power reach you.”
What type of propagation may allow a weak high frequency (HF) signal to be heard at a distance too far for ground-wave propagation but too near for normal sky-wave propagation?

Scatter is correct because this specific situation (inside the normal skip zone) is classic HF scatter territory. Short-path skip and sporadic-E are still forms of sky-wave and typically leave a skip zone; tropo scatter mainly affects VHF/UHF. Memory Trick: “If you’re in the skip hole but still hear something, think scatter.”
On the HF bands, when is scatter propagation most likely involved?
When you receive weak and distorted signals near the maximum usable frequency (MUF)
When the sunspot cycle is at a minimum and D-region absorption is high
At night when propagation is poor
When the F1 and F2 regions are combined

When you receive weak and distorted signals near the maximum usable frequency (MUF) is correct because that’s when normal refraction is failing and scattered components dominate, giving the classic “thin, rough” scatter sound. Memory Trick: “Near MUF + ugly audio = scatter at work.”
Tropospheric scatter frequently explains VHF/UHF communications well beyond the radio horizon. What makes this propagation mode possible?
Small variations in the properties of the lower atmosphere
Increased daytime ionization of the D region

Small variations in the properties of the lower atmosphere is correct because tiny fluctuations in refractive index—caused by temperature and humidity variations—scatter a little of the signal forward, allowing beyond-line-of-sight reception. Memory Trick: “Slightly lumpy air gives slightly stretched range.”
Meteor scatter is most effective on what band?

6 metres is correct because meteor trails are especially effective at reflecting low-VHF signals around 50 MHz. HF bands like 40 and 15 metres usually use normal ionospheric propagation; 160 metres is far too low in frequency for classic meteor-scatter modes. Memory Trick: “Meteors + Magic = 6-metre pings.”
What is the effect of scattering on a radio wave?
A portion of the wave abruptly changes direction
The wave is absorbed by the medium
The wave gets redirected in many directions

The wave gets redirected in many directions is correct because scattering breaks up the original beam into many weaker components going off at different angles. Gradual bending is refraction, abrupt single changes are reflection, and absorption simply removes energy. Memory Trick: “Scatter = shatter the beam into many pieces.”
In which frequency range is meteor scatter most effective for extended-range communication?

30 MHz to 100 MHz is correct because meteor trails ionize strongly enough and have suitable lifetimes to reflect signals in the low-VHF region. Below this range, normal ionospheric propagation tends to dominate; above it, the trails are often too small or short-lived to be useful. Memory Trick: “Meteor sweet spot = low VHF window.”
What is the cause of receiver overload?
Very strong signal from a transmitter

Very strong signal from a transmitter is correct because overload happens when a signal is so strong it drives the front end or IF stages of the receiver beyond their linear range, causing distortion and spurious responses. Instability, oscillations, or overmodulation may cause other issues but not overload by themselves. Memory Trick: “Too big a signal = receiver says ‘I can’t handle it.’”
What is one way to tell if your HF transmitter causes front-end overload interference to a neighbour's receiver?
Interference is heard regardless of the volume setting on the receiver
Adding a low-pass filter at the transmitter solves the problem
Transmitting on various frequencies produces similar interference
Adding receiver shielding has no effect

Transmitting on various frequencies produces similar interference is correct because overload is mostly about signal strength, not your exact transmit frequency. If changing bands doesn’t change the interference much, it points to the neighbour’s receiver front end being swamped. Memory Trick: “If every band breaks their gear, it’s overload, not ‘bad band.’”
If a neighbour reports television interference whenever you transmit, no matter what band you use, what is probably the cause of the interference?

Receiver overload is correct because if every band causes interference, the neighbour’s TV front end is probably being driven too hard by your strong RF signal. Harmonics or spurious signals are usually more frequency-specific. Memory Trick: “All bands, same problem = their receiver is overloaded.”
What type of filter should be connected to a TV receiver as the first step in trying to prevent receiver overload from an amateur radio HF transmission?

High-pass is correct because a TV uses VHF/UHF, which are much higher in frequency than HF. A high-pass filter at the TV input attenuates the strong HF signal while passing the wanted TV channels. A low-pass would do the opposite, a band-pass would be too narrow and band-specific, and an AC line filter only affects mains power, not RF on the antenna input. Memory Trick: “TV lives high — protect it with high-pass.”
During a club Field Day outing, reception on the 20-metre SSB station is compromised every time the 20-metre CW station is on the air. What might cause such interference?
Both stations are fed from the same generator

Receiver desensitization is correct because the very strong nearby CW signal is overloading the front end of the SSB receiver on the same band, reducing its sensitivity to weaker signals. Sharing a generator or imperfect grounding might cause hum or noise, not this “goes deaf when the other station transmits” effect. Harmonics would show up on other bands, not mainly the same one. Memory Trick: “Strong neighbour on same band = your receiver gets ‘deaf’ (desensed).”
The signals from two commercial transmitters combine outside your receiver to produce noise on a desired frequency. What type of interference is this?

Intermodulation is correct because two (or more) strong signals are mixing in a nonlinear device (often in the receiver front end or nearby metalwork), creating new “combo” frequencies that fall on your desired channel. Spurious and harmonic emissions refer to unwanted outputs from a single transmitter. Overload is just “too much signal,” but here the key is mixing. Memory Trick: Think “IMD = ‘I Mix Distortion.’”

You have connected your hand-held VHF transceiver to an outside gain antenna. You now hear a mixture of signals together with different modulation on your desired frequency. What is the nature of this interference?

Receiver intermodulation is correct because the external gain antenna is overloading the radio’s front end with many strong signals. These mix together in the RF stages and create extra signals on your receive frequency. Harmonics are multiples of a single transmitter’s frequency, and audio-stage problems don’t normally create new RF frequencies. Memory Trick: “Big antenna + crowded band = IMD inside the receiver.”
Two or more strong signals mix in your receiver to produce interference on a desired frequency. What is this called?

Intermodulation interference is correct because multiple strong signals are mixing in a nonlinear stage (like the RF amplifier or mixer), creating new, unwanted signals. Harmonic interference comes from multiples of a single signal, capture effect is an FM phenomenon where the strongest signal wins, and desensitization is loss of sensitivity rather than creation of new frequencies. Memory Trick: “When strong signals inter-mix, think intermodulation.”
Two mobile stations are communicating through a repeater. As they arrive in close proximity to each other, they begin to have difficulty communicating. What is the most likely cause?
Transmitter signals are mixing with the repeater signal to cause intermodulation
Transmitter signals are desensitizing the receivers
CTCSS tones are activating the receivers' squelch circuits
They have entered a null area of their antenna patterns

Transmitter signals are desensitizing the receivers is correct because as the mobiles get close, their transmit signals can be very strong at each other’s receiver, overloading or desensing them, especially in duplex/repeater use. CTCSS issues affect access to the repeater, not local desense. Antenna nulls are possible but less likely in this specific “very close together” scenario, and mixing with the repeater signal is a more complex case than needed here. Memory Trick: “Too-close mobiles = too-much signal = desense.”

A television receiver suffers interference on channel 5 (76 MHz - 82 MHz) only when you transmit on 14 MHz. From your home you see the tower of a commercial FM station known to broadcast on 92.5 MHz. Which of these solutions would you try first?
Insert a high-pass filter at the HF transmitter
Insert a low-pass filter at the television receiver
Insert a high-pass filter at the television receiver
Insert a low-pass filter at the HF transmitter

Insert a high-pass filter at the television receiver is correct because it will attenuate your 14 MHz HF signal while passing the VHF TV and FM broadcast signals. The problem is likely intermodulation in the TV front end between your HF and the strong local FM station. A high-pass at your transmitter doesn’t protect the TV; a low-pass at the TV would pass HF and reject TV signals—the opposite of what you want. Memory Trick: “TV uses high frequencies, so protect it with high-pass.”

You are experiencing interference in your VHF receiver. You have determined that signals from two nearby transmitters are mixing in your receiver to cause the interference. What device can you install to reduce the interference?

Suitable filter at the receiver is correct because by limiting the range of frequencies reaching your front end (for example with a band-pass filter for just your band), you keep out one or both of the strong off-channel signals that are causing intermodulation. A common-mode choke fixes RF on cables, an attenuator just weakens everything, and an IF filter works at the intermediate frequency, after the unwanted mixing has often already happened. Memory Trick: “Prevent IMD at the front door with front-end filtering.”
What devices would you install to reduce or eliminate interference to a home entertainment system from an HF transmitter?

Coils on ferrite cores is correct because ferrite chokes on power, speaker, and interconnect leads act as RF filters, blocking HF currents from entering audio/video equipment. Bypass resistors or inductors are not standard RFI cures in this context, and MOVs protect against surges, not RF ingress. Memory Trick: “Clamp-on ferrite = clamp down the RF.”
What should be done if a properly operating amateur radio station is the cause of interference to a nearby telephone?
Make internal adjustments to the telephone equipment
Install a modular plug-in telephone RFI filter close to the telephone device
Ground and shield the telephone distribution amplifier
Stop transmitting whenever the telephone is in use

Install a modular plug-in telephone RFI filter close to the telephone device is correct because these filters are designed to keep RF out of the phone circuitry, solving the problem at the victim device. Grounding/shielding distribution amps is more complex and may not apply, you’re not required to stop transmitting if you are operating properly, and you should not alter someone else’s telephone internals. Memory Trick: “For phone RFI, plug in a phone RFI filter.”
What sound is heard from a public address system if audio rectification of a nearby single-sideband transmission occurs?
Distorted speech from the transmitter's signals
Clearly audible speech from the transmitter's signals

Distorted speech from the transmitter's signals is correct because the PA’s non-linear components are acting like a crude detector, turning RF into audio but with poor fidelity, so SSB speech sounds garbled or harsh. Clear speech would require a proper receiver, and hums or clicks are more typical of CW or power issues. Memory Trick: “SSB into audio gear = scrambled ghost voice in the speakers.”
What sound is heard from a public address system if audio rectification of a nearby CW transmission occurs?

On-and-off humming or clicking is correct because CW is keyed on and off, so rectified RF becomes bursts of tone or clicks that follow the keying pattern. There is no speech content to be heard. Memory Trick: “CW in audio gear = clicks or buzz in code rhythm.”
If an amateur radio transmission is heard in a device that contains no RF components, what type of interference is this?

Audio rectification is correct because strong RF is being picked up by wiring and non-linear junctions inside the device (like diodes or transistor inputs), which then act like a detector and produce audio. There is no RF front end to “overload,” and splatter/intermodulation are RF-stage phenomena. Memory Trick: “No tuner, no RF stages, but you hear radio = audio circuits are rectifying RF.”
An amateur radio transmitter is being heard across the entire dial of a broadcast receiver. The receiver is most probably suffering from:

audio rectification is correct because if you hear the amateur signal everywhere on the dial, the RF is getting into the audio or detector stages directly, bypassing the tuned RF stages. Harmonics or images would appear on specific frequencies, not the whole dial, and splatter still stays near the transmit frequency. Memory Trick: “All over the dial usually means the dial is being bypassed (rectification).”
Your SSB HF transmissions are heard muffled on a sound system in the living room regardless of its volume setting. What causes this?

Audio rectification of strong signals is correct because the sound system is not a receiver, but strong RF is being detected in its input or amplifier stages. The fact that the effect is independent of the volume control is a key clue: the RF is entering after the volume control. Harmonics or filtering issues would mainly matter to radios, not to a hi-fi amp. Memory Trick: “If the volume knob doesn’t affect the ‘radio’ sound, it’s rectification past the knob.”
What device can be used to minimize the effect of RF pickup by audio wires connected to stereo speakers, intercom amplifiers, telephones, etc.?

Coil on ferrite core is correct because ferrite chokes on audio leads present a high impedance to RF while passing audio, greatly reducing RF pickup. High-pass filters, attenuators, and surge suppressors are not the standard cure for RF on low-frequency audio wiring. Memory Trick: “Ferrite beads and chokes are the ‘aspirin’ for RF on cables.”
Stereo speaker leads often act as antennas to pick up RF signals. What is one method you can use to minimize this effect?
Connect the speakers through audio attenuators
Connect the speakers through series capacitors

Shorten the leads is correct because long parallel wires make better antennas. Shorter leads intercept less RF and present a less efficient pickup path. Lengthening them makes the problem worse, and audio attenuators or series capacitors do not specifically address RF pickup on the leads themselves. Memory Trick: “Less wire, less antenna.”
One method of preventing RF from entering a stereo set through the speaker leads is to wrap each of the speaker leads:

around a ferrite core is correct because ferrite increases the inductance for RF currents, choking them off while leaving audio essentially unchanged. Copper, iron bars, or wood do not provide the needed RF impedance in this way. Memory Trick: “If it’s ferrite, it fights RF.”

You are using an HF off-centre-fed (OCF) unbalanced antenna. When you transmit on SSB, distorted audio and noise are heard from an outboard amplified speaker. What device could you install in the transmission line to mitigate this problem?

A common-mode choke is correct because OCF and other unbalanced antennas often put RF current on the outside of the coax shield, which then flows into shack equipment and audio gear. A common-mode choke on the feed line blocks these currents. A low-pass filter only cleans up your transmitted RF spectrum; surge suppressors and tuners don’t directly stop common-mode RF from entering audio devices. Memory Trick: “Common-mode RF? Kill it with a choke on the feedline.”
What term describes the undesired creation of new frequency components when one or more signals enter a non-linear device?

Intermodulation is correct because non-linear devices mix input frequencies, producing sums, differences, and other combinations that weren’t present before. Phase or linear distortion alter the original signals without creating new frequencies, and aliasing is a sampling/ADC issue, not an RF nonlinearity effect. Memory Trick: “Non-linear in, more lines out (extra frequencies) = intermodulation.”
If someone tells you that signals from your hand-held transceiver are interfering with other signals on a frequency near yours, what could be the cause?
Your hand-held is transmitting spurious emissions
You need to reduce your output power
Your hand-held has a chirp due to low battery voltage

Your hand-held is transmitting spurious emissions is correct because interference on nearby frequencies usually means the transmitter is radiating energy outside its assigned channel, such as harmonics or other unwanted products. Low power, chirp, or wrong offset mainly affect your own signal quality, not nearby channels. Memory Trick: If others just off your frequency complain, think “spurs splashing next door.”
If your transmitter sends signals outside the band where it is transmitting, what is this called?

Spurious emissions is correct because it is the general term for unwanted signals emitted outside the necessary bandwidth or outside the assigned band, such as harmonics or mixing products. Side tones are audio monitor tones, and chirp is a frequency wobble during keying. Memory Trick: “Spurious” = “spare, unwanted” signals.
What problem may occur if your transmitter is operated without its cover or other shielding in place?
It may transmit a chirpy signal
It may transmit a weak signal

It may radiate spurious emissions is correct because removing covers and shielding lets RF leak directly from internal circuits, bypassing normal filtering and causing strong off-frequency radiation. Power level, current draw, or chirp are not the primary issues here. Memory Trick: “No shield, RF is revealed (and leaks everywhere).”
In Morse code transmission, local RF interference (key clicks) is produced by:
frequency shifting caused by poor voltage regulation
poor wave-shaping caused by a defective filter capacitor
the making and breaking of the circuit at the Morse key

the making and breaking of the circuit at the Morse key is correct because hard on/off switching of RF produces very fast edges that contain wideband energy, heard as clicks on nearby receivers. The other options describe different faults but not the basic source of key clicks. Memory Trick: “Every hard on/off ‘click’ at the key becomes a click in someone’s speaker.”
Key clicks, heard from a Morse code transmitter at a distant receiver, are the result of:
too sharp rise and decay times of the keyed carrier
power supply hum modulating the carrier
sparks emitting RF from the key contacts
changes in oscillator frequency on keying

too sharp rise and decay times of the keyed carrier is correct because very abrupt keying generates a wide RF spectrum, which is heard as broad, clicky interference around the signal. Hum and frequency shift cause different kinds of distortion. Memory Trick: “Soften the edges, soften the clicks.”
In a Morse code transmission, broad bandwidth RF interference (key clicks) heard at a distance is produced by:

poor shaping of the waveform is correct because if the RF envelope rises and falls too abruptly, it creates many side frequencies, producing wide key clicks. The other issues may cause chirp or noise but not the classic wide click pattern. Memory Trick: “Good shaping, narrow signal; bad shaping, clicky signal.”
What should you do if you learn your transmitter is producing key clicks?
Use a choke in the RF power output
Check the keying filter and the functioning of later stages

Check the keying filter and the functioning of later stages is correct because key clicks are usually cured by improving the RF envelope shaping in the keying and amplifier stages (for example with proper shaping or ALC). Adjusting only the key or power supply does not directly fix the RF envelope. Memory Trick: “Key clicks are born in the shaping circuits, so fix the shaping path.”
What term describes an unwanted oscillation in an amplifier or oscillator circuit?

Parasitic oscillation is correct because it refers to an unintended self-oscillation at some frequency, often different from the desired one, inside an RF stage. Secondary emission is a tube effect, instability is general drift, and harmonics are multiples of a normal signal, not random extra oscillations. Memory Trick: “Parasitic = a ‘hitchhiker’ oscillation you did not invite.”
What can cause parasitic oscillations in a stage?

Unwanted positive feedback is correct because positive feedback reinforces any small signal and can cause an amplifier to break into self-oscillation. Negative feedback tends to stabilize, not oscillate. Drift and supply issues may move frequency but are not the root of a parasitic oscillation. Memory Trick: “Positive feedback pushes gain over the edge into oscillation.”
Transmitter RF amplifiers can generate parasitic oscillations:
on harmonics of the transmitter frequency
above or below the transmitter frequency

above or below the transmitter frequency is correct because parasitic oscillations can occur at various unintended frequencies, not just exact harmonics or only on VHF. They may show up at lower or higher frequencies depending on stray capacitances and inductances. Memory Trick: “Parasites pick their own frequency, not just neat harmonics.”
If a neighbour reports television interference on one or two channels only when you transmit on 15 metres, what is probably the cause of the interference?

Harmonic emissions from your transmitter is correct because a harmonic of your 21 MHz signal can fall in or near a VHF TV channel, affecting just one or a few channels. Overload typically affects many channels at once, and parasitic oscillations are less predictable in frequency. Memory Trick: “Single TV band hit by HF station? Suspect harmonics lining up.”
Unwanted signals that are combined with a 60 Hz hum
Unwanted signals caused by mixing with a nearby transmitter
Signals which cause skip propagation to occur
Unwanted signals at frequencies which are multiples of the fundamental (operating) frequency

Unwanted signals at frequencies which are multiples of the fundamental (operating) frequency is correct because harmonics occur at 2x, 3x, 4x, etc., the carrier frequency when stages are non-linear or filtering is poor. Hum and mixing are different phenomena. Memory Trick: “Harmonics march in multiples: 2f, 3f, 4f...”
Why are harmonic emissions from an amateur radio station not wanted?
They may cause interference to other stations
They may result in excessive power dissipation
They may overload a nearby transmitter
They may interfere with stations on adjacent frequencies

They may cause interference to other stations is correct because harmonics often fall in other bands and services, such as TV, FM broadcast, or other amateur bands, causing harmful interference. Power dissipation and overload are not the main regulatory concern. Memory Trick: “Harmonics = you are accidentally on multiple bands at once, annoying others.”
What term describes unwanted radio energy transmitted just outside the necessary bandwidth?

Out-of-band emissions is correct because it refers to radiation on frequencies just outside the assigned band or channel, such as excessive sidebands or splatter. Harmonics are at multiples of the carrier, and “spurious” is a broader category that includes harmonics and out-of-band energy. Memory Trick: “Too close to the band edge but still outside = out-of-band.”
If you are told your station was heard on 21.375 MHz but at the time you were operating on 7.125 MHz. What is one reason that could cause this to happen?
You were sending CW too fast
Your transmitter's power-supply filter capacitor is defective
Your transmitter's power-supply filter choke is defective

Your transmitter radiates harmonic signals is correct because 21.375 MHz is exactly 3 times 7.125 MHz, so this is the third harmonic of your operating frequency. That points directly to inadequate harmonic suppression. CW speed or power-supply ripple does not produce such an exact multiple. Memory Trick: “Heard on a multiple = it is a harmonic.”
Unwanted feedback in an amplifier stage

Overmodulating a transmitter is correct because when the audio level is too high, the signal goes non-linear and its sidebands spread out, causing interference to adjacent frequencies known as splatter. Fast keying or non-resonant antennas do not create the same wide SSB/AM sideband mess. Memory Trick: “Too much mic gain = ugly wide ‘splatter rain’ around your channel.”
A television tuned to channel 3 (60 MHz - 66 MHz) experiences interference when you are transmitting on the 15-metre band. Other channels are not affected. What is the most likely cause?
No high-pass filter on the TV
No high-pass filter at your transmitter

Harmonic emission from your transmitter is correct because a particular harmonic of your HF signal can land in the channel 3 band so that only that channel is disturbed. Overload or lack of filters typically affects several channels or creates more general problems. Memory Trick: “One TV channel, one matching harmonic.”
What is the probable cause of "flat topping" (non-linear operation) of an amplifier in an SSB transmitter?

Excessive microphone gain is correct because driving the SSB stages too hard pushes them into saturation, clipping the peaks of the RF envelope. On a scope this looks like a flat top and on the air it sounds distorted and wide. Filters and supply issues can cause other problems but are not the classic flat-topping cause. Memory Trick: “If the RF peaks are cut off flat, your mic gain is too fat.”
Which of the following may cause excessive harmonics in a transmitter?

Overdriven stages is correct because when amplifier stages are driven beyond their linear region, they produce strong harmonic and intermodulation products. Antenna or tuner issues mainly affect matching and SWR, not the creation of harmonics at the source. Memory Trick: “Push the amp too hard, and it spits out lots of extra frequencies.”
An interfering signal from an HF transmitter is found to have a frequency of 56 MHz. What could be the source?
Crystal oscillator operating on its fundamental

Second harmonic of a 10-metre transmission is correct because the 10-metre band is around 28 MHz, and 2 × 28 MHz = 56 MHz. The other options do not match 56 MHz as neatly as a simple second harmonic from 10 metres. Memory Trick: “56 is double 28, so think 10-metre second harmonic.”
Harmonics may be produced in the RF power amplifier of a transmitter if:
excessive drive signal is applied to it
the output tank circuit is tuned to the fundamental frequency
modulation is applied to a high-level stage

excessive drive signal is applied to it is correct because overdriving the RF power amplifier pushes it out of its linear region and causes distortion, which generates harmonics and other spurious signals. Proper drive keeps the stage linear and the output spectrum clean. Memory Trick: Think “too much drive = distorted and full of harmonics.”
What is the frequency response of an ideal notch filter?
Attenuate all frequencies except a range of frequencies
Attenuate one frequency and pass all others
Attenuate a range of frequencies and pass all others
Attenuate all frequencies except one single frequency

Attenuate one frequency and pass all others is correct because a notch (band-stop) filter is designed to place a very deep “notch” at one specific frequency while leaving the rest of the spectrum largely unaffected. The other answers describe band-pass or wide band-reject responses, not a sharp notch. Memory Trick: Picture a graph with one deep narrow “bite” taken out at the problem frequency.
A filter attenuates frequencies below its cut-off frequency of 60 MHz. What type of filter is it?

High-pass is correct because a high-pass filter rejects (attenuates) low frequencies and allows frequencies above the cut-off (here 60 MHz) to pass. Low-pass is the opposite, and band-pass or notch would only pass or reject a limited slice. Memory Trick: “High-pass lets the highs pass, blocks the lows.”
What type of filter attenuates RF energy above and below a certain range of frequencies?

Band-pass is correct because a band-pass filter allows only a chosen band of frequencies through and attenuates signals both below and above that band. High-pass and low-pass each work on one side only, and a notch filter removes a narrow slice instead of passing it. Memory Trick: “Band-pass = only one slice of the spectrum gets through.”
Why should the impedance of a filter match the transmission line where it is inserted?
To preserve the balance of the line
To minimize noise in the receiver

To avoid unwanted reflection is correct because when the filter’s impedance matches the transmission line (for example 50 ohms), power flows smoothly with minimal standing waves. A mismatch causes reflections, higher SWR, and extra loss. Memory Trick: “50 ohms into 50 ohms = no echoes, no surprises.”
Listening to shortwave on a low-cost software defined receiver (SDR), you hear several stations known to operate on much higher frequencies. What type of filter could help?

Low-pass is correct because placing a low-pass filter ahead of the SDR will pass only the desired HF shortwave range and strongly attenuate higher-frequency VHF/UHF signals that are folding back (aliasing) into the HF spectrum. High-pass or band-reject filters would not cleanly remove all the higher-frequency stations. Memory Trick: “To keep only HF, ‘low-pass’ lets the low stuff pass.”
You need to install an AC line filter to reduce radio frequency noise heard in your station equipment. What type of frequency response should it have?

Low-pass is correct because the AC mains is at low frequency (50 or 60 Hz), so you want to pass that while blocking high-frequency RF noise riding on the power line. A low-pass filter does exactly that. High-pass or band-pass responses would block or distort the mains power itself. Memory Trick: “AC is low frequency, so use low-pass on the power line.”
A strong interfering signal is very close to your receive frequency. Which type of filter can effectively suppress it?

Notch is correct because a notch filter can place a very narrow, deep rejection at the exact frequency of the interfering signal while leaving nearby desired frequencies mostly unaffected. Broad low-, high-, or band-reject filters would remove too much of the wanted band. Memory Trick: “Carve a tiny notch exactly where the pest lives.”
In a Field Day operation with separate transmitters assigned to specific bands, what type of filter is needed on the receivers to minimize interference?

Band-pass is correct because each receiver can use a band-pass filter for its assigned band, greatly attenuating strong signals from other Field Day transmitters on different bands. Low-pass or high-pass filtering is too broad, and band-reject removes only a single unwanted range instead of isolating one operating band. Memory Trick: “One band per station? Give each receiver a band-pass window on just that band.”

A nearby high-power HF broadcast station in the 31-metre band is interfering with your reception on the 40-metre and 30-metre bands. What type of filter is needed on the receiver to minimize interference?

Band-reject is correct because you want to notch out (reject) just the strong 31-metre broadcast band while still receiving both lower-frequency 40 metres and higher-frequency 30 metres. A band-pass filter would only let one band through, and low- or high-pass would remove either the desired lower or higher band. Memory Trick: “One noisy band in the middle? Use band-reject to ‘erase’ that band.”
Your 2-metre station suffers receiver overload from several land mobile service transmitters on adjacent bands. What type of filter could help?

Band-pass is correct because a 2-metre band-pass filter will strongly pass only the 144–148 MHz region (in most countries) and attenuate strong out-of-band land mobile signals above and below that range, reducing overload. A single notch would remove only one interfering signal, and low- or high-pass filters are not selective enough. Memory Trick: “To protect 2 metres from neighbours, frame it with a band-pass window.”
A filter attenuates frequencies above its cut-off frequency of 40 MHz. What type of filter is it?

Low-pass is correct because a low-pass filter passes signals below its cut-off (40 MHz here) and attenuates higher-frequency signals. High-pass is the opposite, band-pass passes only a slice, and a notch removes just a narrow range. Memory Trick: “Below the cutoff passes, above it does not → low-pass.”
